IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The object of this proposal is to develop a local cancer immunotherapy to deliver a safe and effective particle- anchored cytokine as a novel combination regimen for eliciting anti-tumor immunity in solid tumors. This project will also explore the impact of this local cancer immunotherapy on the tumor microenvironment in order to decipher the underlying mechanisms. The success of this project will provide a new and effective treatment option to potentiate immunotherapy while also ameliorating systemic toxicity, advance the research of drug delivery technology, and improve our understanding of how the combined localized immunotherapeutics impact the tumor immune infiltrations that boost anti-tumor efficacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gastric ulcer is characterized by full thickness mucosal injury with a cavity surrounded by acute and chronic inflammation, which is a major cause of gastrointestinal surgery with high morbidity and mortality. Our identification of reprogramming of acid secreting parietal cells into other cell types during gastric ulcer repair has led to the design of present studies that will validate the function of parietal cells as reserve stem cells in gastric ulcer healing and dissect the role of Sox4 in the process. The results of this study will enlighten the molecular mechanism of parietal cell plasticity and its role in gastric ulcer healing, and lead to the discovery of novel targets for treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fusion-positive alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma (FP-RMS or ARMS) is one the most fatal cancers of childhood. While the disease is still poorly understood, a fusion protein called PAX3-FOXO1 (i.e., PAX3::FOXO1, P3F) is a critical driver of ARMS and dysregulates the expression of many disease genes. The PAX3-FOXO1 fusion protein was discovered three decades ago, yet it has not been successfully targeted for treating FP-RMS. Our comprehensive, coordinated discovery approach will identify small molecules that impact PAX3-FOXO1 activity, exploring multiple mechanisms of action and accelerating the development of agents to treat this cancer of unmet need.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project narrative We do not yet understand why animals behave the way they do, why the same sensory input (e.g., a smell or a sound) can elicit vastly different behaviors across individuals. To study how animals interpret sensory information and turn this information into decisions for survival, we examine a simple creature –a fly larva– as it performs one of the most important survival tasks: finding a food source. By quantifying, modeling, and then controlling the nervous system of a larva while it converts information from an ambiguous world into accurate navigational decisions, we aim to reveal the inner workings of a simple yet remarkably powerful brain and build new theories of how our own brain works.
PI_NAMEs: LOUIS, MATTHIEU R. P. J. C. G. (contact)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The effectiveness of the widely prescribed drug, levodopa, in treating motor impairment in Parkinson’s disease declines over time, in part due to a progressive shortening in the time for which each dose of levodopa is effective. We recently found that repeated optogenetic stimulation of a specific neuron type in the external globus pallidus – the parvalbumin-expressing neurons – led to long-term rescue of locomotion deficit in parkinsonian mice, which recapitulates aspects of levodopa’s long-term rescue (its “long-duration response”). This project will examine the neural circuitry that underlies this beneficial effect of external globus pallidus stimulation; its elucidation will advance our knowledge of both therapeutic utility and potential side effects of globus pallidus deep brain stimulation for Parkinson’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Myasthenia gravis is a chronic debilitating autoimmune disease caused by autoantibodies to nicotinic acetylcholine receptor of skeletal muscles. The goal of this proposal is to develop an antigen-specific cell therapy for myasthenia gravis by infusing chimeric antigen receptor-engineered regulatory T cells using a rodent disease model. This study will provide a proof-of-principle for the effectiveness of the therapy and outline a road map for translating the discovery to clinical use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE d Opioid use disorder (OUD) frequently co-occurs with intimate partner violence (IPV) and posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD), and there is an imminent need for the development of digital clinical decision-support tools to screen, assess, and appropriately refer individuals with IPV and PTSD to treatment. The proposed study will design and test the implementation and effectiveness of a digital toolkit for screening, referral, and planning for IPV and PTSD in three opioid treatment programs in South Carolina. Findings will demonstrate how a digital toolkit for may reduce IPV and PTSD, increase uptake of referral, and decrease opioid use and associated psychiatric conditions among a population in dire need.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative No engaging, immersive intervention exists for vaping cessation therapy, and there is no clinical trial to test the efficacy of embedding cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) content into virtual reality (VR) to increase success at quitting. We are expanding on our previous work, CESSATION—Charles River’s VR-based CBT-embedded app for smoking cessation—to focus on vaping, producing Novel, On-demand VR for Accessible, Practical, and Engaging therapy (NO VAPE). Current vaping cessation treatments lag far behind treatment for other substance use disorders (SUDs); therefore, a commercially available VR app to be combined with hybrid live and digitized CBT or used alone that increases access, reduces costs, is engaging, realistic, available on-demand, and effective for initiating and maintaining abstinence will help more people quit vaping.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS RIO GRANDE VALLEY
PHR: The objective is to acquire and install state-of-the-art individually ventilated caging in a newly constructed animal facility, which is dedicated to breeding and conducting biomedical research with laboratory opossums. The cages will provide an optimal environment for the animals, and are highly efficient with respect to requirement for energy and provision of care. This laboratory opossum research resource is the only large one of its kind in the world, and it serves the nation’s biomedical research community by providing opportunities for collaborative research on site, and by providing animals and biological materials from them to investigators at other institutions.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The University of Illinois Chicago (UIC) has a robust animal-based research program that supports over $110 million in biomedical research and an average daily census of approximately 40,000 animals. UIC proposes to modernize its centrally managed animal facilities by purchasing and installing a cloud-based environmental monitoring system that will improve animal well-being, safety, regulatory compliance, and ensure experimental reproducibility while also resulting in significant efficiencies in operational management. Such an upgrade will directly improve the institution's animal facility infrastructure to facilitate both biomedical research discoveries and research reproducibility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Experience drives structural and functional remodeling of neuronal circuits in the brain during discrete developmental windows called critical periods, after which circuits stabilize. Premature closure of critical periods is thought to contribute to the development of autism spectrum disorders due to an early loss of neural plasticity, and in turn, reduced cognitive flexibility. The experiments outlined in this proposal will test whether critical period plasticity can be reopened and will assesses the structural and functional consequences of boosting neural plasticity in mature circuits.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD), also known as chronic lung disease of prematurity, is the most consequential complication of preterm birth and is a leading pediatric cause of disability and early death. Pathologic gastroesophageal reflux (GER) contributes to respiratory disease in >40% of very preterm infants with BPD through induction of bronchospasm, hypoxemia, and aspiration induced lung injury. Transpyloric feeding reduces aerodigestive sequelae of GER in high-risk older children and adults but has uncertain safety and efficacy in infants; this randomized trial will be the first to determine the tolerability and physiologic efficacy of transpyloric feeding to reduce objectively diagnosed GER in preterm infants with BPD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative Cleft Lip and palate is a common, but poorly understood birth defect. It is known to have genetic, epigenetic and environmental causes, yet most animal models for its development only include genetics. Here, we develop an epigenetic model of cleft lip and palate to model how an epigenetic change can cause a cleft to form.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative A primary reason we forget is because we store a vast number of memories and interference between these memories becomes inevitable. The proposed research seeks to identify how memories, and corresponding neural representations of memories, adapt to interference such that forgetting is prevented. By establishing fundamental new insight into how the brain resolves interference between similar memories, this research will be broadly relevant to disorders and diseases which affect the memory system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Mycobacterium abscessus are versatile opportunistic pathogens that can cause devastating persistent infections. We have demonstrated that P. aeruginosa potently antagonizes M. abscessus when co-cultured as dual-species biofilms and propose that inter-bacterial antagonism of M. abscessus by P. aeruginosa is mediated by a novel antibacterial strategy. This research will directly benefit people with inflammatory and muco-obstructive lung disorders as well as in patients infected with these organisms in wounds and abscesses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding how the immune system is able to interact with the organisms that live on our body has revealed unique immune-microbe interactions that are now known to influence mammalian health. This has yet to be done with our resident viral community. Our proposal will be the first to catalog and identify what commensal viruses interact with antibodies in humans, which has the potential to identify novel viruses that are relevant to human health and will facilitate future mechanistic studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Recent research indicates that conventional health interventions focusing on individual knowledge and behavior are of limited effectiveness. Nutrition based disease in childhood, specifically Early Childhood Caries and obesity, are closely linked to social context and environment. Low income and immigrant children are at particularly high risk. The Mothers’ Action Project for Child Health (MAP- CH) seeks to intervene at the level of social level by creating new social networks for low income South Asian mothers. Mothers living in close proximity will be recruited into Mothers’ Clubs of 10-12 mothers. While receiving health education and skill building over a 12 month program, mothers will engage in activities designed to strengthen social ties among Club members. If successful, the project will provide a model for the development of social network interventions to improve child nutrition-based disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative For many individuals with incomplete spinal cord injury, walking recovery is a primary goal. While functional walking requires trunk control and stepping, rehabilitation emphasizes stepping and overlooks trunk control, leaving individuals with severe trunk control impairments that increase fall risk and cause reliance on assistive devices. The proposed project will quantify neuromechanical control of the trunk during walking and provide a foundation to address this critical component of walking function after incomplete spinal cord injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narra+ve Smoking is responsible for over 8 million preventable deaths annually. Currently, varenicline is the most eﬀec+ve non- nico+ne replacement therapy (non-NRT) for smoking cessa+on. However, its success rate is only 22%, and over 67% of pa+ents discon+nue treatment due to adverse events and ineﬀec+veness. Enhancing varenicline's eﬃcacy and pa+ent compliance could have a signiﬁcant impact on overall health outcomes and healthcare costs. The objec+ve of our STTR Phase I grant is to develop a more eﬀec+ve smoking cessa+on treatment. This will be achieved by crea+ng and tes+ng prodrugs of varenicline with a longer dura+on of ac+on and the ability to be formulated into various administra+on methods. Our prodrugs will be tested to evaluate their impact on speciﬁc markers associated with nico+ne addic+on. The goal is to iden+fy and select the most promising prodrug candidates that stabilize basal dopamine levels and reduce nico+ne self-administra+on. Successful execu+on of our strategy has the poten+al to help over 20 million adult smokers in the US who are trying to quit. Given the overall health impacts of smoking, even a modest increase in eﬃcacy and pa+ent compliance with the best available non-NRT will have a drama+c eﬀect. As part of our development plan, we seek mentorship through the I- Corps™ program to help us deﬁne the unique value proposi+on for our prodrug.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The gene, protein and lipid changes that contribute to the enlargement of adipocytes or hypertrophy resulting in obesity remain largely unknown. This gap in knowledge limits the ability to successfully develop therapeutics for weight loss or weight gain prevention, which we aim to address using our novel model of adipocyte hypertrophy in combination with an unbias multi-omic approach. In addition to providing critical insight into the cellular processes underlying adiposity, the proposed studies have the potential to identify Zfp949 gene regulation as a possible therapeutic candidates for obesity and other lipid-associated disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most aggressive type of adult leukemia that results in less than 30% of 5- year survival rates. Most AML studies focus on discovering the intrinsic mutations that generate AML cells, however, less is known about the role of the bone marrow microenvironment (BMME) in progressing the disease. The project is taking an innovative approach to explore the role of CCL3-mediate BMME dysregulation and polypharmacy impact during AML chemotherapy using an in vitro model of the human BMME-on-a-chip.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE “Ending the HIV Epidemic in the US” is an ambitious initiative launched in 2019, aiming to eradicate HIV by 2030 in the United States. To achieve this, a critical need is to identify the root causes contributing to HIV acquisition. Finding causal effects between drug use disorders and HIV acquisition and how these causal effects are mediated by the hosts’ gut microbiota and immune responses are essential for designing effective prevention and intervention strategies, guiding public health policies, understanding the mechanisms involved, and ultimately reducing the burden of HIV in populations affected by drug use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The most common cause of idiopathic and familial Parkinson’s disease, an adult onset movement neurodegenerative disorder, are mutations in leucine-rich repeat kinase 2 (LRRK2). The overarching goal of this proposal is to understand how the DNA repair enzyme PARP1 impacts mitochondrial function. It is hoped that cellular pathways involved in maintaining genome integrity will reveal potential new therapeutic strategies to treat this devastating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because chronic pain imposes a substantial burden on the healthcare system and exerts an enormous impact on the quality of life of approximately 20-30% of U.S adults and their families. As poor sleep is a risk factor of chronic pain, understanding specific mechanisms of how sleep impacts chronic pain is important. The proposed research is directly relevant to the part of NIH's mission that pertains to improving the health of the nation by conducting research onsleep and pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Measurement of the axial length (AL) of the eye has wide applications in eye research and clinical practice; however, it relies on an estimate of the refractive index of the lens (NLens), which has never been accurately measured for individual eyes in vivo. The primary goal of this proposed project is to combine a ray-traceable Scheimpflug imaging system (RTSI), developed recently by the contact PI, Dr. He, with a whole-eye OCT (WE- OCT) to measure the (NLens) and axial length (AL) simultaneously for human eyes in vivo. This system will be used to derive accurate AL measurements for a group of young adults and cataract patients and will present a substantial breakthrough in the methodology for accurately measuring the AL of the eye.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will reveal specific details about how microbes and the host interact during a critical developmental period of early-life to determine invariant Natural Killer T (iNKT) cell levels and susceptibility or resistance to enteric diseases in later-life. Such information is of potential im- portance to diseases of the esophagus (e.g. eosinophilic esophagitis), small intestine (e.g. celiac disease) and colon (e.g. infections, cancer and inflammatory bowel disease) where iNKT cells have been shown to play a role. The proposed studies are relevant to the mission of the NIDDK because they will identify a new cell type that regulates immune cells and provide information that could be potentially used to prevent or treat mucosal dis- eases that depend upon iNKT cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: TEXAS TECH UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIS CENTER
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement (Project Narrative) Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a slowly progressing disease with significant health, social and occupational consequences, but its subtle development and untreatable nature require broader understanding of the underlying molecular mechanisms leading to it. The proposed research project focuses on alternative polyadenylation (APA) as a molecular mechanism regulating protein expression in a cell type-specific manner in the brain during the development of AD. The successful completion of the project’s aims will provide knowledge about molecular pathways altered by APA in AD in a cell type-specific manner, thus contributing to the development of new therapies for the prevention and/or treatment of Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this proposal is to study the human virome in tissues from across the whole-body and determine the mechanisms by which viruses persist in these deep tissues. We will leverage the unique San Francisco POstmortem Systematic InvesTigation of Sudden Cardiac Death (POST SCD) study and our prospective tissue collection cohort for in-depth study of host-virus responses that facilitate the virome and impact overall health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative Abnormal gut microbiota (dysbiosis) has been implicated in the pathogenesis and progression of Parkinson’s disease (PD), but definitive evidence is lacking. We propose a cross-sectional and longitudinal study to collect symptoms, biomarkers, and microbiota data from PD patients of different phenotypes and demographics (both White and Black populations), with age- and sex- matched healthy controls included as well. We will test the hypothesis that dysbiosis and microbiota metabolomics are markers of PD phenotypes, predictive of the development and progression of PD and PD phenotypes, and potential targets for disease modifying therapies.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative: Functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS) is a popular neuroimaging method for pediatric brain imaging studies. However, since the sensitivity of fNIRS varies exponentially with the depth of the brain from the sensors placed on the scalp, it is impossible to distinguish between changes in the magnitude of evoked brain activity signals and changes in thicknesses of the extracerebral layers of the head or systematic variations in anatomy. This project introduces a novel analysis approach to use priors on the distribution of structural factors extracted from existing databases of structural MRI to incorporate marginal anatomical uncertainty per demographics as part of group level statistical tests for fNIRS in pediatric studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative Periodontitis, one of the most prevalent oral diseases, is a leading cause of tooth loss, but standard mechanical debridement cannot effectively treat patients with severe periodontitis. This project aims to develop engineered cytokine-secreting Limosilactobacillus reuteri encapsulated in a microneedle patch to treat periodontitis in preclinical models. The results will advance the applications of engineered microorganisms combined with novel biomaterials in treating periodontitis through host modulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because the GGGGCC hexanucleotide repeat expansion in the C9orf72 locus is the most common cause of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and the related neurodegenerative disorder, frontotemporal dementia (FTD). We propose to apply our DNA methylation editing tools to study the epigenetic mechanisms contributing to the pathogenesis of C9orf72 ALS/FTD. Precise editing of C9orf72 methylation will establish the functional role of these epigenetic events in the pathogenesis of C9orf72 ALS/FTD and demonstrate the therapeutic potential that editing methylation may have for the most commonly known cause of ALS/FTD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Orphan G Protein Coupled Receptors (oGPCRs) constitute an untapped pool of pharmacological targets. Here, we will adopt optimized tools and cell-based assays to identify endogenous and synthetic candidate ligands for GPR156, a clinically relevant drug target for treating hearing and balance disorders. At the same time, we will define the components of the signaling complex involving GPR156 in establishing planar cell polarity in hair cells of the inner ear.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Surgical removal of brain tumors requires a delicate balance between maximum resection of the tumor and maximum preservation of neurological function, also known as maximum safe resection. Resting-state functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) is a rapidly developing approach for presurgical mapping of cortical brain function that does not require patient participation. It can complement task-based functional MRI in patients who have difficulties performing tasks and can efficiently map a large number of functional brain systems to guide surgery. It replaces traditional approaches of functional MRI that require patient participation in patients with functional impairment and holds considerable promise for intra-operative guidance of minimally invasive surgery. Here, we propose a fully automated, highly sensitive and cost-effective real-time resting-state functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging analysis software tool on a custom high-performance computer workstation for presurgical and intraoperative mapping of cortical brain function, building on TurboFIRE, a powerful real-time rtfMRI and sfMRI analysis software tool and the success of a prior Phase I STTR program. This approach meets urgent clinical needs and has high commercial potential for seamlessly integrating resting-state functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging into the clinical workflow of presurgical planning and intra-operative MRI. This technology will have significant clinical and commercial potential for a wide range of neurological and psychiatric applications beyond pre-surgical mapping in patients with brain tumors. It opens up functional brain mapping to patient populations that have been difficult to study in the past.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative  This Dissertation Award (R36 Substance Use/Substance Use Disorder Dissertation Research Award (R36 Clinical Trials Optional)) challenges existing conceptualizations of racism-related experiences through an innovative framework that includes historical and present-day dimensions. Historical trauma may intensify traumatic stress-related reactions in response to present-day racial discrimination for Black young adults and may provide critical insight into the observed disparities in polysubstance use risk beyond what a unidimensional approach of racial discrimination can provide. Lastly, the omission of historical trauma in research examining racial discrimination as a risk factor for polysubstance use presents a critical barrier for the development of novel, comprehensive culturally-relevant tools and interventions that effectively reduce polysubstance use in Black young adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Anxiety is highly prevalent in those with opiate use disorder, and is linked to earlier and more rapid progression, and high probability of co-use GABAA receptor positive modulators, such as benzodiazepines (BZDs), the current standard of care treatment for fast-acting relief of anxiety. BZDs are involved in an estimated 12,000 overdose fatalities each year in the US, largely due to the concomitant use with other CNS depressants, such as opioids. Our innovation is aimed at providing equally effective fast-acting treatments for anxiety that do not enhance opioid-induced respiratory depression to prevent overdose fatalities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: 8. Project Narrative: Fusion oncoproteins act as the key drivers of cancer formation and progression in many forms of pediatric and adolescent cancer. Our team of investigators will develop novel small molecules that impair the function of critical fusion oncoproteins through two approaches: 1) identifying small molecules that target transcriptional regulatory complexes that are co-opted by fusion oncoproteins to induce oncogenic gene expression programs, and 2) developing small molecules that impair protein sequences required for self-association of intrinsically disordered regions that are essential to the oncogenic nature of many fusion oncoproteins.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is currently no therapy that can prevent the development of epilepsy after brain trauma. Here we propose to test the efficacy of a novel compound, and determine its efficacy and tolerability in an animal model of posttraumatic epilepsy, in a setting that resembles the clinical practice of care of people with severe traumatic brain injury. We also aim to identify and validate novel biomarkers that can predict who will develop epilepsy and who may respond to a treatment that can prevent epilepsy, in hope that this may accelerate and optimize future efforts to develop new antiepileptogenic therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Neurons relies on lysosomal activity to maintain homeostasis and its disruption results in an irreversible process called neurodegeneration. This project will define how the deficiency of the TBCK protein disrupts the levels of the JIP4 protein and how this disruption could result in impairments to the maturation and motility of lysosomes. Such studies are crucial to understand how the novel interaction and mechanism between TBCK and JIP4 influences lysosomal functionality in neurons, and how this mechanism can be translated to other disorders, such as lysosomal storage disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Globally, alcohol causes more than 3 million deaths and is a leading avoidable risk factor. Currently, in low-resource settings like Tanzania, alcohol-related treatment and resources are scarce and our team has created an effective brief intervention to reduce alcohol use among patients at Kilimanjaro Christian Medical Center. This program planning project will conduct a mixed method feasibility assessment and co-design final intervention, implementation strategy and trial design work products to implement this innovative intervention in the Northern Tanzania region.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: The proposed study is relevant to public health because it addresses the critical lack of psychosocial interventions adapted and studied in Latin America for Spanish-speaking Latinos diagnosed with advanced cancer. Meaning-Centered psychotherapy (MCP), a novel psychotherapeutic intervention designed to help patients with advanced cancer sustain or enhance a sense of meaning, and it will be tested in a type 1 hybrid randomized clinical trial with Spanish-speaking Mexican patient with advanced cancer treated at the National Mexican Cancer Institute.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Pancreatic cancer is one of the deadliest solid tumor malignancies. With DUO-307, Duo Oncology combines a chemotherapeutic and an immunomodulatory agent to kill cancer cells and stimulate the body’s immune response to recognize and kill the cancer. This therapy is delivered as an ultrasmall nanomedicine that can penetrate the dense stroma tissue surrounding the tumor.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK STATE PSYCHIATRIC INSTITUTE DBA RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR MENTAL HYGIENE, INC
PHR: Project Narrative Millions of Americans suffer from deficits in reward processing in the context of psychiatric disorders, such as major depressive disorder and schizophrenia. The endogenous opioid system plays a key role in reward processing. In this project, we will test whether administering a novel compound that increases endogenous enkephalin levels can reverse reward processing deficits without raising the risk of substance use disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The overall goal of this research is to examine the psychosocial, ethical, and clinical implications of unexpected medical findings in healthy adult volunteer stem cell donors – the proposed project focuses on demonstrating our ability to collect these data. We will (1) conduct focus groups with past donors who have no unexpected medical findings and (2) conduct telephone interviews with, and collect biological samples from, donors who have received unexpected medical findings. Results from this study will lead directly to a larger investigation of unexpected medical findings in this healthy donor group, which will have implications for a broad range of healthy and ill individuals with such findings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Opioid use disorder (OUD) during pregnancy is a major contributor to maternal morbidity and mortality in the United States, and particularly in rural and low-resource obstetric settings. Collaborative care approaches to substance use treatment – which are designed to comprehensively treat the social, behavioral, and physical health needs of patients – have emerged as a way to address the complex needs of pregnant, postpartum, and parenting persons with OUD. This research project will adapt an innovative comprehensive care model for low- resource obstetric settings and will test the implementation and effects of the care model on maternal, infant, and family health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Recent research has shown that hand grip strength (HGS), an index linked to systemic physiological frailty and all-cause mortality, may provide a new biomarker of risk assessment of surgical readiness and potential of postoperative complication; diminutive preoperative HGS indicates a heightened risk of postsurgical complication. This project aims to develop a self-administrable dynamometer for older adults that uses a smartphone’s built-in vibration motor and sensor to record HGS, with the goal of enabling a machine learning- based risk prediction prior to admission day-of-surgery. An automated phone-sensor based surgical outcomes prediction tool has the power to enable remote monitoring to guide preoperative care through adapting prehabilitation protocol and timely intervention for unexpected health status changes needed for maximizing surgical preparedness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE Overdose with opioids (drugs similar to morphine, such as heroin) causes subjects to stop breathing enough and suffocate. An antidote to opioid overdose, naloxone, is widely distributed, but it requires a bystander to identify a person overdosing, obtain naloxone, and inject it properly; all within < 5 minutes to prevent brain damage, and somewhat longer to prevent death. Therefore, we have invented the DOVE device, which is an armband that detects opioid overdose and automatically injects the antidote, and we will further develop and test it here.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Myelin is essential for rapid nerve signaling and its loss in diseases like multiple sclerosis or after injury causes severe disability in patients. We propose to harness innovative tools and methods we developed to increase our fundamental understanding of how myelin forms normally during vertebrate central nervous system development, using both in vivo and primary cell culture approaches. These studies will contribute knowledge toward our ultimate goal of promoting remyelination in patients to reduce the burden of neurological diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is currently no therapy that can prevent the development of epilepsy after brain trauma. Here we propose to test the efficacy of a novel compound, and determine its efficacy and tolerability in an animal model of posttraumatic epilepsy, in a setting that resembles the clinical practice of care of people with severe traumatic brain injury. We also aim to identify and validate novel biomarkers that can predict who will develop epilepsy and who may respond to a treatment that can prevent epilepsy, in hope that this may accelerate and optimize future efforts to develop new antiepileptogenic therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The desmoplastic small round cell tumor (DSRCT) remains one of the most lethal adolescent/young adult (AYA) sarcomas. The EWSR1-WT1 gene fusion is the primary and defining genetic driver alteration in this sarcoma but a better understanding of EWSR1-WT1 oncogenic mechanisms is needed to identify novel, rational therapeutic strategies that will be more effective. We propose to address these knowledge gaps by establishing the first genetically engineered mouse model of DSRCT and to define its pathobiology more fully by harnessing two recent novel observations in DSRCT, namely induction of neotranscripts and recurrent ARID1A loss as a frequent additional genetic alteration in these cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The recent development of [11C]ORM13070, a PET radioligand for 2C-adrenergic receptors (ARs), became a milestone for the development of subtype-specific drugs and radioligands for ARs, whose nonspecific drugs are consumed every day by middle-aged or older population worldwide to prevent cardiovascular emergencies and to manage their blood pressure, as strategies for reducing the dangerous cardiac and neuronal side effects of the nonspecific drugs for ARs. The localized distribution of 2C-ARs in the limbic regions of the brain and their presynaptic function as autoreceptors and heteroreceptors, which regulate the levels of norepinephrine, dopamine, and serotonin in the synapse, motivated us to develop more practical and useful F-18 PET radiotracers for 2C-ARs based on [11C]ORM13070 and to monitor the receptors in viable states to help set up the therapeutic strategy for 2C-ARs. This proposal will use a stepwise approach to synthesize seven 1,4- benzodioxane derivatives followed by receptor-binding assays for the in vitro screening, and the selected compounds will be prepared as F-18 radiotracers for preclinical PET imaging studies and autoradiography, which will be compared to immunohistochemistry work to validate the PET imaging data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE: Radiation therapy (RT) is commonly used to treat brain tumors, however improvements are needed to make RT more effective against tumor cells and/or less damaging to normal brain cells. Our team of physicists, biologists and radiation oncologists has developed a platform to test genes and drugs as well as new types of radiation (ultra-high dose rate radiation, or FLASH-RT) to improve radiation therapy for brain tumors. This proposal describes how we will use this platform and our existing data to test combinations of standard and FLASH-RT with drugs targeting the ATM gene and other genes to improve treatment for brain tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Significant shifts in the gut microbiome are observed when humans are exposed to antibiotics or during gut inflammatory conditions, yet the causes and functional consequences of these shift events on human health, including the contributions of the gut virome, are poorly understood. The proposed study addresses this knowledge gap by leveraging an extensive collection of stools and associated clinical data from healthy or perturbed infants and adults to i) characterize the viruses associated with microbiome shift events and their bacterial hosts, ii) determine the in vitro and in vivo effects of antibiotics and inflammation on viral activities, and iii) define the immunological causes and effects of altered viromes on the mammalian host. By directly investigating viral-bacterial and viral-eukaryotic relationships, this project supports the goal of functionally characterizing the human virome to understand its role in human health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will determine if intraindividual cognitive variability can be used to identify early symptoms of neurodegeneration and vascular injury in American Indians, an underserved population with elevated risk of dementia due to high rates of cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and social vulnerability. The proposed work will identify less invasive ways to detect early signs of neurodegeneration, enabling earlier interventions to reduce the impact of dementia on individuals, their families, and their communities. The project is relevant to National Institute of Aging‘s mission because it will contribute new knowledge to differential diagnosis of symptomatic cognitive impairment and to develop biomarkers in asymptomatic individuals, expand and disseminate research on co-occurring conditions and dementia; and understand health differences and inequities associated with ethnic minority older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: Project Narrative Motivational interviewing is an effective counseling style to affect behavior change in patients, and it has shown its promise in behaviors influencing the severity of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2MD). However, training, consistency, and availability of a provider to preform motivational interviewing prevent it from being implemented effectively. With advances in AI and speech technology, this project examines the development and feasibility of translating some of the motivational interviewing expertise to a software agent that can help patients realize their ambivalence of their unhealthy behaviors that lead to T2DM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because integrating information from different sensory modalities is a fundamental but essential brain function, and, sensory integration deficits are prominent symptoms in people with autism, schizophrenia, and ADHD. The goal of this research plan is to identify the mechanisms used during development to create the circuitry responsible for sensory integration in the mouse superior colliculus, a midbrain sensory integrative structure, and determine the consequences to behavior when integration is disrupted. These findings will provide fundamental knowledge that will enable researchers to better understand and treat disorders of sensory integration.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Preterm labor leads to preterm delivery of an underdeveloped fetus in 50% of cases. There are no FDA- approved medications available to prevent preterm delivery. The research planned in this application will employ tissues from pregnant women and mice to explore the therapeutic potential of novel ‘designed multi-ligands’ and combination tocolytics to delay preterm birth. Our research Aims are designed to address myopathic dysregulation of the uterus to advance a ‘designed multi-ligand’ and combination drug strategy to prevent preterm birth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Relevance to Public Health: The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic has infected hundreds of millions, estimated to have resulted in over 15 million deaths, and has caused incalculable economic damage and social disruption worldwide. This grant will identify and develop comprehensive information on the contribution and influence of genetic variants and phenotypic characteristics/comorbidities on COVID-19 infection- and/or vaccine-induced immune responses. These data will help us understand how and why people do and do not respond appropriately to these vaccines, help us to give the right vaccine to the right person at the right time, and may help predict re-infection risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The human brain has approximately equal numbers of glia cells and neurons, and interactions between these cells are essential for all nervous system functions. Impaired glia-neuron interactions underlie many neurological diseases including Alzheimer's disease, Autism, epilepsy and may contribute to age-related neural decline. To understand glial contribution to nervous system health, aging and disease, we will dissect glia-neuron interactions with exquisite speed and molecular resolution in vivo by using a powerful genetic model we recently established.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Statistical analysis of big data from electronic medical records or other sources such as the national American Academy of Ophthalmology IRIS® registry can provide high impact evidence regarding disease diagnosis, surveil- lance and treatment, including studying rare events. However, these study designs are subject to selection bias and unreliable results due to subgroups with sparse data caused by imbalances among patient categories, and analysis of millions of records on patient level is a significant computational investment of time and cost, during which software and/or computer crashes often occur. We aim to develop novel subsampling strategies such that sufficient data will be selected to guarantee statistical efficiency and unbiased estimation of covariate effects for both rare and non-rare events and we will build new statistical software for the eye and medical community to use when they analyze big data from EMRs including the IRIS registry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE [parent project] Extracellular vesicles (EVs) show great promise as next-generation targeted drug delivery systems, but their complexity and heterogeneity in structure, composition, and function have stalled their translational use. In this study we propose physicochemical approaches to homogenize EVs and fuse them with synthetic drug loaded liposomes to engineer a drug delivery vehicle that delivers a therapeutic payload with high intracranial uptake. We will test the safety and biodistribution of the engineered product as well as its efficacy in a glioblastoma orthotopic mouse model

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Binge drinking both induces ethanol tolerance and has complex and lasting effects on sleep. We and others discovered clues that sleep genes and brain circuits encode aspects of ethanol tolerance. Our goal is to determine the extent of the genetic and circuit overlap; our results will lead to in-depth understanding of the tolerance:sleep relationship and potentially point to ways to manage alcohol's effects on sleep.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transcription coupled-nucleotide excision repair (TC-NER) plays a critical role in maintaining genome stability by repairing DNA lesions that would otherwise disrupt the expression of genes; however, a number of the key steps in TC-NER remain poorly defined. This proposal aims to characterize the molecular basis by which the transcription elongation factor Elf1 regulates TC-NER through its carboxyl-terminal domain (CTD), and how the Elf1 CTD is regulated by phosphorylation and the elongation factors Spt4/Spt5. Successful completion of these aims should provide new insights into the functions of a key proteins that regulate transcription-coupled DNA repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The physical, emotional, and societal costs of Lewy body diseases (LBD), including Parkinson’s disease and dementia with Lewy bodies, will increase over the coming decades as more of us live longer; in fact, the number of people with LBD is expected to double in the USA by the year 2040 unless we find safe and effective means to cure, delay onset, or slow progression of these diseases. Non-motor features, including gastrointestinal symptoms like constipation, are a common feature of LBD with serious subsequent impact on quality of life and caregiver burden. By determining the interplay between the gut microbiota and immune system, our project is focused on the clear imperative to understand the role of gut health in the pathogenesis of LBD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transgender youth face a high risk for serious mental health problems (e.g., suicidality, depression, anxiety) relative to cisgender youth due to their disproportionate exposure to transphobic discrimination and trauma, and significant barriers to mental health care. The proposed project seeks to increase mental health care access for transgender youth by enhancing the dissemination of evidence-based mHealth interventions through the design of a gender-affirming training intervention for lay health workers (LHWs), with cultural tailoring for transgender youth of Color and their caregivers. The aims of the current project are to: (Aim 1) co- design a mechanism-driven gender-affirming training intervention for LHWs, then (Aim 2) build the gender- affirming LHW training intervention via usability testing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative This Diversity Supplement will support Ms. Blevins to examine the role of psychological pain in the relationship between discrimination and substance use among Black, Indigenous, and Persons of Color (BIPOC) adults, who have been and continue to be impacted by discrimination and other social stressors on a daily basis, including when seeking healthcare. We will conduct focus groups and use daily questionnaires via a smartphone application to study the specific factors that influence substance use among BIPOC adults, which will inform and support data collection pertaining to healthcare discrimination and psychological pain in patients who use substances and are seeking care within the Emergency Room at Los Angeles General Medical Center. Together with the parent study, this will be the first study to provide an in-depth description of the impact of discrimination on substance use behaviors and addiction vulnerability in the context of daily and prolonged psychological pain among BIPOC adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The overall goal of this work is to improve outcomes for neuroendocrine tumor (NET) patients by fashioning cost effective, patient friendly technology to enable 177Lu-DOTATATE treatment personalization based upon daily, at- home measurements of the radioactivity in their organs at risk and tumors. We are developing compact, durable, easily transportable technology that will enable treatment personalization while forgoing the need for serial visits to imaging centers over 7 plus days for each treatment administration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Migraine is characterized by dysregulation of the autonomic nervous system, including functional and structural alterations of the insula, and by sensitization to pain and interoceptive sensations such as nausea as a function of the phase of the episodic migraine cycle. The aim of this proposal is to investigate whether neural mechanisms of interoceptive awareness are altered in individuals with episodic migraine, and to what extent interoceptive awareness varies across phases of the episodic migraine cycle. In the proposed project, we will use functional MRI to compare brain response in the insula during an interoceptive attention task between people with episodic migraine versus healthy control participants, and will examine how that response varies across phases of the migraine cycle.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiometabolic diseases like hypertension and type II diabetes are increasing globally, particularly in low- and middle-income countries, but little evidence exists for strengthening health systems and their existing care platforms to address this burden or for prevention strategies that can be deployed in community settings. This project leverages data from ongoing R01, UG3/UH3, and intramural grants to conduct formative research into implementation determinants for integrating type II diabetes care into HIV and hypertension care cascades, and to explore whether community-based nutritional education can improve diet, a well-established contributor to cardiometabolic disease risk. This research will inform efforts to strengthen cardiometabolic care by building on successes and existing assets within the health system, such those for HIV care, as well as community-based interventions for preventing cardiometabolic disease, while providing opportunities for the F31 candidate to gain expertise in new methods and advance as an independent investigator.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  Recent insights into the pathogenesis of Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) suggest therapies which manipulate the plasticity of neural circuits will be central to the next-generation of treatments to slow and/or reverse its progression. Toward this end, Outlier Technology proposes the development of a novel, Neurologic Music Therapy (NMT) platform that offers evidence-based interventions to stimulate neuroplasticity, mitigate cognitive decline, and prolong functional independence in individuals suffering from AD. This proposal describes the development of a gesture-powered “smart instrument” that combines an interactive, therapeutic, personalized music creation experience with structured data analytics and a curriculum of NMT games/puzzles that adapt to the users’ sensitive needs and musical tastes; allowing them to “play” their way to better health.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this application for “Modern Equipment for Shared-use Biomedical Research Facilities”, the Genomics Research and Technology Hub, the shared genomics resource for the University of California, Irvine, proposes acquisition of the Hamilton LiquidScan NGS STAR robotic system, which is readily programmable for next generation sequencing workflows to enable automation of multiple steps in genomics sample processing for various genomic, transcriptomic and multiomic sequencing, and beadarray experiments. Increased automation will further support recent increases in throughput for long- and short-read sequencing platforms, and the new LiquidScan feature enables translational development of biomarker assays from biological fluids. This modernization of infrastructure will leverage our trained personnel, provide relief from physically repetitive tasks, and improve accuracy and precision within the workflow.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The Nav1.5 subunits of FGF12A, FGF12B, and calmodulin have been shown to individually modulate the cardiac sodium current. This proposal looks to determine the combined effects on these subunits have on Nav1.5 and class 1b anti-arrhythmic drug interactions with Nav1.5. The results from the proposed studies will clarify potential differences in the treatments of pro-arrhythmic patients and will develop methods to characterize similar auxiliary subunits on voltage gated ion channels.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE For the first time a heparan sulfate proteoglycan, SDC-1, has emerged as a regulator of hepcidin and iron metabolism. By evaluating the mechanism by which SDC-1 modulates hepcidin expression and the significance of other hepatic heparan sulfate proteoglycans in relation to hepcidin, new targets for pharmaceutical therapies intended for hepcidin-dysregulated diseases, like anemia of inflammation, will be identified.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The purpose of this mixed methodological study is to conduct a community needs assessment including an evaluation of epidemiological, social, and contextual factors related to overweight and obesity in adolescents (e.g., using population estimates and geospatial mapping) and qualitative data collection methods to gather stakeholder perspectives in a two-part process of 1) obtaining input from stakeholders in the community about barriers and facilitators to existing evidenced-based programs as well as locally developed programs and community resources and 2) reviewing core components of existing scientific evidence to determine fit with community needs and priorities. This project will make a significant and novel public health impact by creating an academic-community partnership (i.e., Young Voices Panel) that will synthesize and integrate current scientific evidence and community input into a prototype of a lifestyle modification intervention for adolescents in Greater Providence, an urban area with substantial racial/ethnic diversity57.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative During the early phase of cancer metastasis to the lung, monocytes are recruited to the lung and differentiate into metastasis-associated macrophages (MAMs). Both monocytes and their progeny MAMs are known to play tumor-supporting roles and exacerbate metastasis in the lung. The goals of this proposal are to identify the signals and factors that influence monocyte differentiation and to define the function of monocytes during their transition into MAMs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pulmonary hypertension (PH) related to connective tissue disease-related interstitial lung disease (CTD-ILD) is an understudied and challenging clinical entity with high morbidity and mortality. PH in CTD-ILD may arise through two different mechanisms and manifest as either a parenchymal or vascular phenotype. In this proposed study, I will compare the disease severity and response to treatment of the parenchymal and vascular pheno- types of PH in patients with CTD-ILD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), the third leading cause of mortality worldwide, comorbid diseases and exercise capacity are known independent predictors of morbidity and mortality. While iron level is an important determinant of exercise capacity and plays a vital role in various biologic processes in the lungs, the association between iron deficiency and COPD morbidity is not well known. This proposal seeks to determine whether iron deficiency, a prevalent and treatable condition, is associated with worse COPD morbidity, specifically hospitalization and functional outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Emerging findings show complex functions of p38 MAPK in development and aging. We are working to understand how these p38 MAPK functions work in a non-cell autonomous manner to promote lysosome regeneration during aging. The role of stress-responsive pathways supporting homeostatic physiological functions provides an opportunity to reveal key mechanisms underlying integrity of tissues during aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Early-onset CRC, which is especially prevalent among under-served individuals, is difficult to diagnose because routine screening tests are not recommended until age 45 and, even when younger patients report red-flag symptoms for CRC, the symptoms can be misattributed to benign causes and not followed up with CRC testing. No previous study has assessed follow-up with early onset CRC testing for patients reporting red-flag symptoms in a safety-net healthcare system. Our proposed work will expand data from a large NIH- funded safety-net cohort to study CRC test order, testing and cancer diagnoses among patients aged 18-49 who report a red-flag symptom, with the goal of better understanding healthcare delivery for this vulnerable group.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Plasmodium vivax is a major obstacle to malaria control and elimination due to its ability to form persistent liver stage forms known as hypnozoites. New therapies to eliminate hypnozoites are needed because these forms are responsible for up to 85% of P. vivax infections, and current therapies cannot be widely administered due to contraindications in large portions of at-risk populations. This project will address this public health problem by determining when and how P. vivax commits to dormancy, which is needed to develop new approaches to eliminate hypnozoites.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project narrative Despite the success of chimeric antigen receptor T (CAR T) cell therapies in treating lymphomas, it remains challenging to target solid tumors safely and effectively without impacting healthy tissues. However, targeting CAR T cells to metabolites that are enriched or depleted in the TME, in addition to tumor cell surface antigens, may improve the efficacy of this approach for solid tumors. In this project, we target combinations of tumor- specific antigens and TME metabolites by engineering modular CARs that link the extracellular detection of these ligands with the activation of T cell signaling pathways for tumor destruction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mucormycosis incidence is on the rise, with the overall mortality rate of over 50%, and disseminated disease being nearly universally fatal, as currently available treatments are limited. Our goal is to elucidate the evolutionary history of symbiotic associations between the Mucoromycotina fungi and the endosymbiotic bacteria often found in clinical isolates, focusing on population-level processes, including fungal adaptation to mammalian hosts and contributions of 6-methyladenine (6mA) DNA epigenetic modifications shared by Mucoromycotina and bacteria as means of communication between the partners. Findings of this project will inform new mycosis therapies relying on inhibition of 6mA DNA methylation in both partners.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Glioblastoma (GBM) is the most devastating primary brain tumor in adults, characterized by enhanced invasion and proliferation and therapy resistance. This project will evaluate the role and therapeutic implications of the SPAK and OSR1 kinases in GBM. Our long-term goal is to develop a research program focused on identifying druggable signaling pathways that regulate GBM cell invasion and proliferation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: This project seeks to enhance the value of the AphasiaBank database and tools for the study of spoken language and communication as used by people with aphasia. We will do this through the introduction of innovative methods for automatic speech recognition, discourse analysis, gesture analysis, corpus analysis, and a new system called collaborative commentary. We will apply these new methods to the analysis of the current database, as well as many new corpora. We will configure these new methods for widespread use by both researchers and clinicians.

PROJECT_TITLE: AphasiaBank: A Shared Database for the Study of Aphasic Communication

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women experience greater nicotine use vulnerability in addition to higher rates of cancer, heart attacks, and mortality from smoking; hormonal contraceptives heighten this nicotine use vulnerability in addition to exacerbating women’s already greater risk for adverse smoking related health consequences. In turn, massive gains would result from a better understanding of mechanisms that underly this enhanced nicotine use vulnerability and its augmentation by hormonal contraceptives. The long-term objective of this research program is to provide a behavioral mechanistic understanding of how synthetic hormones contained in contraceptives influence nicotine intake, ultimately providing the preclinical basis for which researchers and practitioners can develop better cessation treatments and reduce health disparities caused by enhanced nicotine use vulnerability and comorbid contraceptive use in women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Being able to map specific cell types affiliated with vulnerable brain regions and their network connections would be a critical advancement in our ability to predict age-related processes that lead to irreversible damage. We will develop a unique multi-scale reference dataset and network-based analysis strategy to investigate macroscale network architecture and cell-type specific microstructure in the macaque monkey. The macaque is uniquely positioned to provide a mechanistic understanding of processes related to age-related decline using both translational in vivo MRI and invasive histology markers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: NARRATIVE Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) is a ubiquitous human pathogen that can cause significant morbidity and mortality in humans and has been implicated in neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer’s disease and multiple sclerosis. Here we propose to investigate the molecular mechanism of the antiviral response by the human stress response protein PML. We will focus on PML’s sumoylation activity and its ability to target and silence viral genes during the early stages of infection to provide a detailed understanding of the key events in the formation of anti- viral PML nuclear bodies which is currently missing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The protist pathogen Cryptosporidium is a water-borne pathogen that infects immune competent and immunocompromised humans and animals in all countries but is a major cause of diarrhea in infants under a year of age in developing countries. We have discovered polycistronic transcription in C. parvum. This is surprising, as it is not common in eukaryotes and has never been reported in the Apicomplexa. The proposed work seeks to validate these transcripts and begin studies of how they contribute to gene regulation in this important pathogen.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project is relevant to the public because sarcoidosis is a common interstitial lung disease of unknown cause that often causes chronic disability and, in some cases, premature death, and for which effective and affordable treatments are not currently available. The successful completion of this project will provide novel insights into the pathogenesis of sarcoidosis to inform the development of more effective treatments, including repurposing existing therapeutic agents. Thus, the proposed research and future scientific and clinical implications are relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission that pertains to developing fundamental knowledge that will reduce the burdens of illness and disability, and is responsive to the NHLBI strategic vision as relates to understanding human biology, reducing human disease, and advancing translational research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT – PROJECT NARRATIVE Metastatic triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) patients have poor clinical outcomes, in part, because there are no targeted therapies approved to treat this aggressive breast cancer subtype. By elucidating new post-translational mechanisms of eIF5A1/2-dependent TGFβ/fibronectin-induced heterogeneity and metastasis within primary and premetastatic niches, the proposed studies have the potential to identify new therapeutic strategies for abrogating TNBC progression. Additionally, this work has broad applicability across the field of oncology as many of the molecular regulators being investigated in this proposal have been reported to be altered or dysregulated in other solid tumor types where cancer metastasis is a primary cause of patient mortality.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research will test the efficacy of enrichment interventions focused on parent-infant interactions via singing, music-listening, and book-reading, for improving parent and infant health. Primary outcomes of interest include improvements to infant and parent mood, infant sleep quality, infant ability to recover from distress, and parent well-being. The interventions are low-cost and low-effort for parents, so may have outsized impacts, especially in underprivileged families and first-time parents.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Cervical insufficiency or incompetence (CI) describes the inability of the uterine cervix to retain a pregnancy in the absence of the signs and symptoms of clinical contractions, or labor, or both in the second trimester. Currently, there are no objective tests to evaluate cervical tissue strength as a means to confirm a diagnosis of CI and the diagnosis of CI cannot be made or excluded outside of pregnancy by any test. The objective of this study is to determine if the blood perfusion and/or microvascular pressure around the internal os of the uterine cervix can distinguish patients with a history of CI (presumably “weak” cervix) from normal controls in a non-pregnant state.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Herpes simplex viruses cause cold sores and sexually transmitted infections, and can also cause the more serious complications of neonatal infections, blindness, and fatal encephalitis. The purpose of this research is to determine how the herpesvirus initiates infection in humans by studying the entry of virus into host cells. Greater understanding of the virus entry processes will help to identify novel approaches to prevent herpes infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (cSCC) is a highly-prevalent form of skin cancer that causes an estimated 15,000 deaths with 1.8M new diagnoses each year in the United States alone. This high prevalence and mortality risk creates a tremendous need for effective treatment selection strategies, so that patients at risk for poor outcomes can benefit from more aggressive treatments while low-risk patients can be spared the corresponding side effects and costs. We propose to develop artificial intelligence algorithms to help stratify cSCC patients into low risk or high risk based on the histopathology images from their biopsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on interactions between two commonly co-occurring gastrointestinal bacteria pathogens, both of which are classified in the top antibiotic resistance threat levels in the United States by the Centers for Disease Control. Understanding how these two bacteria interact will be critical to developing therapeutics which do not inadvertently benefit one species. The proposed research is relevant to the part of NIAID’s mission devoted to understanding how antibiotic-resistant microbes cause disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Drug repurposing has emerged as an important therapeutic strategy in the context of rare genetic diseases. Due to the mostly inhibitory nature of existing drug molecules, they are most effective on genetic variants that are likely to increase a protein's function, but the identification of such variants remains an open challenge. The objective of the proposed research is to apply variant impact prediction methods and other computational approaches, on publicly available Common Fund data sets to: (1) identify disease-associated variants that increase the propensity for specific biochemical functions in proteins, and (2) identify candidate drug molecules that directly or indirectly inhibit these functions.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal hypothesizes that chronic hypoxia leads to metabolic and epigenetic disruption in the developing brain, which contributes to long-term functional dysfunction. Using advanced imaging and multi-omic studies, we propose two aims: to test if there is a correlation between placental metabolic dysfunction and brain metabolic dysfunction from chronic hypoxia and if cortical metabolic dysfunction from chronic hypoxia correlates with transcriptomic and epigenetic disruption in the developing cortex. The findings from this study could provide a framework for understanding the complex multi-system dynamics that impact the effect of prenatal insults on neurodevelopment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH STATEMENT  Chronic alcohol drinking is associated with development of alcohol dependence, but the specific molecular mechanisms by which alcohol-induced brain changes lead to alcohol use disorder have yet to be fully elucidated. We propose to develop a rodent preclinical model with which to advance our understanding of the molecular and cellular changes associated with alcohol exposure and test the feasibility of biomarker development for early detection of alcohol-induced neuropathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on investigating differences in immune mechanisms of myocarditis development between pediatric and adult populations. Myocarditis caused by viral infections is a leading cause of sudden death in children and young adults, but it is understudied, especially in children. There is a critical need to understand better the mechanisms of myocarditis in order to improve diagnosis and prevent progression to chronic heart failure and death; thus, this project is related to the NIH mission of lengthening life and reducing illness, especially in vulnerable populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Motor function is often compromised as part of the normal healthy aging process or due to acute neurological insult, such as stroke and spinal cord injury. This project is expected to demonstrate that when the sensory afferent vagus nerve is stimulated noninvasively during motor training, motor skill improvement is enhanced in healthy older adults. The expected findings will be the foundation for opening new research directions, tool development, and applications to rehabilitation for various populations with movement disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Impaired ability to respond to the earth’s gravitational field results in falls with adverse consequences to health, quality of life, and health care costs. This risk of falling is a particularly major issue for elderly individuals and those with neurodegenerative diseases. To understand the mechanism of gravity sensing at the molecular and neural circuit level and thus set the stage for the development of novel therapeutics to reduce falls, we propose using the simple yet experimentally powerful microscopic nematode Caenorhabditis elegans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to examine multi-directional tuning of head orientation in navigating rats. This project will determine how the brain learns and encodes transitions between headings within a complex network of pathways. The findings will be relevant to understanding of learning and memory processes in the hippocampal and subicular systems and in neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE  The present study explores the role of long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) in the ovulatory process. We have discovered a number of lncRNA transcripts that were highly regulated by hCG (LH-analog) prior to ovulation in mice, however, nothing is known about their function in the ovulatory process. Hence, the proposed studies will investigate the role of the most highly LH/hCG-regulated ovarian lncRNAs associated with the processes of follicular rupture and oocyte release, which will aid in the understanding of the regulation of human fertility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We will investigate whether expression data from serum-derived extracellular vesicles can be used to predict the in vivo pharmacokinetics of the CYP3A4/5 substrate tacrolimus. Using a multi- pronged strategy, we will integrate pharmacokinetics, liquid biopsy technology, genotyping, and activity data to propose individualized doses, based on the individual expression of hepatic and gut enzymes. Data will be integrated into model-informed Bayesian estimation tool to guide individual tacrolimus dosing in post-liver transplant patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative This study will evaluate the impact of the OpenNotes policy on clinical documentation in two specialties: mental health and primary care in the United States using a computational analysis with natural language processing (NLP) tools. We will identify shifts in the medical record language pre and post the policy implementation with a focus on aspects related to the accessibility and readability of the note, how specific it is, any changes in the provider socio- emotional tone, and how sensitive topics and stigmatizing language shifted. Furthermore, we will study the impact of OpenNotes on health disparities and the use of stigmatizing language and how these aspects can lessen or inase the gap of disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: NARRATIVE Chlamydia trachomatis sexually transmitted infection poses critical threats to women’s reproductive health. Our proposed study aims to characterize the early immune responses to Chlamydia infection in the female reproductive tract, and identify major cellular components and their effector functions essential for protective immunity and development of immunopathology. These studies are important for fundamental understanding of host innate immunity to Chlamydia, and will aid the design of a protective Chlamydia vaccine.
