IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Phospholipase C (PLC) enzymes increase cytoplasmic calcium levels in response to diverse hormonal signals, but how they are regulated and how they interact with biological membranes where their substrate is located remains poorly understood. In this proposal, we will use single molecule studies, cryo-electron microscopy, and cell-based functional studies to investigate how heterotrimeric G proteins and the membrane coregulate PLCb. This work is expected to reveal novel regulatory features that could be exploited to develop new strategies for the treatment of cardiovascular disease, cancer, and opioid addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to study the transcriptional control of the innate-like natural killer T cells (NKT cells). We will examine how the transcription factor, PLZF, which controls the functions of these cells is regulated by a co-factor protein. In this application, we will combine sophisticated cellular, molecular and biochemical approaches that will give insight into how these cells are controlled and how they contribute to a wide range of immune responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Evidence from this project will elucidate how experiencing housing instability over one’s lifetime can lead to worse health and disease later in life. Knowledge of how the negative consequences of housing instability for cognitive functioning, psychological distress, self-rated health, and functional limitations contribute to persistent racial/ethnic health disparities at older ages stresses to policymakers and health professionals the need for bridging housing policy with public health to meet the basic needs of disadvantaged, underserved individuals and communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Hidradenitis suppurativa (HS) is chronic inflammatory skin disease characterized by painful lesions in areas of skin folds and affects approximately 1% of the population, predominantly women and African Americans. A better understanding of HS pathogenesis is needed to develop novel treatment strategies that will improve quality of life in those living with this devastating disease. Here we will study the role of antibodies in the disease pathogenesis so that knowledge gained from these studies could be used identify novel therapeutic strategies to reduce pain and suffering.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Project Narrative The current proposal asks how a specific aspect of infant’s experiences - speech from young children – shapes language development, using both in-lab tasks, naturalistic play sessions, and longitudinal assessments of vocabulary development. Using naturalistic observational data alongside experimental methods, the proposed research provides critical new insights into how speech from young children is attended to and processed by infants, and whether that speech differs systematically in content relative to speech produced by adult caregivers. The results of this multi-method approach will allow for a better understanding of why infants with older siblings have been found to have slower language development, which can readily be applied to educational or clinical settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study has the potential for significant public health impact due to the prevalence among older adults of balance and walking deficits, increased fatal and nonfatal falls, and impaired spinal cord neuronal structure and function that may affect spinal control of balance and walking. Transcutaneous spinal direct current stimulation (tsDCS) is one of the few available approaches for safe and feasible intervention of spinal circuitry that may improve spinal excitability and enhance practice-based rehabilitation of balance and walking. Successful completion of this study will provide an empirical basis for designing a novel tsDCS intervention in combination with balance exergaming, an approach that is feasible for translation into home- or community-based rehabilitation programs as a practical, cost-effective, and safe method for helping to preserve balance, walking, and independence among older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Overweight/obesity in children remains a leading public health concern and parents often gravitate towards using food parenting practices high in coercive control to manage their child’s obesity risk; however, these strategies are often counterproductive and lead to undesired eating and weight outcomes. Cross-sectionally, positive food parenting practices are associated with healthy child eating and weight outcomes, but less is known on whether we can successfully intervene to increase use of positive food parenting practices to help support healthy growth and diet quality in children at risk for obesity. The proposed study aims to examine the feasibility and acceptability of a positive food parenting intervention designed to prevent obesity and improve diet quality in children at risk for obesity.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This interdisciplinary project aims to unravel the mechanisms of protective mucosal innate immunity activated during respiratory virus infections. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study seeks to develop two instruments used to measure sexual and gender minority (SGM) help-seeking barriers and recovery needs after experiencing gender-based violence (GBV). The proposed research is relevant to public health because unaddressed GBV victimization represents a key driver of SGM health disparities (e.g., suicidality, substance use, depression, HIV transmission) and understanding help-seeking barriers and recovery needs can help improve care linkages and identify additional areas for intervention and survivor support. This project is relevant to NIH's mission because it focuses on improving health for marginalized populations through identifying barriers to GBV treatment access, engagement, and effectiveness, with the goal to inform acceptable interventions to reduce health disparities and improve health outcomes for SGM populations.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: This proposal aims to advance the understanding of gene regulatory networks in genomics by developing deep learning models that integrate spatial transcriptomics data. Two aims include developing methods for cell-type specific network estimation that transition between scRNA-seq and spatial transcriptomics, and creating models with spatial regularization to uncover networks at a spatial resolution. These efforts are expected to revolutionize our understanding of cellular functions and tissue organization by incorporating the nuances of individual cells and their spatial context.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Understanding cellular responses to harmful alterations in the in utero environment is critical for the development of therapies which prevent congenital defects. We will exploit in vitro differentiations of kidney organoids and the openly manipulatable environment to interrogate how the pregestational diabetic milieu alters developmental programs, providing novel insights into how disruptions to normal development result in physiological consequences. Our studies will extend the current utility of kidney organoids and open up prospects for the development of interventional strategies that prevent kidney congenital defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Based on extensive human brain injury data research (athletes, soldiers, and non-sport related brain impacts), we hypothesized that injury-induced cell-specific dysregulation in mitochondria bioenergetic and metabolic functions transforms them into neurodegenerative factories that control the onset of acute neuroinflammation and neuronal damage and the widespread long-AD- like pathology. We will use novel genetically engineered brain cells with fluorescent mitochondria to determine cell-specific injury-induced alterations in mitochondria function and potential molecular mechanisms responsible for AD-like degeneration spread through dysfunctional mitochondrial uptake by neighboring cells over time. The outcome of this project will provide 1) a chronologic understanding of cell-specific mitochondria alterations in acute and chronic phases of brain injury progression, 2) potential molecular mechanisms that drive mitochondria alterations and further neurodegeneration progression, 3) a causal understanding of the cell-specific contribution to mitochondrial dysfunction-driven AD-like neurodegeneration progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our project aims to develop child-tailored quantitative imaging tools for assessing treatment effects in children with cancer while ensuring the lowest possible radiation exposure. We are testing novel diffusion-weighted magnetic resonance imaging and positron emission tomography technologies for therapy response assessment of pediatric cancers. We anticipate that child-tailored imaging tests will introduce a new, safer, more efficient, and more accurate generation of imaging exams for children that can be widely applied to interrogate health and disease without the risk of radiation-induced secondary cancers later in life.

PHR: Project Narrative (max: 3 sentences) Spinal cord injury (SCI) can result in permanent loss of mobility or sensation below the injury. There are approximately 300,000 Americans living with SCI and 18,000 new cases every year. This proposal uses new genetic technologies and a mouse model of SCI to efficiently compare many candidate combination therapies that could potentially enhance the regeneration of injured neurons and improve functional recovery after SCI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE Human and animal studies of schizophrenia implicate aberrant hippocampal network oscillations as a result of alterations to N-methyl-D-aspartate receptor (NMDAR) GluN2B subunits at excitatory synapses, however, GluN2 subunits regulate NMDAR ionotropic and direct intracellular signaling at excitatory synapses and the independent roles of these different signaling mechanisms have not been investigated with respect to schizophrenia. This pioneering proposal will extend investigation into the neural underpinnings of schizophrenia to the neurotransmitter receptor subunit domain level by exploring of the contributions of distinct GluN2B signaling domains to hippocampal network dynamics and spatial memory. Outcomes will fill important knowledge gaps in what is known of the molecular and physiological bases of schizophrenia, which will revise our understanding of this devastaing disease and enable the creation of novel treatments and potential cures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Natural IgM antibodies are part of the immediate early defense from infections, but their presence also reduces the incidence of autoimmune disease. This grant proposal aims to identify novel genes that regulate the development and/or maintenance of the cells generating these antibodies. Gaining this knowledge is critical for harnessing the potential broad protective powers of this antibody through development of vaccines and/or therapeutics. It may also identify new pathways that can control autoreactive B cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: || Project Narrative Restoring blood flow to the heart by surgery can be complicated by cells in the blood vessel wall dividing continuously after the surgery, eventually blocking blood flow again. We know that many therapy targets used to stop cells from dividing are found inside the cells, making them difficult to target. Our research aims to define a new type of therapy based on very small antibodies, show that we can make these go inside the cells, and demonstrate that this stops cells from dividing in the blood vessel.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative  This project will examine the impact of sexual minority stress and post-traumatic stress disorder symptoms on alcohol use using an innovative ecological momentary assessment design. The proposed investigation will carry implications for the reduction of alcohol use, including heavy episodic drinking, by providing information on critical risk factors among bi+ college students. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the prevention and treatment of alcohol use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Tuberculosis (TB), caused by the intracellular pathogen Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb), infects one-fourth of the world’s population. Majority of the infected individuals are latently infected (LTBI), of which 5-10% stand a risk of progressing to active TB disease (ATB) during their lifetime. Work proposed here will delineate the cellular mechanisms of protective pathways that mediate Mtb control and TB reactivation aiding in the development of new therapeutics for TB disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Biomarkers that reliably inform the selection of therapy or prognosis for patients with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) are lacking. Emerging data suggest that analysis of the profiles of small (30-150 nm) extracellular vesicles (sEV), also known as exosomes, in body fluids is a promising approach to the detection of non-invasive biomarkers in cancer, including HNSCC. This project will simultaneously assess the utility of sEV produced by tumor cells (TEX) and sEV produced by non-malignant cells (NTEX) in HNSCC patients’ plasma as biomarkers of prognosis and/or response to therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Peak lung function is achieved in early adulthood, progressively declines with age, and significantly impacts quality of life. This research will study the effects of normal aging on the ability of lung stretch to increase airway caliber and maximize ventilatory capacity in elderly adults. The findings will generate novel insight into the physiological mechanisms of reduced lung function in the elderly and will have important implications for the clinical interpretation of changes in pulmonary function across the aging spectrum.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (RELEVANCE) Mutations in GBA1, which encode for the protein glucocerebrosidase (GCase), are the most common genetic risk factor for Parkinson’s disease (PD) and dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB) and emerging evidence suggests that the loss of GCase activity is involved in the onset of these diseases. Despite there is significant interest in developing GCase-targeted therapies for the treatment of these diseases, a lack of methodology for measuring GCase activity in disease-modeling systems hinders progress in developing GCase therapies. The successful completion of our high throughput screening will provide unique drug candidates for these diseases and will provide a new drug screening platform for GBA1-associated PD/DLB and sporadic PD/DLB patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Dendritic cells (DCs) play a critical role in the innate and adaptive immune responses to blood-borne antigens and regulate T cell immunity versus tolerance. Patients with factor VIII (FVIII) and IX (FIX) deficiencies are at risk of developing inhibitory antibodies to factor replacement, however it is unclear whether DCs mediate the differences in FVIII and FIX immunogenicity. The main objectives of this work are to characterize the role of DCs in the innate immune response to FVIII and FIX and to evaluate the impact of factor-DC interactions on adaptive immune responses in hemophilia A and B, respectively.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The very low birth weight (VLBW) preterm infant, born at 24-32 weeks gestation, is at a critical stage of structural and functional auditory development in a suboptimal environment, and with limited access to speech. By harnessing the existing cohort of VLBW preterm infants, and recruiting age-matched full-term infants, the researchers aim to identify predictors of language growth, including gestational age, health and demographic factors, and initial (0-18 months) language development trajectories, influenced by parent-infant communication patterns, across a period of rapid language emergence typically observed in the second and third years of life. Results from the proposed project will advance our understanding of factors that impact risk and resilience for language growth over time and will provide an evidence base for meaningful clinical and family-based interventions to improve language outcomes, and thus public health, in this at- risk population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICIs) are less effective at reducing tumor burden in bone metastatic patients and coincide with musculoskeletal toxicities including bone loss and fractures. Interactions between the tumor, bone, and immune microenvironments that might be contributing to this clinical observation are not well understood. This proposal investigates the novel concept that ICIs suppress bone formation and enhance bone resorption, increasing patient fracture risk, and therefore have the potential to transform clinical care and outcomes for patients receiving ICIs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: This F99/K00 proposal focuses on engineering innovative computational tools that integrate multiscale multimodal cancer patient data for the development of prognostic and predictive markers of clinical outcomes. Comprehensive deep learning frameworks combining genomics, pathology, radiology, and clinical patient data can capture intricate cross-scale associations, enabling identification of reliable markers for determining a treatment’s likelihood of success. Such markers could facilitate the selection of optimal treatment regimes, leading to improved long-term outcomes and a transformative impact on cancer management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: Narratives Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is a leading cause of blindness at ages > 50. The objective of this project is to establish a novel mouse model that integrates multiple environmental and genetic factors suspected to contribute to AMD in human patients. The availability of such a model may greatly enhance our knowledge of AMD pathology and facilitate the development of novel AMD therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the unprecedented success of immune checkpoint blockade therapies that tremendously improved patient survival in certain types of cancer, such as melanoma and non-small cell lung cancer, it has been recognized that the response rate to current immunotherapies is still below 30% in most cancer types. In this proposal, we aim to (1) functionally and therapeutically interrogate tumoral secreted-protein-mediated T-cell exclusion from the tumor microenvironment to turn “cold” tumors “hot”, and (2) identify additional tumor microenvironment-specific molecules that impair the maintenance of T-cell quantity and effector functions in inflamed tumors to maximize the durability of anti-tumor immunity. Collectively, the proposed research will address the urgent need in therapeutic innovations for patients with primary and acquired resistance to current immunotherapies, and provide most patients personalized therapeutic strategies tailored to their pathological classifications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: OTHER PROJECT INFORMATION – Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it addresses the intersection of two public health crises in the U.S., notably by assessing the extent to which the opioid crisis has contributed to elevated levels of intimate partner violence (IPV). Given the severe adverse consequences of IPV for the physical and mental health of victims and children, understanding whether supply-side policies implemented in response to the opioid crisis have had spillover effects on the risk of IPV perpetration and victimization is critical for evaluating the full societal costs and benefits of these policies, and for identifying sub-populations at heightened risk of IPV exposure. This project will evaluate for the first time the effects of policy-induced changes in opioid use on the risk of IPV perpetration/victimization, and in the process inform a key public health concern relevant to the NIH's mission at the intersection of the opioid epidemic and its impact on violence towards women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Chronic subdural hematoma (CSDH) is one of the most common types of intracranial hemorrhage and has seen recent sharp increases in incidence in the aging population. Although the hematoma resolves in many patients, in others the brain does not reexapand to fill the space after treatment. In this project, we explore the measurement of brain mechanical properties, noninvasively with MRI, to predict patients who will demonstrate reexpansion of the brain after treatment for CSDH.

PHR: Project Narrative Parenterally administered, molecularly targeted radiotheranostics offers delivery of lethal doses of cytotoxic radiation to cancerous lesions and makes precision medicine possible in oncology. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Epilepsy afflicts 1% of the population and is characterized by spontaneous seizures. About 30% of patients do not respond to current therapies. Thus a deeper understanding of the mechanisms that drive the disease are required. We have constructed a machine learning algorithm that can predict when a rat brain is about to enter a zone of high seizure risk. By analyzing rat brains as they transition from epochs of low seizure risk to high risk, we will uncover the molecular, cellular and network changes that push brains to the edge of a seizure. We will perform single cell sequencing and cellular recordings from brains that are in low and high seizure risk states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative: Toxoplasma gondii causes severe opportunistic infection, mostly in unborn children and HIV/AIDS patients. The parasite employs an unique cell-division machinery that supports a fast and cell-lytic proliferation, which is responsible for tissue lesions followed by inflammation in e.g. the eye (Ocular Toxoplasmosis), the brain (causing Encephalitis) or the heart (causing myocarditis). Our research focuses on the parasite’s specialist cytoskeleton and seeks to better understand how parasite offspring is assembled, hereby highlighting potential new avenues for drug discovery in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Proposal Narrative  The proposed study is to establish an in vitro model of the human yolk sac, which is a vital extra- embryonic organ to support embryo development during early pregnancy. The goal is to use such an in vitro model, or yolk sac organoid, to identify environmental factors that harm embryo development. Effective and swift identification of reproductively harmful factors is crucial to ensure healthy pregnancies.

PHR: Project Narrative Center for Disease Control data indicate that ~20% of adolescents and young adult women are prescribed oral contraceptives (OCs), yet our understanding of how synthetic hormones contained in OCs may impact the neurobiological landscape is markedly limited. We propose to measure neuron-derived exosome microRNA expression profiles in adolescent/young adult females (ages 15-22) prescribed oral contraceptives (OC) compared to natural cycling, OC naïve adolescent females. Study outcomes will elucidate the influence of exogenous hormones on brain development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current therapies for the major human demyelinating disease multiple sclerosis (MS) target its inflammatory component, and they are effective in modifying the disease course and in managing symptoms; however, they are not curative. Stimulation of central nervous system (CNS) resident myelinating cells, namely oligodendrocytes (OLGs), is seen as an important step toward a curative treatment. As an attempt toward the characterization of novel molecular mechanisms with the potential to modulate myelin repair, the present application seeks to explore a novel role of the glutamate transporter GLT-1 (EAAC2/SLC1A2) in promoting CNS remyelination via glutamate influx mediated intracellular responses in maturing OLGs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK STATE PSYCHIATRIC INSTITUTE DBA RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR MENTAL HYGIENE, INC
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mutations in GRIN2B, which encodes the GluN2B subunit of NMDA receptors, confer risk of ASD, but the underlying mechanisms remain unclear. We found that increased or decreased expression of the neuronal glutamate transporter, which modulates NMDA-GluN2B function, reciprocally impacts dopaminergic neuron function – a key neurotransmitter system associated with ASD – and downstream behavior. Here, we propose to determine the impact of diminished NMDA-GluN2B expression in dopaminergic neurons on dopaminergic neuron firing, release, and resulting behavior, with the goal of elucidating impact of Grin2b in dopaminergic circuits, and potentially informing precision-medicine interventions with NMDA-GluN2B compounds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Current referrals to newer antidepressant therapies (e.g. transcranial-magnetic stimulation (TMS)) are targeted for patients with treatment resistant depression (TRD), but TRD can only be established through multiple first- line treatment failures for the individual patient. The current study proposes to identify patients prone to treatment resistance by documenting monotherapy treatment failure (TF) across multiple first-line treatments, with the ultimate goal of referring to alternative therapies earlier in the treatment course. The focus of the study is to determine if initial TF is a reasonable proxy for subsequent treatment failure and thus treatment resistance in both the clinical trial and observational settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Schizophrenia is the 8th leading cause of disability world-wide and is associated with impaired decision-making related to difficulty processing information about choices that lead to potentially rewarding outcomes relative to potentially detrimental outcomes. The project leverages neuroimaging, eye-tracking, and daily experience monitoring to identify how attentional biases and the application of cognitive strategies impact decisions, and how activity in coordinated brain regions during evidence integration relate to real-world decision-making problems in people with schizophrenia. The results will guide interventions to empower those with schizophrenia to improve their decision-making capacity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recently, malaria incidence has considerably reduced because of the significant efforts in malaria control and elimination and many lives have been saved. But independent emergence of drug resistance and most importantly to the frontline treatment regimen, artemisinin combination therapy has threatened this progress. We propose that K13 independent artemisinin resistance is emerging in Bangladesh; that K13 independent resistance will serve as a catalyst for highly resistant and fit K13 mutations to arise and spread in this population. We will use genomics, phenotyping, reverse genetics to identify these early genetic determinants and evaluate the propensity of K13 mutations to emerge and circulate in this population, to offer improved tools to inform malaria treatment and control spread of drug resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative The aging global population is facing an increased risk of cognitive decline, often characterized by familiarity bias and memory interference. Our research focuses on identifying the neural circuits behind memory interference to understand these deficits. We aim to explore how age- related deterioration in the dopaminergic innervation of the lateral entorhinal cortex contributes to memory interference.

PHR: Project Narrative Clinicians in emergency departments experience persistent burnout and psychological distress. This research would help to understand how factors (in the department, the pandemic, and personal characteristics) contribute to their experience and provide a visualization tool to communicate current status to hospital leadership. This work would support decisions to improve clinician well-being and corresponding improvements in patient care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Burnout among clinicians is a significant concern in Emergency Departments across the US and globally, and with increasing workload, additional shift work requirements, staffing shortages, and other stress-inducing activities, clinician well-being can be significantly compromised. This has ramifications on patient flow and quality of care, including increased handoffs, increased miscommunications, and reduced time for patient/clinician interaction. The purpose of this proposal is to create a framework for redesigning ED nurse and physician shift schedules, integrating clinician preferences and physiological parameters to improve clinician well-being and patient outcomes.

PROJECT_TITLE: Redesigning Emergency Department Clinician Shift Scheduling to Improve Well-being and Patient Outcomes (EDSHIFT)

PHR: NARRATIVE: This proposal deals with large barriers in bacteriophage discovery. We will separate mixtures of bacteriophages using electrophoresis. We will determine the physico- chemical basis of fractionation. The technology developed here has obvious implications in antimicrobial development and as a census of phage genes for molecular exploitation. Thisproposal is in line with NIH mission statement to seek fundamental knowledge of the nature of living systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The correlates of pathogenicity for filoviruses, including the highly fatal WHO priority pathogens Ebola and Marburg viruses, remain poorly understood. Inteins, or intervening proteins, can make and break peptide bonds in a controllable and specific manner, which has led to numerous impactful tools in protein engineering. The overall goals of this application are to develop novel intein-based technologies to better understand the expression and function of individual Ebola virus proteins during infection and disease progression.

PHR: Infections due to Acinetobacter baumannii are increasing in frequency and have become exceeding difficult to treat with antibiotics. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Endoplasmic reticulum (ER)-associated degradation (ERAD) is the principal ER quality control machinery responsible for the clearance of misfolded ER proteins for cytosolic proteasomal degradation. Recent studies from our laboratory have revealed the significance of ERAD in the maturation of nephrin within the ER of podocytes; however, the underlying molecular mechanism and significance of ERAD in podocytes remain largely unclear. This study will test an exciting hypothesis that SEL1L-HRD1 ERAD protein complex plays a critical role in maintaining ER homeostasis in podocytes by coordinating autophagy activation.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed technology will help surgeons to treat young patients who have difficulty breathing due to narrowed airways, a potentially life-threatening condition. Currently, surgeons perform either a very complicated surgery, or they open the front of the trachea with an incision and use rib cartilage to hold the trachea open. The technology is an off-the-shelf trachea patch that will replace the need to harvest rib cartilage, allowing the patient to breathe normally without the need to harvest cartilage from the rib.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative In rheumatology practice there is an unmet need for a system that can collect accurate information on disease activity during telehealth consultations. We will implement and validate a new technology that uses smartphone cameras to capture visual measures of joint-specific information such as range of motion and joint swelling. The technology can lead to faster and more precise measurement of symptoms in telehealth visits to optimize medication and therapy interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE This project is aimed to translate our engineered extracellular vesicles (EVs) into effective cancer therapy. We will optimize cytotoxicity and immune stimulatory functions of DR5 agonistic scFvs armed EVs and test these designer EVs in mouse clinical trials. We will then optimize bioprocessing and standardize workflow for the EVs production. This work will prepare our designer EVs to be explored as an alternative therapy for CAR-T cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TOLEDO HEALTH SCI CAMPUS
PHR: Project Narrative Autism and neurodevelopmental disorders are commonly caused by a combination of multiple interacting environmental and genetic risk factors, and yet research on combined autism risk is underdeveloped. Here, we propose to study the interaction between a genetic risk factor (Shank3 haploinsufficiency) and an environmental risk factor (developmental exposure to the pyrethroid pesticide deltamethrin) in the prairie vole, a wild rodent with highly sophisticated social behaviors. We will leverage this model to test for the dose- dependent effects of pyrethroid exposure during development on Shank3 and wild-type prairie voles, with a focus on autism-relevant behaviors and the MAPK/mTOR signaling pathways as outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current access to liver transplant is limited by the number of viable organs, and the number of suitable grafts can be improved by increasing the liver’s ability to tolerate ischemic preservation. Hypothermic oxygenated machine perfusion, a novel preservation technique, decreases ischemic damage compared to conventional storage on ice, but the molecular pathways modulated remain largely unknown. This project will identify markers of early liver graft preservation injury affected by hypothermic oxygenated machine perfusion compared with conventional storage on ice to optimize liver graft utilization, and increase access to life-saving liver transplant.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: THE TRUSTEES OF THE STEVENS INSTITUTE OF TECHNOLOGY
PHR: Project Narrative Epilepsy is one of the most common neurological disorders and at least 3.4 million people in the U.S. live with seizures, with one third patients being drug-resistant and 50% still having persistent epilepsy after surgery. This project aims to develop an Electrophysiological Network Imaging framework to characterize the seizure onset zones and propagation pathways by an integration of scalp EEG and intracranial EEG to estimate the whole brain electrophysiological networks, based on a principled inference framework with the help of partially observable information from iEEG. The proposed framework can delineate the seizure onset zone and seizure propagation pathways, thus providing an improved epileptogenic zone identification accuracy and a reduced hospitalization time and risk for epilepsy patients.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal seeks to validate the first transabdominal, non-invasive fetal electroencephalogram (EEG) using data collected from fetal scalp electrodes during active labor. The system employs a novel artificial intelligence approach to reconstruct fetal EEG from electrophysiological signals collected from the maternal abdomen. Successful validation of this system has the potential of transforming fetal monitoring and brain development research in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Hemorrhagic shock following a traumatic injury is a leading cause of preventable deaths in people aged 1-44 years old. To enhance treatment and clinical management of critically injured patients, this Diversity Supplement aims to investigate the impact of endovascular devices on fluid and medication requirements. Leveraging on an established preclinical model of hemorrhagic shock, the candidate will use novel quantitative methods including machine learning to understand the relationship between poor blood flow and heart performance with the goal of identifying improved patient monitoring algorithms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Lung cancers with mutations in KRAS and KEAP1 are notoriously difficult to treat and associated with poor outcomes in patients. We found these cancers can be killed by a histone deacetylase inhibitor drug, and by combination of this drug with a KRAS inhibitor that was recently FDA approved. In this grant we will determine the potential of this drug and drug combination to inhibit KRAS/KEAP1 mutant human lung cancers grown in mice, and identify the mechanisms involved.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Understanding the immune response to SARS-CoV-2 vaccination is important to improve vaccine efficacy in populations that are vulnerable and more at risk of developing complications from COVID-19. Patients with multiple sclerosis (MS) are on immunotherapies that can impact their immune system, affecting the quality of the vaccine response, particularly in children. Our study will assess the quality and duration of antibody and B- and T-cell responses, including neutralizing antibodies against SARS-CoV-2 infection, in vaccinated children and adults with MS undergoing different immunotherapy regimens, which may inform therapeutic decisions prescribed to vulnerable MS patients and identify critical immune pathways to boost the vaccination response in patients with MS and other patients on similar immunotherapies.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will evaluate the validity and reliability of mobile health technology to quantify movement of the hand and arm in children with hemiparetic cerebral palsy. Validating assessments that could extend into the home or other environments offers potential for measuring real-world performance that is not captured from existing clinical measures. Such assessment technology could be implemented in future work to expand the current knowledge of how children with hemiparetic cerebral palsy develop and respond to rehabilitation interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As mitochondria are fundamental to both cellular and organismal metabolic homeostasis, their dysfunction in aged women due to accumulated mitochondrial DNA mutations coupled with lack of circulating estradiol contributes to metabolic-associated steatotic liver disease. Thus, targeted mitochondrial delivery of estradiol has the potential to improve treatment for metabolic conditions in post-menopausal women. We will test whether mitochondria-targeted drugs with and without estradiol can correct age-related mitochondrial dysfunction in hepatocytes and menopausal mouse models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative Graft versus host disease (GvHD) is a frequent outcome of hematopoietic stem cell transplants used to treat hematologic diseases, such as leukemia. We have identified a means of reducing GvHD by administering cells pre-treated with a purified bacterial molecule, exopolysaccharide (EPS). EPS is non-toxic and the goal of this grant is to use a humanized mouse system to optimize treatment and to determine how EPS-treated cells inhibit GvHD, leading to new drugs to prevent GvHD in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recently, we introduced a transformative approach for cancer patient stratification by concurrently profiling canonical and modified miRNAs (miR isoforms), revealing intricate interactions influencing gene regulation. Current miR isoform-oriented resources lack user-friendly result consultation, missing the chance to uncover new cancer mechanisms. To address this gap and align with FOA objectives, we aim to develop isomiRGate, a free web-based gateway to comprehensively outline the broader miRNAome's function and regulation in cancer, including integrated methodologies and accessible data retrieval to discover novel cancer biomarkers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  By 2050, osteoporosis is expected to affect >50% of Americans over the age of 50; further, osteoporotic hip fracture incidence is expected to increase by >200% compared to rates in 1990. Recent studies have identified a large number of loci associated with bone mineral density (BMD), an important clinical marker for osteoporosis diagnosis. This project aims to define causal genes at these loci to understand their biological mechanisms, and in turn, identify new drug targets for osteoporosis therapies.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Pathogenic mutations in the mitochondrial Lon protease cause a broad spectrum of rare developmental disorders, which include CODAS syndrome and profound neurological dysfunction. This exploratory project addresses a critical gap in our understanding about the mechanistic impact of Lon's binding to mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) and its role in regulating mtDNA integrity and expression. By using innovative approaches and isogenic patient-derived cell lines expressing wild-type and mutant Lon proteins, we will elucidate the function and dysfunction of Lon not only in rare diseases, but also in common disorders in which Lon has been implicated (e.g., cancer, neurodegeneration and heart disease).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: We will determine whether the ATG16L1 T300 isoform predominantly found in African Americans predisposes that patient population, over non-Hispanic whites who predominantly express the ATG16L1 A300 isoform, to tumors that present earlier, grow faster, metastasize more rapidly and that are predisposed to being killed by drug combinations which utilize autophagy as a killing mechanism versus standard of care therapies where autophagy acts to reduce drug efficacy. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research study aims to identify whether a daily ketone supplement (KS) reduces the need for benzodiazepine medication to treat withdrawal and improves brain ketone and GABA metabolism in individuals with alcohol use disorder (AUD) during inpatient detoxification. The proposed study will generate fundamental knowledge on the potentially beneficial effects of a novel treatment for AUD and its underlying neural mechanisms. As a treatment for AUD, KS may offer a unique option: a dietary supplement whose use could obviate potentially dependence-producing benzodiazepine medication or augment its beneficial effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE An increasing number of women are using cannabis products to treat their menopausal symptoms. Our research will investigate the causal relationship between endocrine status, aging, and cannabis exposure on mood, cognition, and metabolism, with the overarching goal of understanding how cannabis use during menopause alters aging trajectories.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Single cell genomic technologies enable systems-level characterization of individual cells and are rapidly transforming biomedical research. This proposal will develop a coordinated set of computational and statistical methods and software tools for unsupervised integrative analyses of single cell genomic data across multiple samples, different data modalities, and different species. These methods and tools will advance our understanding of both basic biology and human diseases by allowing scientists to use multi-sample single cell data to discover dynamic cellular and molecular programs associated with the variations in sample phenotype without prior knowledge about the sample phenotype.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Multiple hereditary exostoses (MHE) is a debilitating genetic disorder that affects one in every 50,000 children worldwide, and currently there are no approved therapies. The significance of this work lies in the development of novel screening assays to uncover new therapeutic targets for MHE and the potential for discovery of regulatory factors involved in heparan sulfate formation. This research is highly relevant to public health because the candidate genes identified in these studies represent new potential therapeutic targets for drug development to treat this orphan disease as well as other disorders where heparan sulfate formation goes awry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PARENT R35 PROJECT NARRATIVE The active sites of central synapses are several times smaller than can be resolved using conventional approaches. Thus, much of what we know about the complex and dynamic processes involved in synaptic transmission has been inferred from indirect electrophysiological and/or biochemical assays. Our innovative nanoscale resolution imaging technology can visualize, track, and quantify presynaptic processes with single- vesicle resolution. We propose a research program based on this technology that promises to close the gap in our knowledge of synaptic transmission, including the role such processes play in the pathophysiology of Fragile X syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Schizophrenia is associated with disrupted activity of brain circuitry, precipitated by aberrant synaptic interactions between pyramidal and interneurons. Previously, we reported that Src kinase signaling, the hub of N-methyl-d- aspartate (NMDA) receptor pathway in the postsynaptic neurons, is reduced in schizophrenia, resulting from convergence of multitudes of molecular alterations schizophrenia. This project is designed to investigate how Src ad NMDAR signaling is altered distinctly in pyramidal neurons vs. interneurons.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: In this project, we will use state-of-the-art cryogenic electron tomography in situ (i.e., within cells) to understand how the filovirus nucleocapsid assembles inside cells. This work, combined with high-resolution structures, mutagenesis, and biochemical analyses, will deepen our understanding of filovirus replication processes and pave the way for the development of novel therapeutics to treat filovirus infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The science is overwhelming that the climate of our planet is changing with little time to reverse course and climate action has the potential to benefit human health and address long standing health inequities; yet local health departments and health care systems—frontline defenders of the population’s health—have historically not engaged in local climate resilience efforts. Local health systems are in constant recovery mode as evidenced by the significant impact of the COVID-19 pandemic and critical barriers to local climate action include a lack of expertise, capacity, and sustained funding within the public health workforce. The proposed community-driven project seeks to integrate climate change impacts into a regional community health assessment framework to enhance the capacity of local health systems to identify, address, and monitor climate impacts on health in rural Appalachia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project narrative Rising levels of antibiotic resistance in the bacteria as well as rising case numbers have created an urgent need to develop effective vaccines against Neisseria gonorrhoeae, and studies suggest that vaccines that contain bacterial outer membrane vesicles may provide partial protection against N. gonorrhoeae. A major protein antigen in outer membrane vesicles, PorB, has immune suppressive properties that may limit the immunogenicity of these vaccines. We propose to develop chemically inactivatable PorB proteins that can be used to generate outer membrane vesicles with improved immunogenicity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: The decision to perform a biventricular repair (BiVR) or a single ventricle palliative (SVP) in patients born with a  borderline left ventricle (BLV) remains challenging and subjective. We aim to develop a robust personalized  computational model capable of predicting the immediate postoperative outcomes of virtual BiVR and SVP with  confidence intervals and provide recommendations to choose the procedure that yields the most favorable  hemodynamics. Ultimately, this simulation-guided treatment planning will mitigate the risk of morbidity and  mortality and reinterventions in this critical population. Project Narrative

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Lassa virus causes thousands of cases of hemorrhagic fever each year in West Africa. Infection by Lassa virus is marked by pH-dependent conformational rearrangements of viral glycoprotein complex (GPC) that drive a switch from the receptor used at the cell surface to a subsequent receptor used in the endosome. In this project, we will interpret these GPC rearrangements and endosomal receptor engagement at the atomic level in order to provide the long-term missing knowledge of Lassa infection, as well as novel templates for antiviral design.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  A substantial number of clinical studies have observed defects in mitochondria in Alzheimer’s disease (AD) patients as well as post-mortem patient samples, but research remains overwhelmingly needed to better understand the mechanisms underlying mitochondrial dysfunction in AD in order to reveal promising therapeutic targets. The proposed project will study the AD-associated ubiquitination of mitochondrial proteins by a E3 ubiquitin ligase Nedd4L using a familial AD mouse model. The goal is to establish Nedd4L as a contributor for mitochondrial dysfunction in AD and introduce future therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Project Narrative Genomic medicine is rapidly expanding in cancer care and altering how and when patients receive hereditary cancer genetic testing and genetic counseling, with fewer patients being seen for both pre- and post-test counseling with a genetic counselor. This project observationally investigates how the process and content of post-test genetic counseling for hereditary breast and ovarian cancer (HBOC) vary depending on whether posttest counseling was preceded by pre-test counseling by a genetic counselor, and whether differences in communication are associated with client outcomes (retention of key information, intention to inform at-risk relatives, efficacy for follow-up, satisfaction with communication quality, psychological health, and decisional regret). Understanding how communication affects client outcomes in post-test HBOC genetic counseling interactions (F99) is critical for developing practice and curriculum standards and designing targeted training interventions (KOO) poised to increase cancer prevention and control through effective genetic counseling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Stuttering is a disorder of speech fluency that affects 3.5 million people in the USA alone. There is a great need  for increased efforts to translate recent discoveries from mechanistic neurophysiological studies into evidence based treatment options with potential for continuous optimization and personalization. The goal of this project  is to assess whether fluency enhancement with auditory feedback manipulations or with pharmacological agents  that regulate dopamine uptake improve the sensorimotor functions of speech feedback prediction and processing  in stuttering. Project Narrative

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Our proposed implantable airway stents with integrated artificial cilia, overcome the limitation of existing airway stents such as tissue ingrowth or cilia impairment, and can allow minimally invasive removal of excessive mucus in the airway. It thus addresses the current limitation of existing airway stents in terms of excessive accumulation of mucus in patients with Central Airway Obstruction due to Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease and other lung diseases. The proposed work thus could lead to novel implantable medical devices which can save lives and improve the quality of our life, with an eventual goal to shed light on new therapies for pulmonary diseases and other diseases related to cilia dysfunction.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Exercise represents one of the most beneficial things people can do to improve their health, but people often struggle to exercise enough to see the health benefits. In order to identify medications that provide some of the same benefits as exercise, this study will synergize two NIH Common Fund datasets (MoTrPAC and LINGS). By identifying biomolecular signatures of exercise from MoTrPAC and matching them to signatures of small molecules from LINGS, this study expects to identify multiple medicines that can be tested as exercise-in-a-pill.

PHR: Project Narrative Urethral disease and hypospadias are conditions that affect children and adults. When urethral replacement or  repair is required, alternative tissue options are limited and are associated with a high risk of short and long-term  complications. This proposal will create and test novel layered three dimensional (3D) bioprinted urethral tissue  patches with optimized mechanical and biological properties to effectively repair or replace urethral tissue.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Trypanosoma brucei and related trypanosomatids are deadly, vector-transmitted pathogens that cause tremendous human suffering and economic burden worldwide. Transmission by insect vectors complicates control efforts and better understanding of pathogen-vector interactions is needed to facilitate novel approaches for preventing transmission. T. brucei cAMP signaling has emerged as critical for enabling transmission by the tsetse fly vector and the current project will define mechanisms of cAMP signaling and chemotaxis in trypanosome-vector interactions, with findings expected to identify candidate targets for transmission-blocking strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

PHR: Project Narrative:  Early cancer diagnostics is critical because the number of cases is rising, and the chances of  survival increase if caught at an early stage. Currently standard screening examinations often fail  to detect these initial changes, and their challenge is to identify abnormal areas with a high  likelihood of cancer transformation. In this project, we will develop a new approach for detection  that uses large and small imaging with guidance of artificial intelligence methods for consistency  in early cancer diagnostics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Occupational silica dust exposure is linked with the autoimmune diseases rheumatoid arthritis. Although experimental models exist for several silica induced diseases, there is currently no animal model in which silica dust exposure results in arthritis. Our studies show that silica dust exposure results in severe arthritis in the BXD2 mouse strain, providing a novel model to study how silica dust exposure leads to arthritis.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Impaired angiogenesis during wound healing is a major clinical challenge in the healing of injured  tissues. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative To reduce substance-use related harms, we need to provide a suite of harm reduction service delivery approaches that will address the needs of a diverse and evolving population of people who use drugs. In the proposed study we will examine the prevalence of use, and barriers and facilitators of using harm reduction vending machines, a novel element of new US-based harm reduction service delivery modalities. This proposal addresses the NI DA 2022 strategic plan goal to accelerate the science of harm reduction and will be directly and immediately relevant to informing national drug control strategy.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: Hazardous drinking is common among Veteran primary care patients and increases risk for more costly and complex medical problems over the long-term. Yet, the vast majority of these Veterans go untreated due to patient, provider, and organizational barriers. By providing an option for care that is easily accessible, private, and self-directed, mobile applications (apps) circumvent many of the often-cited barriers to alcohol use treatment. However, poor patient engagement remains the Achilles’ heel of these apps. Through supportive accountability, Peer Specialists can maximize the reach and engagement of these apps with patients and improve drinking outcomes. If successful, our proposed research has the potential to transform care and increase access to alcohol-related services for Veterans who engage in hazardous drinking but rarely seek treatment, and, in turn, mitigate the adverse health outcomes that stem from untreated hazardous drinking.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Effective psychotherapies for depression are available in VA but are underutilized by therapists working in specialty mental health clinics. Reasons for low use have not been empirically investigated. Findings from research on the implementation of evidence-based psychotherapies for other conditions such as PTSD cannot be fully generalized to depression because depression care is organized differently in VA. In this project, we use an explanatory sequential mixed-methods approach to examine contextual and system factors that impact delivery of evidence-based psychotherapies for depression as well as explore the impact of potential therapist- and patient-level factors. Findings will inform an intervention framework that will help our partners and stakeholders in the field to prioritize barriers on which to intervene and identify promising solutions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Crosstalk between immune cells and brain-resident cells such as neurons and glia occurs both in healthy conditions and during the progression of neurodevelopmental diseases such as autism and schizophrenia. This proposal seeks to understand the role of a unique population of mast cells next to the developing hippocampus and its potential for driving proper neurodevelopment. Unraveling the complexities of these interactions during normal developmental stages can lead to a better understanding of how neuroimmune interactions can be altered in disease.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JAMES J PETERS VA  MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Older Veterans, particularly those with multiple chronic conditions requiring complex medication regimens, are more susceptible to adverse effects of medications. In this study, we examine the effect of a pharmacist led medication management intervention delivered by home televisit on improving medication use. We anticipate that a pharmacist led medication management intervention will lead to reduction in medication discrepancies and inappropriate use, increased medication adherence and reduced adverse drug events in older adults compared to those without the intervention and receiving usual care. Findings will enhance our understanding of methods to improve medication use in older adults, and have the potential to disseminate across VHA.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: EDITH NOURSE  ROGERS MEMORIAL VETERANS HOSPITAL
PHR: Type 2 Diabetes is a common, complex health condition which can result in many serious and costly health complications if not treated and controlled properly. Overall, 24% of Veterans are diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes. Vulnerable Veterans, such as minority, low-income, or rural Veterans, and Veterans with comorbid mental health diagnoses, are disproportionately affected and are less likely to have their diabetes under control. One way to help Veterans improve their diabetes control is through the use of technology to help provide information, motivation, and reminders necessary to support diabetes self-management. This study seeks to leverage “Annie”, a new VA texting system. The study will seek input from vulnerable Veteran groups living with diabetes to help develop DD-TXT, a new customizable, interactive texting intervention that allows Veterans to choose what kinds of diabetes self-management support they need, and when. It will compare DD- TXT with another education-only texting intervention called DSE that is based on a diabetes skills workbook.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE Ultrapotent synthetic opioids, like fentanyl, are highly toxic agents that pose a significant public health risk and can cause near-immediate cardiorespiratory collapse requiring resuscitative action. This proposal aims to provide resolution into the cardiopulmonary and neurophysiological outcomes following resuscitation from fentanyl-induced cardiorespiratory collapse. We will examine mechanisms contributing to reperfusion injury and test how targeting such mechanisms during reversal of fentanyl-induced cardiorespiratory collapse affects survival and physiological outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health, as we will define endolysosomal mechanisms in the context of childhood developmental and neurodegenerative disease. Endolysosomal dysfunction is a critical feature in neurogenetic diseases, as well as more common diseases such as: Lysosome Disorders, Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) and AD-Related Dementias (ADRD), including tauopathies; autism and related intellectual disabilities. A fuller understanding of mechanisms that protect the endolysosomal system may aid in developing new therapeutics for these diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE Mutations in ASH1L are a major cause of autism spectrum disorder (ASD) when these genetic changes impair protein function. The ASH1L transcription factor is a protein that regulates large groups of genes simultaneously, including other autism genes. Our goals in this proposal are 1) identify cellular defects in human neurons with patient mutations in ASH1L using iPSC-derived experimental systems, 2) study the functional and circuit defects associated with ASH1L deficiency, and 3) identify the epigenetic and transcriptional signatures associated with ASH1L using mouse and human experimental systems. For all of these Aims, we will rescue the phenotypes identified using a mechanistic approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This research program addresses critical research gaps in understanding the challenges and supportive care needs of nurses with cancer as they return to work (RTW). Nurses and all other healthcare workers play a pivotal role in the healthcare system and population health, and given nurses’ substantial cancer risks and the significance of a successful RTW on cancer survivors’ health-related quality of life (HRQOL), this study aims to clarify intervention targets and develop a tailored mobile health intervention with human-centered design principles to support healthcare works to RTW. This study aligns with the goal of cancer survivorship research to improve cancer survivors’ RTW and HRQOL and provide appropriate support to the healthcare workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lack of durable CD8+ T-cell response to produce inflammatory cytokines upon tumor infiltration remains a barrier to immunotherapy for most cancer patients, prompting the need for a deeper understanding of how T-cells rapidly become dysfunctional. My predoctoral research will delve into how environmental amino acid depletion drives the loss of protein synthesis and cytokine production in tumor-infiltrating T-cells. Furthermore, my postdoctoral research will delve into non-coding-RNA-mediated translational suppression during terminal T-cell exhaustion, unveiling distinct dysfunctional mechanisms during early and late tumor infiltration and justifying metabolic interventions that enhance intracellular AA availability in T-cells to enhance the potency of immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: A novel computational imaging algorithm that combines principles of light matter interaction and information theory to characterize the mechanobiology of three-dimensional whole slide tumor microenvironments, which is important for understanding cancer development, its metastasis and its response to therapy. The input to the algorithm is Hematoxylin and Eosin brightfield images capturing the tissue structure, and multiplexed immunofluorescence images spatially profiling the molecules and cellular diversity of interest.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Project Title: Long-term Effects of a household Air Pollution intervention: Follow-up of a randomized controlled trial This proposal seeks to evaluate the long-term effects of an 18-month clean fuel intervention in Puno, Peru, on lung function, cardiovascular disease risk and neurodevelopmental outcomes in children. We will measure clinical outcomes, kitchen concentrations and personal exposures to PM2.5 once yearly and monitor biomass stoves continuously throughout the study period. We will examine whether health outcomes of intervention participants differ to those from control households through the child’s eighth birthday and conduct exposure- response analyses based on the PM2.5 exposure and stove use data during the intervention and subsequent follow-up period.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding how mutations in DYRK1A cause decreased neuronal growth will give us important insight into the pathobiology of ASD/ID and microcephaly and identify potential therapeutics for this condition. This proposed research will study the neurodevelopmental relationship between Dyrk1a mutations and mTOR signaling, a biological pathway known to be dysregulated in humans with autism spectrum disorder and intellectual disability. The goal of this project is to identify a mechanism by which Dyrk1a mutations cause altered brain and neuronal growth and ASD-relevant behaviors and ultimately rescue these alterations through genetic and pharmacological interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The supplement will permit the purchase of a next-generation imaging device that offers superior color representation to allow our funded AI imaging grant to work with the latest scanning laser technology. The overall goal of our federally funded research study is to develop artificial intelligence-based methods of montaging images of the back of the eye from different imaging devices. This instrument is just now available, and our ophthalmology department does not have one; it will be housed in the Jacobs Retina Center and serve our overall goal of helping ophthalmologists and researchers to better understand and diagnose eye diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Glutamate-activated NMDA receptors mediate a Ca2+-permeable component of excitatory synaptic transmission in the brain that is involved in learning, memory, and development. NMDA receptors have been implicated in a wide range of neurological conditions, and there is intense interest in the development of allosteric modulators as new therapeutic treatments for neurological disease. This research program is designed to address all key aspects of glutamate receptor signaling, including the structural underpinnings of function, genetic variation as it relates to rare disease and risk factors, identification of therapeutically-relevant molecules that can be used as probes to develop novel treatment strategies, and the fundamental process of synaptic transmission.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Drug resistance and Acute Myeloid Leukemia burdens are associated downregulation of tumor-suppressing pro- teins and the manifestation of tumor-promoting protein fusions, but therapeutic approaches directly focused on these pivotal biomolecules remains a technical challenge. This proposal aims to investigate the roles and mech- anisms underlying RNA deregulation in primary and relapsed Acute Myeloid Leukemia. Findings from this ex- ploratory study will lead to the development of a larger grant providing the scientific basis for a novel RNA-based therapeutic for the disease that is poorly treated.

ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: Narrative The CDC reported over 176,000 cases of syphilis in the U.S. in 2021, which is a 74% increase from 2017. The current serum antibody-based diagnostic tests for Syphilis are unable to distinguish current and past infection and suffer from imperfect specificity and sensitivity. This project aims to develop a rapid (< 30 minutes) and low- cost (<$3 per test) point-of-care diagnostic assay for active Syphilis.

PHR: Pluripotent stem cells (PSCs)-derived cardiomyocytes (CMs) fail to fully mature in vitro and in adult hearts, limiting their biomedical applications. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: Cerebellar ataxias are debilitating neurological disorders. The next generation of therapies for neurological disorders will need to understand how cerebellum actuates control to manipulate specific output pathways. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Most microbes that affect our health self-organize into spatially structured communities, for example on surfaces where they form biofilms or in crypts or the lumen of the gut where they form interacting collectives. By elucidating and thoroughly testing how the self-organization of a key pathogen interplays with antimicrobial resistance evolution in vitro and in vivo, this project can offer valuable insights for spatial structure-based methods to mitigate or slow drug resistance evolution. More generally, an improved understanding of the basic forces of evolution in spatially structured populations provides foundational knowledge for modeling a wide range of evolutionary processes and formulating hypotheses about drug resistance in other evolutionary diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Psychological distress is a common symptom experienced by breast cancer survivors, however data about psychological distress in Black breast cancer survivors is sparse. This study will address these gaps by leveraging an existing longitudinal cohort data and primary qualitative interview and focus group data, to a) explore healthcare delivery and psychosocial factors that contribute to psychological distress among Black breast cancer survivors, and b) the strategies employed by Black breast cancer survivors to cope with psychological distress. Findings from this study may offer opportunities to develop multilevel interventions seeking to improve psychological distress outcomes in Black breast cancer survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE PIK3CA mutant positive tumor-initiating cells (TICs) can resist anti-tumor immunity and drive tumor relapse after immune checkpoint blockade (ICB) treatment in squamous cell carcinomas (SCCs). The F99 phase of this proposal will determine how PIK3CA mutations expand the immune-resistant TICs in SCC tumors by stabilizing the Sox2 transcription factor following ICB. The K00 phase will dissect how PIK3CA mutations enhance TIC immune resistance to T cell-mediated ferroptosis and how other genetic determinants confer stemness and intrinsic immune resistance to TICs, revealing novel drug targets and biomarkers for predicting patient responses to immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sophisticated single-cell and spatial multi-omics data provide unprecedented characterization of the regulatory programs of cellular phenotypes in tumors and their microenvironments, but they do not capture the dynamics of cell interactions that drive cancer progression. Agent-based simulation models (ABMs) allow scientists to test hypotheses as model rules, but it is challenging to determine model rules from imaging data. This project will merge state-of-the-art bioinformatics tools for spatial multi-omics data with web-hosted ABM software to give scientists new, biologically interpretable tools to learn, refine, and manipulate the rules of cancer ecosystems, paving the way for future cancer patient digital twins and next-generation predictive medicine. ‘

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Narrative Type 1 diabetes is an autoimmune disease caused in part by destruction of insulin- producing beta cells in the pancreas by white blood cells called T lymphocytes, which recognize Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC) molecules presenting beta cells proteins as foreign and attack them as if they were viruses or bacteria infecting the body. Research proposed in this project will determine how MHC polymorphisms influence the susceptibility of succumbing to T1D and how T lymphocytes initiate autoimmune responses. This understanding might lead to better understanding of the autoimmune response in diabetes, and how it could be better diagnosed, controlled, or prevented.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Optical methods are a primary technique for the study of cellular physiology. This research concerns the development of new optical probes that will enable photocontrol of membrane excitability in vitro and in vivo. Since almost all cell signaling is bidirectional or symbiotic, these new methods will revolutionize our ability to control function and therefore uncover many fresh details of cell physiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL), which remains incurable despite recent advances in targeted therapeutics, relies on metabolic alterations to meet the immense energetic demands of sustained growth and persist in diverse environments including the blood, spleen, lymph nodes and bone marrow. Sphingolipids, particularly ceramides, hold great therapeutic potential as they can regulate many cellular pathways that impinge on metabolic systems and the delivery of these bioactive molecules has been shown to induce cell death in both in vitro and in vivo models of CLL. The F99 phase of this proposal will establish the mechanism by which exogenous ceramide induced ganglioside accumulation leads to mitochondrial dysfunction and cell death in CLL, while the K00 phase will leverage CRISPR screening and advanced in vivo mitochondrial characterization to better understand the role of sphingolipids and their therapeutic potential in mitochondrial transfer and glioma stem cell support of glioblastoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative Advanced melanoma is the most serious type of skin cancer with poor prognosis. Here, we propose to investigate multivalent small circular RNA vaccines that generate potent and long-lasting immune responses for melanoma combination immunotherapy. The results from this project are anticipated to define the design guidelines of these novel vaccines and ultimately improve the clinical practice and outcomes of current melanoma treatments.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Narrative: Linking differences in our genes to the molecular and physiological mechanisms underlying disease remains a major challenge. Here we use data from the Common Fund Data Ecosystem (CFDE) along with two advanced data science technologies, knowledge graphs and visible neural network, to develop a new method for revealing the molecular pathway of genetically complex disorders. We will initially develop this tool for data related to Type 2 Diabetes, but have the ultimate goal of extending this approach to other genetic studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: EBV infection usually has a benign outcome, yet nearly 144,000 people annually die of untreatable malignancies caused by latent EBV infection of lymphoid or epithelial cells. EBV protein expression is the oncogenic driver and progressive force in B cell lymphomas. This current proposal will reveal new epigenetic and metabolic vulnerabilities that can be leveraged to treat EBV+ B malignancies specifically.
