IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ocular misalignment (strabismus) and compromised visual acuity (amblyopia) are visual developmental disorders that affect a vast number of children born every year in the United States and around the world. Prior to application of treatment in humans, a better understanding of neural mechanisms and pre-clinical testing in non-human primate models are needed to help develop and refine rationally based therapy. This project will a) combine various physiological methods and behavior investigation in an animal model for strabismus to investigate how gaze is re-oriented to visual stimuli and b) develop and test in the non-human primate, a novel treatment strategy for amblyopia that has shown promise in cat and mouse models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE Cellular plasticity drives tumor heterogeneity and drug resistance; however, we lack an understanding of its underlying molecular mechanisms. In our preliminary work, we identified a mode of non-genetic adaptation in response to therapeutic intervention in clinical and pre-clinical models. In this proposal, we present an approach to dissect the cellular plasticity programs in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) for disrupting and predicting the chromatin landscape that underpins cancer cell state transitions involved in drug resistance.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Cardiorespiratory fitness (CRF) is an integrative measure of cardiopulmonary and metabolic health and independent predictor of long-term survival that can be improved with exercise training. Despite this, limited knowledge exists regarding the biochemical pathways that underlie CRF. Our goal is to combine novel blood protein profiling technology with genetics and gene expression databases from Common Fund resources to identify promising candidate protein determinants of CRF – findings that set the stage for further mechanistic studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement (Narrative) (from Parent Award) Schizophrenia is the 5th leading cause of disability in the world, affecting 51 million people in which patients suffer from cardinal deficits in self-agency (i.e., the fundamental experience of being the agent of one's own thoughts and actions). These deficits directly contribute to debilitating psychotic symptoms, and show limited response to pharmacological treatments with up to 40% of patients with schizophrenia (SZ) remaining symptomatic, thus compelling the need to identify the neurophysiology underlying self-agency deficits to guide new treatment development. Findings from this proof-of-concept study will delineate: (i) the underlying cognitive and neural cause of self-agency deficits in schizophrenia, (ii) responsiveness to new neurostimulation interventions targeting a novel neural target in the medial prefrontal cortex, and (iii) mechanisms of durability and generalizability, revealing how improvements in critical self-agency abilities can generalize to improvements in general cognition, symptoms and life quality in schizophrenia for future TMS treatment development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer-cachexia is a wasting syndrome that occurs in up to 80% of cancer patients and is the primary cause of death for 20-40% of cancer patients. While obesity has been suggested to protect against the severity of cachexia due to having ‘more to spare’, published work from my F31 demonstrates that obesity is not protective against cachexia and suggests exacerbated impairments to mitochondrial function and quality control with a particular disruption in the removal of damaged mitochondria. The goal of my F99/K00 is to 1) understand the microbial and metabolic perturbations with cancer cachexia in the obese state (F99), and 2) establish microbiome-mitochondrial interactions in obesity associated cancer cachexia and identify strategies for intervention (K00).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will use behavioral and functional neuroimaging techniques to investigate how arousal states alter vision-related neural responses. Results will inform and provide critical constraints to models of the human visual system, which provide a necessary framework for the development of diagnostic tools and treatments for clinical disorders that involve deficits of central visual processing. Moreover, the studies could yield generalizable insights about how arousal modulates neural processing across brain systems, thereby informing the development of diagnostic tests and interventions for conditions that involve atypical arousal levels.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding predisposition to hematological diseases, such as pediatric Acute Myeloid Leukemia (pAML) is crucial for deciphering disease pathogenesis, finding treatment targets, and selecting appropriate donors for bone marrow transplant. Here, I propose to study deleterious germline variants in cohorts of pAML from the TARGET and Kids First! Consortiums, and to develop the necessary techniques to model the effects of variants in vivo. I will build on the training and knowledge in the next phase of my career, in which I will study the structural, splicing, and synonymous germline genetic variation and viral infections in the etiology of pediatric and early- onset AML.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The importance of human biospecimens in research continues to grow, and the Human Tissue and Organs for Research Resource (HTORR) program provides innovative services to support investigators that require human tissues and organs for their research. Over the past 4 years, over 500 scientific papers were published by investigators that received biospecimens from HTORR, demonstrating HTORR's indispensable contribution to the research community and the impact of these services on the search for new treatments and cures for common and rare diseases. Importantly, as new tools and technologies are developed, the resources supporting this work also need to evolve and modernize to be able to continue providing the best quality resources to facilitate rigor and reproducibility throughout the research communities that we serve.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Long-term patient outcomes following lung transplantation are poor, in part because it is challenging to diagnose respiratory infections and to distinguish infection from rejection. We have developed innovative approaches that use bacteriophages in peripheral blood to diagnose respiratory infections. These studies may lead to revolutionary, non-invasive diagnostic approaches to monitor patient health following lung transplantation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Maternal obesity with hyperphagia is a risk factor for preeclampsia, pregnancy hypertension, and offspring cardiometabolic disease. In utero programming of female offspring during preeclampsia contributes to the lifecycle of disease in women as a sex and gender. Investigating the maternal obesogenic environment is warranted to halt the transgenerational programming of cardiometabolic disease risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE: We are proposing PLUS - Phenotyping Large Oncosomes for Ultimate Evaluation of Patients Status as an innovative approach to liquid biopsy for patients with prostate cancer. Our PLUS assay will be a multi-analyte test including the protein and RNA cargo of large extracellular vesicles known as large oncosomes, which are identified in patient plasma and strongly associated with aggressive disease both in the castration resistance and castration sensitive space. Our study is technologically innovative, yet maintains a keen focus on obtaining robust datasets that are obtained from validated protocols run in a CLIA laboratory setting using multiple independent cohorts of cancer patient specimens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE The Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome coronavirus-2 (SARS-CoV-2) can hijack the normal operations of human cells, which makes it especially dangerous. It encodes a set of nonstructural proteins (nsp) to protect its RNA genome from host degradation and immune restriction. Our studies will combine biochemical, structural, cellular, and genomic approaches to address fundamental questions related to RNA modification, host immune restriction, viral growth and pathogenesis, and develop new molecular tools to collectively inform new COVID- 19 treatments and protect ourselves against future coronaviral infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Expansion of Clinical Trials Network Research Capacity to Address Overdose Mortality in Pregnant and Post-Partum Individuals with OUD PROJECT NARRATIVE This expansion project will encompass the following four projects, aimed at opioid overdose prevention, learning about barriers and facilitators regarding treatment and research engagement in pregnant and post-partum individuals (PPI) with OUD, especially PPI of color and those living in rural areas. The IMPROVE expansion project teams will work with the IMPROVE COE Implementation Hub to disseminate any products generated, which will focus on recruitment, retention, and engagement of pregnant/postpartum women with OUD. Project 1: Personally-Tailored Opioid-overdose and Medication for opioid use disorder (MOUD) Education (TOME) for pregnant and postpartum persons in MOUD: A pilot randomized trial (TOME trial) This study plans to evaluate the benefit of personally-tailored opioid overdose and medication for opioid use disorder education in pregnant and post-partum individuals receiving medication for opioid use disorder. Approximately 120 PP will be randomized in a 1:1 ratio to TOME or control balancing on site. TOME participants will receive a 15-minute intervention in which a trained research staff member reviews personal feedback reports with the recipient to provide information on the items missed on the opioid overdose (OOD) and MOUD knowledge assessment. Control participants will receive SAMHSA handouts about OOD and MOUD. Project 2: Successful Recruitment and Retention in a Randomized Controlled Trial of Pregnant People with Opioid Use Disorder (SUCCESS STUDY) This study plans to identify currents strategies, facilitators and challenges in recruitment and retention among sites in the MOMs trial. This project will conduct surveys, focus groups and interviews with research staff and individuals currently enrolled in the study. This project will develop a manual with recommendations for strategies and approach for trials to recruit and retain PP with OUD in RCTs. Project 3: Promoting Research with Mothers receiving OUD Treatment; a focus on Equity (PRoMOTE) This study plans to understand patient and provider perspectives and key facilitators and barriers to treatment engagement for women in color and living in rural areas. The study will invite patients and providers to participate in surveys and focus interviews; the patient interviews will be completed by mothers in recovery (trained and mentored on interviewing skills) who have expertise in interviewing women of color and women living in rural areas with SUD. The studies will seek to understand the needs of pregnant women who use opioids (including fentanyl) from diverse communities that include communities with differing laws regarding reproductive health. The data will assist in future outreach and engagement in MOUD. Project 4: Improved Messaging Strategies for MOUD for Underserved Populations of Pregnant and Postpartum Individuals with OUD. This project plans to develop innovative and meaningful education/messaging strategies regarding (1) addiction disease & NOWS, (2) the role of medications in the management of OUD and overdose prevention, (3) stigma and health system mistrust, and (4) PP persons rights to treatment. This project plans to involve researchers, patients, and community advisors to develop products specific to the target population (Hispanic, Black, and Native PP women, and those living in rural areas).

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative The ovarian reserve is a finite and precious pool of early oocytes established in the fetal ovary and that regulates a woman’s overall health and fertility. We have discovered that TAF4b promotes precise development of the mouse ovarian reserve and TAF4b-deficient mice undergo many of the hallmarks of premature ovarian aging including defective meiosis I, increased primordial follicle attrition, elevated gonadotropins and female infertility. By elucidating the molecular mechanisms of TAF4b in the regulation of the establishment of the ovarian follicle reserve in the mouse, we will increase our fundamental understanding of the mechanisms that regulate the establishment of the human ovarian reserve.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Multimodal signals, such as the integrated face and voice of an engaging caregiver, draw attention to and facilitate processing of communicative cues that occur across modalities, particularly beneficial when language processing is difficult. By leveraging the continuum of multi modality that naturally occurs in the ecologically-valid communicative signals of infant-directed speech and song, the current project investigates mechanisms (specific multimodal cues), moderators {diagnosis, expressive language), and communicative contexts (infant-directed speech and song) that adaptively drive patterns of social visual attention (e.g., mouth-looking) for language development in autism. By combining new data collection with a large extant longitudinal database of autistic infants and toddlers over the first two years of life, findings will identify underlying multimodal communication mechanisms, developmental windows of opportunity, and individually-tailored, actionable targets for early language intervention using multimodal infant-directed communication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Air pollution is a known environmental risk factor for lung cancer, but the detailed mechanisms driving air pollution-induced lung carcinogenesis are not yet fully understood. To address these critical gaps, I propose this F99/K00 study to investigate the underlying molecular signatures and pathways using novel multi-omics integration across genomics, proteomics, and metabolomics in my F99 training. Transitioning to my K00 phase, I will focus on developing omics-based risk prediction models to enhance lung cancer risk stratification by smoking status, a crucial step toward identifying high-risk individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Staying in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) can have lasting effects on the brain and behavior, including increasing the risk for substance use disorders. Here we will develop a better rat model of the NICU experience to elucidate how this early adversity changes social and cannabis motivation, as well as causes structural and molecular changes in the medial prefrontal cortex, a key part of the reward circuit. Successful development of this NICU model and the hypothesis-generating activities in this grant will launch future proposals delineating mechanisms by which a common early adverse experience changes reward circuitry and increases adolescent drug misuse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are significant and persistent racial and ethnic disparities in incidence and mortality for endometrial cancer. We propose to develop and validate statistical risk prediction models for endometrial cancer leveraging the racial and ethnic diversity of the All of Us Research Program cohort with the goal of creating better strategies for early detection across diverse populations. Our innovative modeling approach integrates the burden of rare deleterious genetic variation, epidemiological risk factors and socio-environmental indices causally associated with endometrial cancer health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite advances in cancer treatment, metastatic disease is almost always fatal. In addition, tumor cells can spread early to distant organs, survive initial treatment, and lie dormant for years before reactivating to produce a detectable tumor. This study will investigate the tumor cell-intrinsic and extrinsic factors that drive drug resistance and metastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Narrative We aim to deeply characterize the microbes present in the pancreatic cancer microenvironment from spatial and functional perspective. To this end, we will use a combination of human tissue- based analysis, mouse models of pancreatic cancer and liver metastasis, as well as organoid and barcoding-based microbial tracking studies. The results of the studies proposed will be crucial to inform the development of novel microbial modulation strategies to tackle this deadly disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hormone receptor expression and signaling are hypothesized to play varying and important pathologic roles in central nervous system (CNS) tumors, most notably in meningiomas, the most common primary intercranial tumors, and glioblastomas, the most malignant primary brain tumors in adults. However, the biochemical and gene expression mechanisms underlying sex-specificity and hormone receptor signaling in these tumors remain largely unknown. To address these limitations, this project will investigate the role of female sex hormones in driving progesterone receptor expression and signaling in meningiomas, and will use large-scale proteomics to shed light on hormone receptor signaling axes in glioblastomas in order to identify novel therapeutic targets in these devastating CNS cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The growth factors and transcriptional activators that specify monocyte/macrophage (MF) differentiation into diverse types of monocytes and tissue-resident MFs have largely been identified. In contrast, the impact of environmental signals – particularly that of endogenous metabolites – on MF differentiation and function remains essentially unexplored. In this project we will characterize the impact of intracellular trafficking of heme, a vital metabolite, in MF biology and its role in homeostasis and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Depression and poverty are linked together in an intractable syndemic affecting millions of people around the world. Poverty is a major cause of depression, while depression significantly reduces economic productivity. Integrated intervention approaches that seek to interrupt the cycle of poverty and depression have not been tested. Innovative science is required to move forward in this area: a diversified scientific workforce is key to scientific innovation. This application describes a Diversity Supplement application that will prepare a diversity candidate, the first in her family to attend college, for a career in global mental health research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative: Public Health Relevance Sensory afferent feedback plays a critical role in controlling movement, however, we still know very little about the central transmission pathways and how they intersect with spinal motor system. Studies in this proposal will dissect the functional organization of the sensorimotor circuitry in the spinal cord, in order to better understand the control systems that regulate movement and to develop new approaches for treating spinal motor disorders and spinal cord injury, as well as neuropathic pain and chronic itch.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Directed evolution has proven to be a valuable technique for adapting enzymes to do elaborate chemistries that would otherwise be synthetically challenging. A major bottleneck to evaluating the hundreds to thousands of individually mutated library members involves the screening of products using colorimetric reporter or bioactivity assays, or time-consuming chromatography-based analyses on the experiments themselves. We propose to combine our respective strengths in biochemistry and mass spectrometry to develop a sensitive, accurate high throughput mass spectrometry based workflow to expedite the screening of a directed evolution library without the reliance on chromatography techniques in order to identify significant biocatalytic transformations.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JOHN D DINGELL VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Central sleep apnea (CSA) is common in patients with heart failure and those using opioid analgesics. Unfortunately, effective treatment of central apnea remains elusive, pressure therapy given the modest efficiency of positive airway pressure therapy. The focus of this proposal is to identify mechanistic pathways to guide future therapeutic interventions for central sleep apnea based on the strong premise that multi-modality therapy will normalize respiration and hence mitigate adverse long-term consequences of CSA. Our proposed studies will test combination therapies, including PAP plus a pharmacological agent who have heart failure or are using opioid analgesics. We anticipate that findings will inform future clinical trials to improve care and quality of life among Veterans suffering from central sleep apnea, which remains difficult to treat using existing approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative The primary aim of this 90-day randomized trial in older adults with Alzheimer's Disease and mild dementia will determine whether nicotinamide mononucleotide (NMN), a NAD+ precursor, crosses the blood-brain barrier, and engages the hypothesized target mechanism. This request for supplemental funds was necessitated by the delay in trial's completion due to multiple unanticipated factors that are described in the Research Strategies section. This application for administrative supplement requests funds to support the addition of a second clinical trial site to expedite participant recruitment, enable the completion of the trial and accomplishment of the proposed aims of the project.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: LAC Narrative The goals of the proposed SCORE are to identify stress-immune pathway abnormalities beginning in fetal development that impact key stress-related neural circuits resulting in shared consequences for sex differences in lifelong depression and autonomic and other physiologic dysregulation. Our SCORE proposes a set of synergistic basic and clinical studies in tandem with cores to share technological expertise and enhance the training of the next generation. The LAC will oversee responsibility for: maintaining connections between sites and studies, setting up meetings and conference calls to review study progress, budget administration, organizing symposia and conferences, publicizing opportunities for trainees, supporting new initiatives, and implementing dissemination of the knowledge gained to the scientific and medical communities, policy makers, and the public.

ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: NARRATIVE The interactions between keratinocytes and dermal papilla cells are essential for the formation of the hair follicles and the production of the hair shaft but the precise mechanisms are poorly defined. Here, we propose to investigate the role of the proteoglycans produced by the dermal papilla cells on the dermal papilla aggregate formation and hair follicle keratinocyte proliferation. Knowledge gained from this study will shed light on basic biological processes underlying cell-cell interaction and provide novel insight in hair loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to understand the complex biological system of mantle cell lymphoma (MCL) and its contribution to clinical outcomes including therapeutic response and survival. We will conduct an innovative multi-omic pooled analysis of MCL patients that have undergone molecular studies at the University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center (MDACC). We intend to use statistical techniques, computational tools and software to identify clinically useful variables and prognostic features to personalize treatments for MCL.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pain in children is common and inadequately treated due to the paucity of rigorous clinical trials and the absence of a sustainable research and data ecosystem for pediatric pain. This proposal represents a partnership between Duke Clinical Research Institute and The University of Utah. We will leverage our complementary strengths to establish the Duke-Utah HEAL KIDS Pain Resource and Data Center to ensure successful completion of pediatric acute pain trials and generation of high-quality, accessible data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Type 1 diabetes (T1D) is caused by autoimmune attack of pancreatic beta cells. Our proposed work will define the role of PTPN22 in controlling the balance of pathogenic and regulatory CD4 T cells in T1D, leading to a better understanding of the genetic basis of this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Lack of sleep has adverse consequences for memory formation in both humans and animals. We have found that sleep deprivation in Drosophila causes specific defects in dopamine dynamics in the memory circuit, impairing short-term and protein synthesis-dependent memory formation. In this proposal we will uncover the molecular and circuit mechanisms by which sleep deprivation disrupts learning and design interventions to reverse them.

PHR: NARRATIVE Pulmonary fibrosis is a terminal complication of diseases such as idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) and systemic sclerosis (SSc). IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal aims to develop an ultra-flexible and stretchable bioelectronic microarchitecture system converged with an integrated artificial capillary network and a feedback sensing network. This system is designed to be seamlessly embedded in 3D cardiac microtissues and organoids, enabling efficient 3D delivery of essential media and providing real-time feedback on cellular activities throughout tissue development. The successful implementation of this technology is expected to substantially improve cardiac tissue development and maturation, enhancing tissue models for biomedical research and therapeutic applications.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children with acute respiratory failure (ARF) require invasive mechanical ventilation (MV) – an intrusive, painful, lifesaving procedure. They universally receive high-dose opioids, yet still experience episodes of acute pain. Optimizing Pain Treatment In Children On Mechanical ventilation (OPTICOM) is a well-designed large-scale randomized controlled trial that will define the effectiveness of supplementing opioids with acetaminophen and/or ketorolac at (i) reducing pain and (ii) decreasing opioid exposure in this vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: HENRY FORD HEALTH + MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: African American emerging adults (ages 18-30) are disproportionately impacted by asthma, but have been under-represented in research. Mobile asthma management interventions may help improve asthma control and allow people to live healthier lives. During this project, we will use an innovative strategy to develop an optimized mobile asthma management intervention using the most effective combination of nurse-delivered asthma education, a smart phone app, and text messaging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative: The correct segregation of the genomic material during cell division is an important process, which is fundamental to life and any segregation error has severe implications for the organisms. By providing unique and novel information on the spindle structure and function we will gain a better understanding of the forces and mechanisms involved in the process of chromosome segregation and ultimately healthy mitotic spindles. The data acquired in the frame of this proposal will be valuable to identify new therapeutic approaches and targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Our overall goal is to better understand the neural and psychiatric effects of comorbid cannabis use in adolescent depression—two major public health concerns associated with long-term consequences. A prospective multimodal study will test the overall hypothesis that adolescent cannabis use and depression have additive effects, leading to worse clinical outcome and inducing alterations in reward and pain neurocircuits over a 2-year follow-up. By focusing on these predictive relationships, we seek to comprehensively understand the impact of cannabis use in depressed adolescents on both the neurocircuitry and clinical outcome dimensions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is the most common hematological malignancy and the leading cause of cancer-related death in children in the United States. The MEK signaling pathway plays a key role in the progression of T-cell ALL (T-ALL). We have demonstrated that MEK7 is upregulated in this disease, and it causes disease progression by upregulating another kinase, JNK. We plan to develop selective inhibitors for MEK7 to study the activity of these kinases in T-ALL in vivo. This advance will allow for unique insights delineating the role of MEK7 in T-ALL and validating these kinases as potential new drug targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study will adapt and evaluate CARES, an intervention that aims to prevent HIV among adolescent girls and young women by increasing their use of pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) methods. We will test whether CARES increases PrEP use and whether it is acceptable and feasible to implement in real-world programmatic settings in Zimbabwe and South Africa. If successful, the study will provide an effective tool to support PrEP use in this priority population and ensure that CARES ideally positioned for scale-up to programs throughout the region.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (unchanged from initial application) Leukemia remains difficult to treat, indicating an urgent need to develop new therapeutic strategies; thus, the overarching goal of the proposed research is to explore leukemia metabolism and develop novel biomarkers and therapeutic strategies. Our preliminary data demonstrates that specific metabolic pathways driving serine biosynthesis are increased in leukemia; these reflect vulnerabilities that we can develop imaging biomarkers to target. Our proposed work will facilitate future patient-specific treatment planning and novel experimental strategies for cancer treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: NATHAN S. KLINE INSTITUTE FOR PSYCH RES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This project intends to significantly advance our understanding of Alzheimer's disease (AD) by focusing on an aspect of the disease that occurs early: hyperexcitability. We hypothesize that hyperexcitability develops first in the hippocampal dentate gyrus (DG) which would be a paradigm shift; we will address the hypothesis using state-of-the-art methods for selective DG silencing in mouse models of AD. We also will test a novel mechanism for the generation of DG hyperexcitability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lung fibrosis is a progressive, incurable disease with few treatment options. This proposal aims to define if targeting the epigenetic enzyme EZH2 using an FDA-approved drug would be a viable therapeutic option for lung fibrosis patients. The proposed research will expand our knowledge about how epi-drugs can influence important phenotypes of lung disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will determine how the immune cells of the brain, known as microglia, change the synaptic connections between nerve cells in the brain. This novel mechanism could help explain how immune signals can impact the formation of long-term memories.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Built on recent findings from each laboratory, the Qi and Zhao laboratories team up to investigate the role of STING and its crosstalk with a highly conserved protein quality-control mechanism known as endoplasmic reticulum (ER)-associated degradation (ERAD) in AD pathogenesis. Our central hypothesis is that chronic activation of STING-mediated innate immunity in the brain is a fundamental mechanism underlying neuroinflammation in AD pathogenesis, which is regulated by SEL1L-HRD1 ERAD. This hypothesis is supported by our strong preliminary data pointing towards the role of ERAD-STING axis in both neuroinflammation and amyloid pathology.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Each year, >5 million American children undergo surgeries including major and painful cardiac surgeries and spine fusion surgeries. More than 50% of these children experience uncontrolled severe acute surgical pain, significant opioid-related adverse outcomes including respiratory depression, persistent opioid use/misuse, opi- oid dependence, overdoses, and deaths, and chronic persistent surgical pain. Implementation of evidence-based standardized perioperative methadone-based multimodal acute surgical pain management in this clinical trial, and proactive and personalized risk identification will maximize acute surgical pain relief while minimizing opioid use, serious opioid-related adverse outcomes, and transition of acute surgical pain to chronic surgical pain in millions of children undergoing major and painful surgeries each year.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In humans, damage to motor cortex or its outputs causes profound and often permanent movement deficits. Treating dysfunction, or finding ways to bypass it using a brain-computer interface, requires a principled understanding of normal function. The goal of this proposal is to use novel experimental approaches to illuminate how neural activity in motor cortex subserves the generation and control of our movements.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: SANFORD BURNHAM PREBYS MEDICAL DISCOVERY INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) is in urgent need of therapeutic strategies that offer an improvement in clinical outcome and the targeting of glutamine metabolism represents a promising approach in developing anti-cancer therapies. We have identified that the stimulation of macropinocytosis, an amino acid supply route in cancer cells, represents a novel metabolic adaptation to glutamine mimicry and we aim to establish the biological framework for the development of new polytherapies for PDAC that are centered on the targeting of glutamine metabolism and macropinocytosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Beige adipocytes have anti-obesity and anti-diabetes actions in mice and humans. We have defined new roles for developmentally hard-wired postnatal beige adipocytes, but their source, trajectory, and functions remain incompletely understood. Uncovering the origin and dynamics of postnatal beige adipocytes and establishing their functions in normal physiology and in obesity would provide fundamental new insights into a key cellular regulator of tissue homeostasis and whole-body metabolism that could be harnessed to develop new therapies for obesity, type 2 diabetes, and associated diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative We propose a comprehensive bioengineering approach to develop a cell-based therapy to treat arthritis. By programming joint-resident cells to execute customized responses to cartilage matrix degradation, our approach instructs cells to constrain expression of therapeutic transgenes to an arthritic environment exhibiting a unique signature of disease. Our proposal investigates strategies for both ex vivo and in situ cell engineering, potentiating eventual clinical translation of this technology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research will evaluate the effectiveness and implementation of a couples shared decision-making intervention, CUPID (Couples United in HIV Prevention Informed Decisions), delivered in community and clinic settings to support women’s pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) choice and use through male partner support and shared decision-making. Through a partnership with a large demonstration project in Uganda that offers choice in biomedical HIV prevention to women, we will evaluate whether CUPID is effective in increasing PrEP uptake, persistence, and use among Ugandan women and assess implementation outcomes to determine whether it is acceptable and feasible to implement. If successful, CUPID will offer a community-based strategy for engaging male partners to support PrEP choice and improve HIV prevention among women and provide a scalable and sustainable intervention that will contribute to a more comprehensive approach to HIV prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glioblastoma (GBM), the most common primary brain tumor in adults, is a highly invasive, neurologically destructive tumor with a survival range of 12-15 months despite maximum treatment efforts. A central issue contributing to treatment failure is the heterogeneous or varied cell type composition of these tumors. This proposal will identify mechanisms that promote a mesenchymal tumor state, synonymous with therapy resistance. We will pharmacologically target this state to improve therapeutic efficacy of known agents for patients with newly diagnosed and recurrent GBM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is an essential diagnostic tool in the assessment of heart structure and function. TEE requires the use of sedation. Sedation requires specialized procedural space and skilled providers, which increases procedural cost, burdens the workflow, increases the risk to the patient, and overall limits the availability of TEE. Sedation accounts for the majority of the harm associated with TEE including cardiovascular (hypotension, arrythmia) and respiratory compromise. We are designing, building, and testing a novel trans-nasal TEE system that requires no anesthesia, which ultimately will improve safety, reduce cost, and will expand availability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Infectious endophthalmitis remains a frightening complication after eye surgeries, which often results in blindness, or in severe cases, enucleation of the eye. Unfortunately, few clinical tests can differentiate infectious endophthalmitis from non-infectious, making it challenging to identify patients which can delay proper treatment with the appropriate antimicrobial therapy to prevent vision loss. Here, we will integrate cutting-edge metabolomics technology and a machine-learning bioinformatic approach to identify vitreous metabolic signatures to aid in potential clinical diagnosis and study the pathobiology of ocular infections.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Pain is common in children presenting to the emergency department but is frequently undertreated, leading to both short- and long-term consequences. Morphine is the standard treatment for children with moderate to severe acute pain, but its use is associated with serious side effects and caregiver and clinician concerns related to opioid administration. Our research aims to demonstrate that sub-dissociative ketamine is as effective as morphine and a preferable alternative for treating acute pain in children because of its more favorable side effect profile and potential long-term benefits related to pain-related function, analgesic use/misuse, and mental and behavioral health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: NARRATIVE  During animal development, epithelial stem and progenitor cells of the salivary gland undergo a number of dynamic processes of maturation and differentiation, which require the coordinated action of cell-type specific transcription factors such as p63. We propose to use knockout mouse models and genomic tools to better elucidate the functional role of p63 and to identify crucial signaling pathways in salivary gland organogenesis and regeneration. Such studies will provide fundamental mechanistic insights into cellular processes of salivary gland during injury, repair and in diseased states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The project aims to develop methods and tools and conduct collaborative research for the integrative analysis of data generated by the Developmental Genotype-Tissue Expression (dGTEx) initiative, non-human primate (NHP) dGTEx project, existing GTEx project, and other studies. Aim 1 will develop integrative methods for mapping expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs), utilizing multi-view learning techniques for detecting various types of QTLs; Aim 2 will develop a series of multi-age-group multi-tissue/cell Mendelian randomization methods to identify risk genes in a variety of applications; and Aim 3 will conduct collaborative dGTEx data analysis and develop software. We will leverage our expertise gained from the GTEx consortium, and will collaborate with the Steering Committee to ensure the timely dissemination of rigorous dGTEx results.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The United States is an aging society where 1 in 3 healthy older adults experiences a fall every year, causing serious injuries and posing an enormous burden for the healthcare system; yet current fall prevention programs such as conventional balance training fail to reduce fall incidence, potentially due to their lack of task-specificity for acquiring fall resisting skills to recover from environmental falls. Over the past two decades, our work has established that repeated exposure to slip and trips in a safe environment can prevent falls up to 1 year after such training; however, such interventions are expensive, require complex technology, and are not readily scalable to clinics and community living facilities. In this study, we will provide cost-effective, safe and easy to translate task-specific balance exercises consisting of functional tasks and predictable perturbations targeted to reduce real-life falls.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: GRADUATE SCHOOL OF PUBLIC HEALTH AND HEALTH POLICY
PHR: Project Narrative The human microbiome is implicated in the development and response to treatment of some cancers, including infectious agents estimated to be responsible for ~20% of the global cancer burden. However, previously unrecognized bacterial and viral strains, as well as loss of normal structure and function of human-associated microbiomes, likely play additional roles in disease etiology and treatment. This project investigates the role of the human microbiome in cancer by applying novel and state-of-the-art methods to published metagenomic data, and provides enhanced, expanded, and more efficiently usable microbiome data resources back to the cancer research community for a broad range of investigations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Methods that allow scientists to engineer mammalian cells to execute desired cellular functions in response to defined biological and chemical signals offer tremendous potential for biomedical research and for creating next- generation cell-based biotechnologies and therapeutics. However, existing tools face significant limitations – for example, they do not offer clinically-suitable compositions, robust activity, and easy implementation across biomedically-relevant human cell types. To address these limitations, we propose to develop advanced synthetic biology tools to control gene regulation and cell function, and to apply these tools to engineer a variety of clinically-relevant human immune cell types, with broad applicability including potential therapeutic applications for cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recent studies have shown that mRNA can be dynamically regulated on specific adenosine residues to form N6-methyladenosine (m6A), an “epitranscriptomic” mark that occurs on a subset of mRNAs. m6A appears to be particularly important in cancer, where it controls diverse processes including cell fate and differentiation. With the development of novel inhibitors that target this pathway, we will uncover new dependencies to this program and characterize a new epitranscriptomic methylation mark on an adenosine residue in the mRNA encoding MYC, a key protein involved in cancer progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Residual cancer cells that survive therapy in early-stage breast cancer patients have the ability to survive in a dormant state following treatment and linger unrecognized for decades before resuming growth and re- emerging as lethal recurrent disease. Since recurrent breast cancers are typically incurable and arise from the reservoir of residual tumor cells that survive therapy, understanding the biology of minimal residual disease and elucidating the molecular pathways that contribute to tumor dormancy and recurrence is a critical priority in breast cancer research. This application is focused on that goal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Narrative: Duchene muscular dystrophy is caused by mutations in the gene for dystrophin, which is highly expressed in muscle tissue, but also found at inhibitory synapses in the brain. The function of dystrophin in the brain is still unclear. This project will demonstrate that dystrophin, and the protein complex it belongs to, are necessary for maturation of inhibitory synapses. Understanding the function of dystrophin in synaptic function is critical to developing future therapies for cognitive deficits associated with muscular dystrophy and other neurodevelopmental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While the maintenance of cartilage health is critical for functional mobility, cartilage degradation, or osteoarthritis, is a common disease in older individuals. In this project, we will mechanistically interrogate the direct role of soluble and physical microenvironmental factors on the loss of cartilage integrity with aging and according to sex. We anticipate that the innovative research studies proposed will aid in the development of effective interventions that consider sex- and gender-specific variables for the treatment of osteoarthritis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: R21 Project Narrative Alzheimer Disease (AD) is a serious neurodegenerative disorder for which there are no known current therapies. In order to make strides in diagnosis and therapy of AD we need to identify biomarkers that discriminate between AD and other neurodegenerative disorders, assess the progression of the disease and design clinical trials for early prevention or therapy. Our project aims to identify biomarkers for differential diagnosis, assessment of progression and severity of AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a progressive neurodegenerative disease currently affecting 5.8 million Americans 65 or older and is associated with cognitive decline, neuroinflammation, and changes in the gut microbiome. To address the present limitations in our understanding of the factors contributing to AD, we aim to characterize the role of the commensal gut microbiome in both protecting individuals from AD and increasing disease risk by shaping the adaptive immune system. Our goal is that this work will both help to provide greater mechanistic understanding for the causes of AD and to identify key bacterial species which prevent the pathogenesis of AD to provide key targets for intervention and prevent or slow AD progression.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative Three sentences   With a collaborative approach grounded in Indigenous core cultural values, the Indigenous Innovators Collaborative (IIC) team will engage in community-based participatory research study to address the FDA priorities as outlined in FDA OMHHE Health Equity Innovation Award: Racial and Ethnic Minority Acceleration Consortium for Health Equity (REACH) funding opportunity. The IIC seeks to engage American Indian and Alaska Native (AIAN) communities, stakeholders, researchers in an exploration of clinical trials and promote cultural knowledge in understanding clinical trials in Indian Country. One of the fundamental goals of this study is to aid in identifying perceptions of clinical trials and gene therapy within the Native American population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The cerebellum is a critical structure for appropriate voluntary movements and is increasingly associated with element of higher cognitive function through connections with the frontal cortex. The proposed research will provide insight into the molecular regulation by which cerebellar granule cells—the most numerous neuron type in the brain—are generated. Elucidating the basic mechanisms that regulate the genesis of granule cells will provide critical insights into both developmental brain disorders and cancers arising from this lineage.

PHR: Pregnancy poses unique barriers to PrEP use, yet PrEP research among pregnant and postpartum women lags behind other populations. There is an urgent need for strategies with dual benefits for HIV and sexually transmitted infections (STIs) that enhance PrEP use in pregnancy and postpartum while scaling novel PrEP options. Our proposal is designed to fill knowledge gaps regarding co-delivery of STI testing and expanded PrEP options in antenatal care with the overall goal to improve PrEP use among pregnant and postpartum women in HIV priority settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The second messenger cyclic-di-AMP is essential for viability or virulence in most Gram-positive bacteria, including Staphylococcus aureus, Listeria monocytogenes, Mycobacterium tuberculosis, and Bacillus anthracis. This grant aims to elucidate the mechanisms by which bacteria sense external stimuli and modulate the pools of this cyclic nucleotide in response. My findings have the potential to inform the development of drugs that could alter cyclic-di-AMP levels and re-sensitize drug-resistant bacteria to frontline antibiotics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Debilitating conditions such as Lewy body dementias (LBDs) belong to a spectrum of disorders that currently have no available disease modifying therapies. Recent studies point to the role of dysregulated lipid metabolism in LBDs, and developments in imaging mass methods enable the in situ analyses of lipid species in mouse brain tissue samples. The present study uses matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization imaging mass spectrometry (MALDI-IMS), for direct anatomical analysis of lipid alterations as a function of time in brain sections from preclinical models of LBD, to determine lipid profiles from disease, non-disease controls, and animals treated with immunotherapy, which restores lipid homeostasis, to draw robust conclusions about lipid alterations in the course of LBD and after application of therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the cell, many different cargos must be transported with spatial and temporal precision, and defects in intracellular transport are prevalent in many neurological disorders. There is an incredible diversity of cellular transport behavior and modalities in nature—how do different cells transport cargo, and how do they adapt the transport machinery for their specific needs? This proposal will investigate the evolution of different modes of cargo transport.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mapping the structure and function of neural circuits is an important prerequisite to understand how groups of interconnected neurons produce perceptions and drive behavior. Here, we will use molecular design and in vivo work in Drosophila to develop and test a new method to re-engineer the connectivity of brain circuits, by preventing the formation of specific synapses between neurons. Our strategies are in principle applicable to any genetic system and will enable scientists to design new experiments and interventions not possible with existing techniques.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative As PrEP delivery methods change, decision making about how best to use PrEP and the pros and cons to each is important, especially for young trans women ages 15-24 who are less likely to use PrEP and have significant barriers to advocating for their wishes in a healthcare setting. Decision support tools designed to consider and address specific concerns and information gaps young trans women have related to PrEP and its delivery methods could support better informed decisions and empower them to try PrEP. We will develop and pilot test the web-based QUEEN-P decision support tool in young trans women to assess acceptability, feasibility and promise of efficacy in supporting informed decisions around PrEP and clarifying values in method delivery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The purpose of this proposal is to develop gene-edited (CD52-knockout) virus-specific T cells, and to determine the impact of gene editing on antiviral activity as well as off-target effects of CRISPR editing. Using a mouse model, we will test the efficacy and safety of CD52-KO virus-specific T cells. Completion of this study will develop a novel cellular therapy product that can be used in the presence of alemtuzumab, and additionally produce a pipeline for development of next-generation, gene-modified virus-specific T cells to more effectively treat immunocompromised patients who are at risk of severe viral infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tumor-Associated Macrophages (TAMs) constitute a metabolically and functionally heterogeneous cell population of the tumor microenvironment (TME) that play critical roles in tumor growth as well as in anti-tumor immune responses. Nearly 40 years ago, it was demonstrated that inhibition of the mitochondrial electron transport chain (ETC) is critical for the anti-tumor activity of macrophages; however, the mechanisms by which the activity of the ETC is controlled in TAMs and how this process determines the functions of these innate immune cells within the TME is largely unknown. Therefore, the overarching goal of this proposal is to mechanistically uncover how a small peptide and a microRNA encoded by a single transcript act as an evolutionarily conserved immune checkpoint that determines the functional differentiation of TAMs in response to specific signals within the TME through the regulation of Complex IV of the ETC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative:  High-end electron microscopy and cryo-electron tomography are highly specialized and expensive technologies. To pool expertise and high-end equipment, the creation of hub-like service centers, open to the scientific community, has been propagated since several years. Here we propose to form a service unit that is integrated in a wider network, acting together for the benefit of the EM community in a similar fashion as synchrotrons are for X-ray protein crystallography projects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Modified Public Health Relevance Section We propose to establish the Midwest Center for Cryo-Electron Tomography (MCCET) at the University of Wisconsin, Madison, a National Service Network Hub for Cryo-Electron Tomography. The MCCET will provide national and international access to state-of-the-art equipment and well-trained technical staff to support the growing need for cryo-ET of biomedically-relevant specimens from isolated macromolecules to tissue from organisms. The MCCET will enable researchers, inside and outside of the national network of service centers, to prepare specimens suitable for on-site cryo-ET data acquisition and data processing, and to train and cross-train in a broad-range of cryo-ET workflows.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Statement We propose to establish the Stanford-SLAC CryoET Specimen Preparation Service Center (SCSC) to meet the emerging national need for cryoET as a structural biology tool. The Center facility will enable external users to streamline the preparation of samples through providing access to, and support for, advanced cryo-specimen preparation techniques (cryoFLM, cryoFIB, and cryoEM/ET) for a wide range of samples with biomedical applications. The Center will offer a comprehensive program to train and cross-train scientists, regardless of their institutional affiliations, to become independent cryoET investigators.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This study will elucidate sex- and gender-related mechanisms of the disparity in vaso-occlusive pain between females and males with sickle cell disease and test the clinical and biomarker effects of menstrual cycle suppression with depot medroxyprogesterone acetate, a hormonal contraceptive. Because sickle cell disease affects millions of people worldwide, and vaso-occlusive episodes present a public health burden in the United States and abroad, new strategies for pain prevention that emerge from this research will have a significant impact on patient morbidity and health care costs. We seek to fulfill NHLBI and NIH Women’s Health Research objectives to identify sex and gender influences in disease outcomes in order to better target interventions and ultimately close this important clinical gap in sickle cell disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: BENAROYA RESEARCH INST AT VIRGINIA MASON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genetic variation in the human population contributes to inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) risk, but the mechanisms that drive genetic risk are unknown. Here, we use cutting-edge high-throughput methods to pinpoint causal genetic variants associated with IBD and define the genes and pathways they impact. We will accomplish this in primary pathogenic Th17 cells, a key IBD-relevant cell type, to how risk variants affect their gene expression, migration, and function.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative  The study advances the priorities of the NIH-wide IMPROVE initiative, by building skills to address IPV as a preventable cause of maternal death and poor health before, during, and after delivery, and disparities therein (e.g. race/ethnicity, life course stages, and social standing). Results will accelerate the quality and impact of clinical and intervention-related IPV research for populations in greatest need, contributing to our national ability to ensure women’s health and safety and promote health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative There is high unmet need for PrEP among cis-gender women in the U.S. and, even where PrEP is available, it is often inaccessible to women because too few clinical settings provide it. We address this important adoption gap by integrating PrEP decision-making and delivery into contraceptive counseling in sexual and reproductive health clinic settings, which supports women’s choice. Guided by the Health Equity Implementation Framework and sustained input from a Community Advisory Board, we will randomize patients in these settings to receive an expanded PrEP decision aid vs. generic PrEP information, evaluating clinical and implementation outcomes important for understanding scalability and sustainability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Because current care delivery strategies for HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) do not adequately address the unique needs and priorities of Black and Latinx sexual minority men (BLSMM), use remains low. In collaboration with a diverse group of stakeholders, we will use system dynamics group model building to identify and model strategies likely to address barriers to PrEP access and use, and then pilot test the most promising strategies. By enhancing PrEP uptake, this study has the potential to reduce HIV transmission and improve the health of BLSMM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will address sex disparities in obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) severity that contribute to women being underdiagnosed with OSA compared to men. We will characterize OSA severity beyond conventional metrics such as the apnea-hypopnea index (AHI) and leverage sex differences in night-to-night variability in sleep and respiratory physiology to assess its temporal relationships with measures of ecological momentary assessments to improve how we define OSA severity for both women and men. We expect to identify sleep and respiratory traits that have biologically plausible effects on daytime function, to determine the role of sex on these associations, and thus to potentially challenge the current paradigm that the AHI defines OSA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s tau pathology follows a predictable path through the brain, starting in a small brainstem nucleus  called the locus coeruleus decades before any diagnosis. In this project, we test whether daily slow-paced  breathing sessions can promote a healthy pattern of locus coeruleus activity in Black and White adults ages  50-70.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The association of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) with the scaffold protein osteopontin (OPN) is strong and consistent, but without considering the isoform variants of OPN, studies fail to fully elucidate their critical function in IPF promotion. This proposal will investigate the mechanism of intracellular OPN’s induction of fibrosis and its role in Trained Immunity, an innate memory program that may represent an immunological mechanism of IPF progression. This work will define a novel mechanistic understanding of OPN in IPF initiation and progression and has the potential to elucidate targeted therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Neuropsychiatric symptoms (NPS) frequently occur in individuals with Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and related dementias, causing significant distress to both patients and caregivers and often leading to early institutionalization. In this project, we will characterize pathological and molecular/cellular changes associated with NPS-like disturbances by utilizing well-established mouse AD models, and determine the potential underlying neural mechanisms. We hope that this project will generate new understanding of the relatively understudied neuropsychiatric impairments in AD, and can provide help for developing novel strategies for patient care and therapeutic approaches to mitigate deleterious impacts of NPS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: The goal of this project is to develop a scalable digital program to train behavioral addiction professionals (counselors) to high-fidelity levels in Community Reinforcement and Family Training (CRAFT) with the ultimate goal of increasing opioid use disorder (OUD) treatment entry rates. On average 68% of families coached in CRAFT achieve treatment entry for a loved one with OUD and this could help over 2 million Americans recover from OUD with effective treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cystic fibrosis (CF) is characterized by thickened respiratory secretions, recurrent airway infection and neutrophilic inflammation resulting in progressive lung function decline; females with CF experience more pulmonary exacerbations and earlier mortality than males and show increased sputum inflammatory markers in association with high estrogen levels. This proposal will evaluate the effect of estrogen on neutrophil NET (neutrophil extracellular trap) release and inflammatory cytokine production and determine pathways involved using human cells, mouse models and samples from cis and transgender people with CF. The proposed research is relevant to public health because understanding how estrogen impacts neutrophilic inflammation in CF and non-CF bronchiectasis may help guide therapeutic targets, including nebulized estrogen receptor antagonists, and aims to decrease the sex disparity in CF and other chronic inflammatory respiratory diseases.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The number of Veterans living with dementia (VLWD) is expected to increase by 2030 to nearly 340,000; these Veterans and their caregivers often have complex psychosocial and health needs. Coordinating this care is complicated by the fact that most VLWD are Medicare-eligible and therefore use care both through the VA and Medicare, though dual use is often associated with duplication of services and potentially inappropriate care. In light of these complexities, a 2019 VHA directive mandated that VA facilities establish a Dementia System of Care to provide person-centered services for these VLWD. The goals of this project are to examine the links between dual use, continuity of care, and the patient-centered outcome of home time. Then, we will interview staff and VLWD-caregiver dyads at high- and low-performing VA facilities to identify dementia care delivery strategies that maximize home time. Finally, with a Stakeholder & Expert Panel that includes clinicians, researchers, and a VLWD-caregiver dyad, we will identify promising strategies for a dementia care toolkit.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The main objective of this proposal is to develop a site-specific gene editing strategy for the treatment of primary immunodeficiency caused by mutations into the tightly regulated RAG1 gene. This disease represents an ideal candidate for the new gene correction strategy because preclinical studies of Hematopoietic Stem Cells (HSC) gene therapy have already shown i) evidence of potential efficacy even with few amounts of functionally corrected cells; ii) critical safety issues due to ectopic and unregulated transgene expression from conventional integrating vectors. Here we will overcome this hurdle by exploiting nuclease mediated homologous recombination to directly fix RAG1 mutations and restore both its function and expression control, thus providing the ultimate solution for the treatment of RAG1 patients and opening new avenues for HSC gene editing based therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Optic Neuritis (ON) patients need new, effective, and well-tolerated therapies to improve treatment outcomes and reduce side effects, and for these patients, reducing aberrant lymphocyte activation with targeted drugs is a promising therapeutic strategy. Our company, Trethera, is developing a novel small-molecule drug, TRE-515, to treat ON by targeting a pathway required for lymphocyte activation. In the proposed project, we will conduct critical preclinical work to further evaluate the safety of TRE-515 as a drug for ON and to further study how TRE- 515 affects ON relevant cells and disease stages.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Transforming Growth Factor (TGF)-Beta superfamily members play a critical role in repair, remodeling and fibrosis of the infarcted heart, signaling through intracellular effectors, the Smads and through non-Smad pathways. The current proposal will investigate cell- specific actions of Smad1 cascades in the infarcted heart. In vivo experiments using cell- specific knockout mice, in vitro loss- and gain-of-function studies and single cell RNAseq experiments will be performed to study Smad1-mediated actions on fibroblasts, macrophages, cardiomyocytes and pericytes, to dissect the molecular mechanisms responsible for Smad1 effects, and to explore the role of TGF-Beta signaling responses in mediating subset-specific functions of immune and reparative cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This implementation science grant aims to understand PrEP user choices, preferences and implementation impact of the roll-out of long-acting injectable (LAI) PrEP alongside oral PrEP among women in Malawi. The design will: (1) evaluate longitudinal patterns of oral and long-acting injectable PrEP use in women in Malawi and the impact of tracing on re-engagement in PrEP care; (2) assess decision-making among injectable and oral PrEP users and providers, as well as preferences for implementation delivery and support; and (3) synthesize evidence and local inputs to design strategies for optimizing PrEP continuation and re-engagement to achieve implementation impact for women in Malawi. Findings will provide clarity around PrEP users patterns and outcomes of PrEP implementation and support the development of PrEP engagement interventions co-designed with the Community Partnership Council (CPC), Ministry of Health, implementing partners, providers, and PrEP users.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Prenatal alcohol exposure (PAE) causes growth deficits in the offspring; these deficits predict the severity of the accompanying behavioral deficits, and mechanism underlying this impaired growth is unclear. Using a mouse model of FASD, this proposal tests the hypothesis that these growth deficits are driven, in part, by alcohol-mediated disruptions in maternal insulin sensitivity and signaling and reduced fetal access to glucose. An understanding of how alcohol disrupts maternal-fetal energy metabolism will inform the development of nutrition-based therapies that may improve PAE outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Intimate partner violence (IPV) is an important contributor to the HIV epidemic among women globally, and identifying and responding to women in generalized HIV epidemic settings who experience IPV is an important HIV prevention strategy. Given the high burden of both IPV and incident HIV among AGYW in South Africa, biomedical HIV prevention options that do not require participation from both partners, such as HIV antiretroviral pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP), are critical. This research aims to guide the implementation of approved PrEP modalities among IPV-exposed AGYW in South Africa, which will have important implications for biomedical HIV prevention implementation among priority populations globally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Suicide risk is increasing in preteens, 8-12 years old: in clinical samples (e.g., inpatient psychiatry), more than 40% have seriously considered suicide and nearly 20% have attempted suicide. Our knowledge of suicide risk has been limited by the paucity of developmentally appropriate tools to assess suicidal thoughts, and relevant risk factors, in preteens. The goal of this study is to adapt a developmentally and culturally appropriate measures of suicide risk for preteens (via community-engaged research) and to examine different phenotypes (i.e., presentations) of suicide risk among 150 at-risk preteens following discharge from acute psychiatric care settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROPOSED SUPPLEMENT PROJECT The proposed study addresses an important shortcoming of the parent project and a critical gap in research, examining frontal asymmetry development, operationalized as a system of reciprocal effects between left and right frontal activation across infancy20, in prediction of risk for disruptive behavior21. The contribution of conver- gence with behavioral development (i.e., approach growth corresponding with shifts towards relative left frontal activation) will be considered, along with infant emerging regulation and maternal sensitivity as moderators22,23. While the parent study provides a comprehensive examination of risk for anxiety and related internalizing symptoms, it does not address disruptive/externalizing outcomes. Yet factors considered as antecedents of anxiety symptoms are also relevant to the development of disruptive symptoms, and it may be that a trajectory of neurophysiological changes protective with respect to anxiety/internalizing symptoms accentuates external- izing symptoms, possibly depending on the inputs from regulatory capacity and caregiving. The proposed pro- ject provides an opportunity to leverage extensive infancy neurophysiological and behavioral assessments conducted in the context of the parent investigation to answer critical research questions concerning disruptive behavior problems, significantly extending the impact of obtained results. It is hypothesized that the pattern of reciprocal brain activity effects wherein dominant left frontal acti- vation (associated with approach/reward orientation) will translate into greater risk for disruptive symptoms. Specifically, we anticipate that (1) dominance of left hemisphere change effects on right activation growth across infancy will confer risk; (2) this risk will be accentuated by slower advances in child regulatory capacity and attenuated by higher maternal sensitivity across infancy. We plan to test these primary hypotheses and attain the objective of this application by pursuing two specific aims:  Aim 1. Modeling frontal EEG changes as predictors as of emerging disruptive symptoms/disorders. Bimonthly assessments of infant EEG, temperament and maternal sensitivity from 6 to 18 months will be con- sidered in predicting previously omitted disruptive symptoms and disorders (e.g., Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder, Oppositional Defiant Disorder). Assessments begin at 2 months of age measuring covariates: infant birth/medical (e.g., gestational age/weight, APGAR score), family demographic factors, and maternal depres- sion/anxiety. Infant EEG asymmetry markers (i.e., frontal alpha power values), temperament, and maternal sensitivity are evaluated bimonthly starting at 6 months. Laboratory observations provide measures of maternal sensitivity with parent-report used to assess infant temperament, specifically regulatory capacity. Mothers with infants (n=300) recruited at three sites: Pullman, WA, Blacksburg, VA, and Jupiter, FL in the context of the par- ent R01 funded investigation will be asked to contribute data to the proposed study. Specifically, all 300 care- givers will participate in clinical interviews, this time to ascertain severity of externalizing/disruptive problems, also providing responses to related questionnaires. Children will be followed, conducting semi-structured clini- cal interviews with mothers addressing disruptive starting at 24 months. It is hypothesized that greater base- line left frontal activation and stronger left frontal EEG effects across infancy (i.e., left hemisphere dy- namic effects driving change in right activation) would contribute to more severe/frequent disruptive behaviors and increased risk for symptoms/disorders8,24.  Aim 2. Moderation by temperament and caregiving: Child regulatory capacity and maternal sensitivity. We will determine moderating effects of child regulatory capacity and maternal sensitivity on links between EEG markers and disruptive symptoms/disorders. Sensitive caregiving is examined in the parent project and the proposed study provides an opportunity to discover if protective mechanisms are similar for externalizing and internalizing symptoms. Child self-regulation was not considered as a moderator in the parent investiga- tion, yet has been widely demonstrated as protective25,26 and will be examined herein with respect to disruptive problems. Latent changes in child EEG – dominant left hemisphere effects on right frontal activation are expected to confer risk with respect to disruptive behaviors, accentuated by slower advances in atten- tion-based regulation from 6 to 18 months and attenuated by higher levels of maternal sensitivity. Be- cause maternal sensitivity is assessed every two months, we will be able to identify specific develop- mental periods associated with reliable protective effects. This dynamic approach pioneered in the parent study will now be aimed at elucidating risk vs. protection with respect to early disruptive problems and is ex- pected to transform etiology-oriented research in developmental psychopathology. This study will clarify the role of changes in neurophysiology in the emergence of disruptive symptoms8,27, informing preventative efforts by providing potential therapeutic targets. The proposed study will provide currently lacking information related to accentuated risk for disruptive symptoms/disorders as a function of infant neurophysiology and tempera- ment, which can be applied in screening efforts, with malleable periods identified. Importantly, this study prom- ises to specify periods wherein maternal sensitivity can be modified to provide increased protection with re- spect to disruptive behaviors26,28. Identifying these markers is expected to translate into low-cost preventive approaches, in lieu of more intensive services later in childhood29.
