IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) affects millions of people, especially older individuals and postmenopausal women. Cardiac and limb muscle abnormalities are a significant problem in HFpEF patients because it contributes to morbidity and mortality. Our goal is to test whether a compound with antioxidant properties restores exercise tolerance and cardiac and limb muscle function in a rodent model of HFpEF relevant for postmenopausal women.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Dr. Bell is requesting renewal of his SRCS for an additional 5 years. During these 5 years he plans to continue to vigorously pursue his research, education, administrative and service mission. Dr. Bell has an international reputation in psychiatric rehabilitation and has been funded by VA RR&D, VA HSR&D, DoD, NIMH, NIDA, NIAAA and NSF. Renewal will allow him to continue his research in 1) vocational rehabilitation, 2) neurocognitive and social cognitive deficits and their relationships to functional impairments, 3) development of assessment instruments, 4) cognitive remediation, and 5) substance abuse rehabilitation. These research activities meet priority healthcare needs for Veterans. Dr. Bell plans to continue his mentorship to train the next generation of clinical researchers, to continue to provide administrative support to the VA research mission by chairing the Human Studies Subcommittee and by serving on VA RR&D review groups, and to continue to directly serve Veterans as Director of an outreach program to Veterans on area college campuses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  During the last ten years, it has become apparent that deregulation or disruption of proteins residing at the Intercalated Disk (ICD), the unique membrane microdomain that mediates the mechanical and electrical coupling of cardiomyocytes, leads to cardiac defects and development of severe or lethal cardiomyopathies. The proposed studies will provide important and novel information about the modulation of a major component of the ICD, N-cadherin, via the enzymatic activity of the obscurin Ser/Thr kinase domain 1. Elucidating the molecular mechanisms that underlie cell-cell adhesion and communication in cardiac muscle during normalcy will allow us to understand how these are altered or compromised during congenital heart disease, and thus enable us to develop new, effective, and targeted therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Original Project Narrative The U.S. and other countries around the world are facing “dual crises of pain and opioid addiction.” Lohocla Research Corporation has responded to the opioid crisis and medication development challenge by designing, synthesizing and demonstrating, in pre-clinical studies, the efficacy and safety of a non-opiate, non-addictive new chemical entity for treatment of chronic pain. This new chemical entity, called Kindolor, has significant additional benefits of being able to prevent the development of chronic pain if administered soon after tissue injury, including post-operative conditions. Kindolor also has a highly significant “opiate sparing” effect in conditions that may require the use of opiates, since Kindolor demonstrates a strong synergistic effect with morphine. In this grant application we are requesting funds to complete cGMP synthesis and GLP studies necessary for an IND application to the FDA, and given the FDA approval of the IND status, the completion of the first in human, Phase I clinical studies for safety and Phase 2a studies of efficacy to bring our medication to chronic pain sufferers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE Immune dysregulation and inflammation are common features of endometriosis, a benign gynecologic condition that can cause chronic pain, infertility, and myriad other symptoms. Endometriosis commonly co- occurs with inflammatory conditions, but the links between these traits are poorly understood. This proposal comprises two complementary aims that will use human population genetics methods, single cell and spatial genomics, in vitro organoid models and a bioluminescent murine model of endometriosis to identify novel therapeutic opportunities by studying the genes and pathways that link endometriosis and inflammation.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: Suicide and suicide attempts among U.S. Veterans remain a serious concern, as more than 6,000 Veterans die by suicide every year and many more attempt suicide. Current VHA suicide prediction models do not incorporate the rich information relevant to suicide from clinical progress notes. The proposed study will use natural language processing to make this information available for suicide prediction models. The study sets itself apart from other studies in this area by employing the state-of-the-art 3-step Theory of Suicide, which aims to distinguish high-risk Veterans who will attempt suicide from high-risk Veterans who will not attempt suicide. Enhancing VHA's ability to identify Veterans who are most likely to attempt suicide ensures that limited intervention resources can focus on Veterans with the highest needs, before they attempt suicide or die by suicide. The proposed study is well-aligned with priorities for HSR&D research and with VA strategic goals for 2018 – 2024 set out by VA leadership, who listed suicide prevention as “VA's highest clinical priority.”

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Interleukin-1B (IL-1B) has shown conflicting roles in tumor growth and tumor immune rejection across animal models and human clinical trials. Determining when and how regulatory T cells (Tregs) use the decoy receptor IL-1R2 to regulate IL-1B signaling will reveal fundamental information about tumor Treg function and their suppression of other immune cells. IL-1R2 may also serve as a novel therapeutic target for human cancers by selectively depleting tumor Tregs and bolstering tumor immune rejection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Altered nutrient availability between tumors and healthy tissues drive differences in the metabolic dependencies of cells in these environments; these differences may be leveraged to control tumor growth in the clinic. Here we identify suppressed pyruvate oxidation is a critical metabolic adaptation of pancreatic cancer cells grown under tumor nutrient stress. Clinically relevant compounds that disrupt the regulation of pyruvate oxidation are already available, and thus the findings of this project have the potential for rapid clinical translation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Spinal cord injury is a severely debilitating event that profoundly impacts quality of life, yet there are limited effective treatment options for the patient beyond rehabilitation. The proposed research will determine how removal of the adhesion receptor, L-selectin, affects the behavior of the most abundant immune cell type (neutrophils) in the acutely injured spinal cord and subsequent long-term recovery. This work will elucidate the role of neutrophils in acute tissue damage, determine how L-selectin regulates neutrophil behavior, and advance a novel therapeutic strategy that enhances L-selectin removal from the surface of neutrophils.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative When someone suffers a severe brain injury, a portion of the skull must be removed so that the brain can swell. Unfortunately, a second surgery is required to replace that missing piece of the skull, and the patient can experience neurological problems up until the day that missing bone is replaced. In a rat model, we believe that placing our new flexible material during the first surgery that can later turn into bone will still allow the brain to swell initially, while avoiding the second surgery and the neurological problems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PI: Kurshan, Peri T. Project Narrative  Mutations in synaptic cell-adhesion molecules such as neurexins are highly associated with neurodevelopmental and neuropsychiatric disorders and often lead to defects in synapse formation, although the molecular mechanisms by which this occurs are still largely unknown. In this proposal, we seek to understand the cell-intrinsic mechanisms by which presynaptic cell-adhesion molecules including neurexin are localized to synapses and contribute to their maturation. As a result, this research will have the potential to reveal novel therapeutic approaches to target diseases associated with defects in this critical class of synaptic proteins.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Untreated peripheral nerve damage results in a tangled mass of disorganized nerve fibers and blocks functional recovery following nerve injury. While significant advances in understanding the molecular mechanisms governing the repair process have been made in recent years, the clinical results of peripheral nerve repair remain disappointing. This proposal seeks to improve nerve repair by mimicking endogenous cues using topographical guidance and concentration gradients of ECM-peptides and growth factors.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aberrant behaviors of neural stem and progenitor cells (NSPC) during brain development can lead to cortical malformations, such as microcephaly and macrocephaly, as well as various neurodevelopmental disorders. Knowledge about precise control of NSPC behaviors is essential to dissecting the underlying pathogenic mechanisms. Our proposed studies will provide novel insights to how a selective RNA decay mechanism can influence NSPC behaviors and to the etiology of microcephaly.

ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding the regenerative response of the nervous system in models that naturally regenerate is integral to the development of potential therapies for traumatic brain injury and stroke. The proposed studies in the zebrafish seek to investigate the mechanisms through which meningeal lymphatics contribute to adult neurogenesis and regeneration of the nervous system by regulating the immune response and composition of cerebral spinal fluid. Through these studies we will gain novel insights into the mechanisms that underpin the relationship between the lymphatic system and promoting the regenerative response of the central nervous system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Synapses are the primary substrates driving information transfer throughout our nervous system. Defects in synaptic communication are associated with a vast number of neurological, neurodegenerative, and neuropsychiatric diseases including epilepsy, autism, schizophrenia, ALS, and Alzheimer’s Disease. While their importance is undeniable, the mechanisms that establish and modulate the diversity of synaptic strength remain enigmatic. This proposal seeks to reveal fundamental insights into what determines and adaptively modifies the diversity of presynaptic function at glutamatergic synapses in development and plasticity. Ultimately, this knowledge is necessary to understand the etiology of neural diseases resulting from synaptic dysfunction and develop effective therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE JC polyomavirus (JCPyV), a prevalent human-only pathogen, causes life-threatening brain diseases in immunologically compromised individuals. The list of immunotherapeutic and chemotherapeutic agents linked to JCPyV CNS diseases is rapidly expanding; no anti-JCPyV agents are available. Using a mouse virus in the same family as JCPyV, we developed a tractable animal model to explore early stages in the pathogenesis of polyomavirus brain infections that precede development of irreversible lesions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative – Overall Acute intoxication with organophosphate (OP) pesticides or nerve agents can trigger seizures that rapidly progress to life-threatening status epilepticus, and survivors often experience significant long-term morbidity, including progressive brain injury, spontaneous recurrent seizures, and cognitive impairment. Current medical countermeasures for acute OP intoxication can prevent death, but are unable to fully protect against the long- term adverse neurological consequences unless administered within minutes of exposure, which is an unlikely scenario in the event of accidental, suicidal or terrorist-related exposures. The UC Davis CounterACT Center of Excellence seeks to identify and develop novel disease-modifying therapeutic strategies that can be administered in hours to months after exposure to delay the onset and/or reduce the severity of chronic neurotoxic effects.

PHR: Project Narrative The 2024 Alcohol and the Nervous System Gordon Research Conference and the associated Gordon Research Seminar will provide a unique forum that brings together a diverse range of young and established alcohol researchers to discuss groundbreaking advances in alcohol neuroscience research. The innovative GRC format will promote discussions and focus on building bridges in neuroscience research between preclinical and clinical researchers, and foster a community of the next generation of alcohol researchers. The goal of this conference is to stimulate cutting edge research in the field and contribute to the advancement of alcohol research across multiple domains.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The global objective of this proposal is to investigate the tissue-specific causative role of aberrant mitochondrial Ca2+ uptake in skeletal muscle and motor neuron in Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) pathogenesis. Specifically, we will determine the impact of aberrant mitochondrial Ca2+ uptake in skeletal muscle and/or motor neuron on the survival, motor neuron loss, exercise performance, muscle force generation, neuromuscular junction structure/function, and intracellular Ca2+ release properties and mitochondrial function in skeletal muscle fibers, at different stage of disease progression in two established mouse models of ALS. Results from this project will provide pre-clinical evidence needed to determine whether excessive mitochondrial Ca2+ uptake in skeletal muscle and motor neuron is a viable therapeutic target for ALS treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The cerebellum is a structure that is critical for control of movements. However, activities of cerebellar neurons are often difficult to interpret in terms of behavior. Here, we propose new algorithms and experimental procedures that will significantly improve the ability to tackle the question of neural population coding in the cerebellum, ultimately producing a better understanding of how the cerebellum learns to precisely control movements.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  The manner in which the brain responds to cumulative traumatic brain injuries (TBIs) and leads to neurological dysfunction is unknown. Our approach permits inter-injury in vivo microscopy to observe injury- induced change in blood flow and blood-brain barrier permeability, while recording post-traumatic sleep, as predictors of subacute neurological function. New insights to cumulative pathophysiology after TBI can inform clinical management and studies to reduce damage and accelerate recovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The BRAIN initiative has enabled the development of approaches for modulating specific microcircuits through genetically targeting discrete types of neurons; however, their application to disease models is lagging. In this collaboration between Huntington’s disease (HD) researchers and BRAIN tool developers we will utilize novel interventional tools for changing neural circuit dynamics at the early, pre-symptomatic stage for preventing or delaying and mitigating the behavioral deficits in a transgenic mouse model of HD. Our project will drive translational progress toward potential novel therapeutic purposes for HD as well as other neurodegenerative diseases that show circuit imbalances, while at the same time addressing basic questions of neural circuit function underlying behavior relevant to both NINDS and NIMH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) is one of the most prevalent and devastating neurodegenerative diseases in the modern era, impacting millions of people worldwide and with incidence projected to triple as the population continues to age. Underlying the many processes that may contribute to Alzheimer’s are two potential factors: dysfunctional cerebral blood flow and inflammation. The goal of this study is the preclinical assessment of our novel small molecule inhibitors of NADPH Oxidase 2, an oxidant generating protein known to be involved in both processes, as a potential therapeutic option in AD mouse models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Successful control of chronic viruses, such as HIV and HCV, greatly depends on vigorous and well-coordinated CD4+ and CD8+ T cell responses. This study aims to identify cellular and molecular mechanisms, as well as rational designs of therapeutics, that favor the formation and function of effector CD8+ T cells and overcome T cell exhaustion to treat chronic infection and cancer.

ORG_NAME: LUNDQUIST INSTITUTE FOR BIOMEDICAL INNOVATION AT HARBOR-UCLA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal aims to investigate immunoglobulin E overproduction by the sensitization and reflex augmentation of sensory neurons and efferent autonomic nervous system activation. The proposed research is relevant to public health because a better understanding of the complete neuro-immune landscape and its dysregulation with fungal asthma will increase understanding of fundamental mechanisms involved in allergic/asthmatic pathology, of which immunoglobulin E is at its core. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission that pertains to developing fundamental knowledge that will help reduce the burdens of human disability.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Antibiotic-resistant bacteria are a major public health concern. These bacteria cause infections that are often difficult to treat and lead to serious infections. Carbapenem-resistant Enterobacteriaceae (CRE) is a severe type of antibiotic-resistant bacteria because it is resistant to almost all antibiotics and can be very deadly. It is very important to identify which patients are at risk for CRE and to identify the best treatment for CRE. We propose to develop and test a tool that predicts whether a person carries CRE, and to identify the best treatment options for CRE infections. We will use large databases to find patients at risk for CRE and patient who have CRE infections. We will use computer programming and biostatistics to identify which patients are at risk and which treatments work best. At the end of the proposed work, we will have identified new avenues to prevent person-to-person transmission of CRE and improve therapy of CRE infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (from parent R35) Innate immune systems provide critical defenses against microbial infections and are composed of both ancient and newly evolved proteins. To understand where our immune pathways came from and how they integrate new components, we study antibacterial responses in eukaryotes found across the Tree of Life. These diverse immune systems promise to yield new antimicrobials and to reveal how innate immune defenses can change over evolutionary time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project is relevant to public health because memory deficits occur in many psychiatric and neurological disorders and are common as a result of early life adversity. Identifying the neurophysiological mechanisms of memory retrieval in the developing brain will inform the design of effective interventions for alleviating memory impairment in children and thus have a positive impact on life-long wellbeing. Further, this project will pave the way to designing clinical tools to map memory in the developing brain that will influence diagnostic and therapeutic surgical approaches and ultimately improve quality of life in patients with drug- resistant focal epilepsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal is clinically important by focusing on neurobiological mechanisms that underlie anxiety in the early stages of Alzheimer disease (AD). By examining the impact of AD on the neural circuitry of anxiety at multiple levels, this work will provide knowledge that could lead to novel therapies to treat anxiety in human AD patients. As anxiety has been associated with faster decline, such treatments may also have an impact to slow the progression of AD itself.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE An unexamined yet promising pathway through which insomnia may promote cardiovascular disease (CVD) is unhealthy eating behaviors such as emotional eating, external eating, restrained eating, poor diet quality, and night eating. This ancillary study to the SHADES mechanistic trial will examine whether unhealthy eating behaviors explain the links between sleep metrics reflecting poor sleep and biomarkers reflecting elevated CVD risk. This study could identify novel targets (specific unhealthy eating behaviors) for future interventions designed to lower the CVD risk in people with insomnia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer's Disease (AD) is rapidly transforming into a significant economic and social challenge. This proposal will develop and apply advanced AI models to study Alzheimer’s Disease, including the effects of race, comorbidity, and social determinant of health on Alzheimer’s Disease as well as identifying cerebrospinal fluid proteins that are predictive of cognitive decline. Successful completion of this study will provide improved and fair AI models that can be further developed into effective clinical decision support tools as well as enhance our understanding of the pathophysiology of AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Alzheimer disease (AD) is a complex neurodegenerative disease. We will develop computational methods to identify dysregulated communications among AD related cell types by analyzing single-cell data from AD postmortem brains, and validate the findings in human iPSC- derived cortical organoids.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Tau is a protein that can aggregate in the brain and is associated with many neurodegenerative diseases. Reducing the amount of tau protein may prove to be beneficial in the context of neurodegenerative diseases. To aid in developing drugs targeting tau levels, the proposed study will investigate which transcription factors control the expression of the MAPT gene, which codes for tau.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Population-wide genomic screening (PGS) for Hereditary Breast and Ovarian Cancer Syndrome, Lynch Syndrome, and Familial Hypercholesterolemia offers the best chance of identifying the nearly two million people in the US who have these conditions and need tailored disease prevention and clinical management. This project will use an Implementation Mapping approach to conduct a needs assessment of ten PGS programs (Aim 1), develop and produce a multicomponent implementation guide (FOCUS toolkit) to facilitate the implementation of PGS programs (Aim 2), and evaluate the FOCUS toolkit using a hybrid stepped wedge cluster randomized trial among 12 sites at various stages of implementing PGS (Aim 3). These findings will provide a standardized approach for programs seeking to strategically implement PGS and support efforts to bring the promise of precision health to all.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This study is significant for public health as it investigates the potential link between poor oral health and incident dementia, specifically Alzheimer’s disease and vascular dementia. Understanding the underlying biological mechanisms and social determinants in these relationships could reveal new strategies for preventing or delaying dementia onset. The study's findings could lead to improved public health policies and clinical practices, emphasizing oral health as a key component in maintaining cognitive health, especially among the increasing aging population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: TEXAS TECH UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIS CENTER
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT (PROJECT NARRATIVE) The brain extracellular matrix (ECM) plays critical roles in synaptic function remodeling its structure to enable plasticity. We propose to determine if an amyloid-based mechanism, including cystatin-related epididymal spermatogenic (CRES) subgroup amyloids, is integral for the remodeling process allowing sex-specific adaptive changes in a seconds to minutes timescale. Our studies will benefit the neuroscience community broadly by identifying new structural elements in the brain ECM and suggesting novel mechanisms for adaptive functions.

PHR: Project Narrative: The Overall National Construction Center (Center) is comprised of the Planning, Administration and Evaluation (PAE) Core, which manages and coordinates all Center research projects and activities, and four operating cores, Data Core, r2p Core, Communications (COE) Core and Applied Research Core. Each of these core functions, in addition to the nine research projects housed within the Applied Research Core, respond to NORA 3 Construction Sector priorities, NIOSH strategic goals, and the 2018 NIOSH Construction Expert Panel Review. All findings from these projects and activities will be shared broadly through our extensive network of industry partnerships and outreach channels housed within the r2p Core and COE Core.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Recent studies have substantiated role of Eph receptors for the dysfunction of the BBB, as reported in the process of invasion of pathogenic organisms and the early stages of Alzheimer’s (AD) and other neurodegenerative diseases. Yet, the molecular mechanisms regulating Eph receptor function remain poorly understood. To gain insight into the mechanisms of Eph proteins at the molecular level we aim to identify key residues for domain-domain and domain-membrane interactions and configurational changes, primarily in EphA1 and A2, but also in EphA4, B2. The insights obtained will help the eventual development of diagnostic and therapeutic agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding how specific neurons in a selectively vulnerable region such as the entorhinal cortex are affected is critical to unraveling the mechanisms underlying Alzheimer's disease onset. Using in-vivo single-unit electrophysiology recordings and optogenetics we will identify if excitatory neurons or inhibitory neurons or both are more vulnerable to Alzheimer’s disease pathologies. We will use chemogenetic approach to reduce pathology and restore neuronal function.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Reducing ableist discrimination against people with disabilities is one of the most pressing issues faced by the US organ transplant system but, due to the absence of oversight and accountability, we do not know the extent to which the ableism-induced equity gap is narrowing. This proposal will have a high public health impact by providing critical information with direct, actionable, implications for healthcare providers and legislators to further mitigate ableism against people with intellectual or developmental disabilities (IDD) in organ transplantation. This proposal is aligned with the NICHD’s Strategic Plan, as we will evaluate whether existing state laws prohibiting disability-based discrimination in organ transplantation are an “effective solution that meets the need of […] people with intellectual and physical disabilities” and RFA-HD-24-007 in that we will “examine the impact of existing efforts to address ableism (e.g., laws) on the health of individuals” with IDD and the way patient-level factors may mediate the “impacts of ableism on health.”

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is little knowledge available regarding the early detection of Alzheimer's disease (AD) and related dementias (ADRD), the factors that lead some people to develop full blown AD/ADRD, and the biological pathways by which they impact in the body especially in South Asians. We will leverage the ongoing Precision-CARRS Cohort, starting in midlife, to investigate factors associated with early and late AD/ADRD stages and use AI and machine learning to assess early AD/ADRD risk. Our goal is to enhance the understanding of how AD/ADRD to enable personalized and precise AD/ADRD disease prediction and advance prevention and management strategies in the understudied, yet high-risk, South Asian population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Tau tangles in Alzheimer's disease are associated with cognitive impairment, but some patients are resilient to this pathology. We aim to understand why and how tau pathology affects brain networks, which is crucial for developing effective treatments for high-risk patients. Using tau positron emission tomography and functional magnetic resonance imaging, we will determine the relationship between network architecture and cognitive decline in a diverse sample of participants at risk for Alzheimer's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aging is the strongest individual risk factor for Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD). Preclinical data suggest that modifying biological aging pathways as well as the underlying cellular and molecular processes, the so-called hallmarks of aging, may slow or halt age-related chronic diseases including ADRD. Leveraging our novel geroscience-guided studies of biological aging pathways and aging hallmarks in older adults treated with metformin vs. placebo for frailty prevention, our study will expand our understanding of the role that specific biological aging processes exert on ADRD pathophysiology and determine whether targeting the biology of aging with metformin can modulate ADRD markers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to conduct mentoring and research that is patient oriented, sustainable, and focused on the clinical epidemiology and health disparities of cardiovascular diseases and hypertension. Dr. Anderson will leverage a strong track record of successful mentoring and research to recruit and train a diverse group of early career scientists, and strengthen her research portfolio for greater impact on global policy and advocacy.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to develop a tetrodotoxin-based local anesthetic to treat post-operative or chronic pain. IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The suicide rate among female Veterans is a growing concern, yet very little research has sought to understand how to alleviate risk among this group. As such, we know surprisingly little about the health and psychosocial experiences, healthcare utilization, or barriers to care for female Veterans at risk for suicide. By interviewing Veterans about their lived experiences with suicidal thoughts, suicide attempts, and recovery needs, we will begin to develop an understanding of female Veterans' risk. Then, we will follow a large cohort of female and male Veterans over time to develop and test an explanatory model of female Veterans' risk. Findings from this study will reveal which health and psychosocial experiences are predictive of suicide attempts among female Veterans as well as which healthcare services and barriers to care require attention, providing much-needed evidence to guide the selection of intervention targets and direct valuable suicide prevention resources.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neurofibromatosis is a cancer predisposition syndrome where numerous tumors form across the body which result from somatic mutations that accumulate throughout life. Though the specific mutations that cause tumors in neurofibromatosis have been well studied, the overall dynamics of somatic mutations remain unclear. This proposal leverages innovative technology to identify somatic mutations in single cells to better understand the genetic mechanisms that drive the pathogenesis of neurofibromatosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our goal is to improving treatment options and lifespan of women with metastatic breast cancer by improving the understanding of the molecular co-evolution of the tumors and the immune system during tumor development and progression. Our expected outcomes include; 1) advancing our current understanding of resistance mechanisms; 2) determining how stress-induced HSP?0 may regulate immunosuppression; and 3) testing the therapeutic utility of HSP?0 inhibitor to improve effectiveness of current therapies in metastatic breast cancer. Our impact includes the identification of molecular targets that regulate critical steps in metastatic process and will lead to improved therapeutic approaches for the treatment of women with metastatic disease.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Every day, 50.1 million children ages 5 to 18 years attend grades K-12. About 27% of those children suffer from at least one medical condition requiring them to take medication at school. Up to 48% of school nurses reported that they made a medication administration error at school. In this study, we will be implementing a technology, similar to the one used in hospitals, to reduce medication errors at schools.

PROJECT_TITLE: Assuring Medication Safety in K-12 Schools: Implementing and Evaluating the Electronic School Medication Administration Record (E-SMAR) System

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Behaving adaptively in our environment requires retrieving the information about past experiences that is most relevant to our current goals. This project uses empirical and computational modeling methods to examine how memory and control areas of the brain interact to support this adaptive retrieval process. A detailed understanding of these mechanisms could suggest new targets for intervention in mental health disorders such as depression and schizophrenia with disturbances to memory processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative In the United States, one in four adults has an active cavity, and of adults over 65, one in four has fewer than nine teeth. While oral health and the oral microbiome that supports it are both highly heritable, few genetic associations have been established. This project aims to better characterize genetic variation at the salivary amylase locus to identify any associations it has with oral health phenotypes as well as the prevalence of specific bacterial species in the oral microbiome that are known to impact tooth health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The primary mission of our Wellstone Center is to understand the molecular and physiological events that lead to the most common form of adult-onset muscular dystrophy, myotonic dystrophy, and utilize this knowledge to develop safe and effective treatments for this disease. Our Center organization, which includes the National Registry for myotonic dystrophy, is built on close and long-standing collaborations with basic researchers at the University of Florida and clinical experts at the University of Rochester.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Latinas suffer disproportionately from breast cancer, relative to non-Latina Whites, including late-stage diagnoses and worse mental health during diagnostic evaluation, treatment, and survivorship. This Diversity Supplement aims to extend the Parent Grant (R01CA261638), by providing insight into factors that contribute to Latinas' decisions to seek and provide social support after receiving abnormal mammogram results through a prospective qualitative study. Further, the Diversity Supplement will train a bicultural, bilingual Latina trainee seeking a Master's of Social Work degree in health communications and qualitative research methods, which will enhance the diversity and research impact of the nation's workforce of emerging clinician scientists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Lineberger Comprehensive Cancer Center (LCCC) forms the nexus for researchers focused on understanding and identifying the mechanisms leading to, the prevention of, and treatments for cancer. LCCC is an integral component of the research mission at The University of North Carolina (UNC) at Chapel Hill, coalescing the cancer research capabilities of the Schools of Medicine, Public Health, Pharmacy, and Nursing, and the College of Arts and Sciences. The LCCC strives to reduce cancer incidence, morbidity, and mortality in North Carolina, the United States and across the globe through innovative research, cutting-edge treatments, multi-disciplinary training, education and outreach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT – Abramson Cancer Center Cancer is the second leading cause of death in the United States and prevalent in the ethnically diverse catchment area of the Abramson Cancer Center (ACC), which consists of 12 contiguous counties in Pennsylvania, New Jersey, and Delaware, in which 81.4% of ACC's patients reside. Through our Research Programs and Community Outreach and Engagement, the ACC addresses the burden imposed by highly prevalent cancers in the catchment area, including breast, prostate, lung, colorectal, melanoma, and lymphoma. ACC basic, clinical, and population science research – along with Community Outreach and Engagement Activities – are integrated to prevent, diagnose, and treat these cancers and address cancer risk factors to promote healthy living.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Ovarian cancer is the most lethal gynecological malignancy, and the process of ovulation is a risk factor. Our team developed novel microfluidic systems that allow for 3D culture of the ovary and the fallopian tube, which recreate ovulation ex vivo. Building on these systems, we will investigate factors from ovulation that drive tumor initiation, expansion of a secretory and stem cell niche, as well as ovarian specific tumor cell migration using fallopian tube models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative. The intent of this proposal is to provide the baccalaureate candidate with the assets needed to render her highly competitive for a career in academic medicine. With this in mind, we have proposed, 1) a study of the function of ZNF671, a gene frequently methylated in breast cancer, that will provide a solid training in laboratory investigation, 2) courses that will bolster her current understanding of cancer and treatment strategies, and, 3) assistance in career development through conferences, mentorship, communication and networking. This three- pronged approach will provide the candidate with the all the tools necessary for success.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

PHR: Project Narrative    This project will investigate how deficiency in a critical sensor of DNA double strand breaks (Mre11) promotes  the development of triple negative breast cancer (estrogen/progesterone receptor negative, HER2 non-  amplified). We will elucidate molecular profiles and therapeutic vulnerabilities of Mre11 deficient breast cancer.  These studies may engender novel approaches to both prevent and treat triple negative breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE [parent project] State of the art methods for the early detection and monitoring of cancer are either invasive, time-consuming, expensive, or frequently inaccurate, which hinders the routine screening of at risk-patients to improve survival rates. Here, we propose a portable neural network enabled spectroscopy platform to diagnose cancer in patient biofluids (saliva, blood plasma, and sweat). The expected outcome is to deliver a novel point of care liquid biopsy platform to better classify, monitor, and improve diagnostic sensitivity of a broad range of diseases and conditions, with focus on early/late-stage head and neck cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: The prevalence of cardiometabolic risk factors (e.g., obesity) among youth remains high globally, and gestational and childhood exposure to PFAS may adversely influence cardiometabolic risk. However, the biological mechanisms underlying these associations are not well-understood, but PFAS may accelerate biological aging; thus, we propose using epigenetic clocks, a method to measure biological age, to understand the link between PFAS exposure and cardiometabolic health. These results will help to identify PFAS-associated biological targets during early-life with the goal of preventing later-life risk of cardiometabolic disease in historically exposed populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE Substance use and associated HIV, hepatitis C (HCV), and mental health comorbidities continue to drive morbidity and mortality globally. Interdisciplinary, interinstitutional collaborations can challenge paradigms to achieve cross-cutting advances in substance use treatment that limit the spread of HIV/HCV and decrease morbidity and death. As this training program is located in states with high rates of substance use, we propose an interdisciplinary faculty career development program to increase the number of well-prepared investigators with expertise in the risk factors for, and mechanisms underlying, substance use and the behavioral, environmental, and health disparity aspects of substance use and its associated morbidity and mortality.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The persistently critically ill—while not common—are costly, growing in incidence, and their survivorship is associated with high morbidity. Survivorship for Veterans with persistent critical illness has largely been understudied because of the mistaken assumption that all these Veterans will die within the year. This study will help us understand why some VHA hospitals have better long-term quality of life outcomes following a hospitalization with persistent critical illness. By identifying strategies used by high-performing VHA hospitals, we will be able to identify, share, and create a best practices toolkit to improve Veteran survivorship and recovery from a hospitalization with persistent critical illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal leverages the Drosophila model system to address the neural mechanisms underlying social interactions, from processing of cues emitted by a communication partner to generating complex behaviors in response to those cues. Impairments in processing sensory information or generating motor behaviors, particularly in the context of social interactions, underlie several human disorders including Parkinson’s disease and Autism spectrum disorder. This proposal will uncover general principles of neural circuit function that will inform studies of sensorimotor integration in more complex systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will determine how the immune cells of the brain, known as microglia, function during brain development. We will test the hypothesis that immune signals involved in antiviral defenses can serve a dual role in the developing brain by eliminating some types of nerve cells, particularly during stress. This novel mechanism could help explain how immune challenges during early development can impact brain function throughout life.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Using zebrafish as a model, this study will characterize the mechanical properties of the notochord vacuolated cells in live embryos and investigate their physical response to mechanical and genetic perturbations. This work will contribute to our understanding of spine formation and the origin of vertebral malformations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Clinical studies suggest that 85% of all dry eye disease cases are caused by some form of Meibomian Gland Dysfunction (MGD). Despite the high prevalence of MGD, its etiology remains unknown. This proposal will investigate for the first time the role of autoreactive CD4+ T cell that attack the Meibomian Glands, leading to MGD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE State prenatal drug policies are currently being debated and enacted in the absence of rigorous evidence on these laws’ impacts on pregnant and postpartum populations and their infants. In this project, we study the effects of state prenatal drug policies on drug screening, substance use disorder diagnosis and treatment, overdose, and maternal and child health care use. We also assess state implementation of a significant recent federal child welfare policy reform across states with varying prenatal drug law contexts.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: CE24-012 - ASSESSING THE IMPLEMENTATION AND OUTCOMES OF STATE PRENATAL DRUG USE LAWS

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of the proposed research is to develop the technologies necessary to allow multiple bioluminescent reporters to be used simultaneously in the same cell or organism. This technology will enable the observation and control of two or more activities at once, allowing researchers to gather much more informative data when probing the complex dynamics of the brain and other systems in animal models of human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite scientific evidence supporting reduction in overdose risk with use of medications for opioid use disorder and engagement with harm reduction approaches, patient uptake remains limited. Concerned significant others (CSOs) of people who use drugs (PWUD) have the potential to provide positive social support to improve overdose risk behavior through treatment and harm reduction engagement if they are given adequate training and resources. Using community-engaged research methodology, we propose to develop and evaluate a novel brief multi-component digital intervention for the CSOs of PWUD, aiming to reduce stigma around evidence-based medications and harm reduction, provide resources on community and health system navigation, teach positive communication skills, and improve caregiver well-being.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: CE24-013 - Developing and Evaluating the Concerned Caregivers Education for Resource Navigation (ConCERN) Intervention for Preventing Overdose

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will test the feasibility, acceptability, and efficacy of a novel peer harm reduction champion intervention to reduce overdose risk among older Black adults who use opioids. This intervention is designed to both improve access to harm reduction tools and services and to reduce stigma and increase social support. If successful, this intervention will significantly reduce opioid overdose rates among a marginalized population at high risk of overdose.

PROJECT_TITLE: CE24-013 - Reducing Overdose and Substance Use-related Stigma on Chicago's West Side by Training Non-substance-using Friends and Family Members of People who Use Opioids to Be Harm Reduction Champions

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Liver cancer is one the most prevalent type of cancer with deadly outcome in the U.S. and worldwide. Liver- directed therapies such as transarterial chemoembolization or radioembolization can locally target liver lesions with low systemic toxicity, but are currently limited by the lack of precise, individualized, and reliable treatment planning tools. This work develops liver transarterial embolization treatment planning based on clinical imaging and computational methods to improve patient outcome through better selection, greater efficacy and safety.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (From Parent Grant Application) Because blood cancers are exquisitely sensitive to radiation, targeted radiation delivery via radioimmunotherapy (radionuclides stably linked to target-specific antibodies) has gained interest with a commensurate increase in radioimmunotherapy clinical trials. Although clinical efficacy has been observed in stand-alone radioimmunotherapy for cancers, or as part of conditioning regimens prior to allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation, how the normal bone marrow niche differentially responds radioimmunotherapy compared to conventional approaches is not well-understood, limiting potential interventions to mitigate the negative effects from radiation to the marrow. This proposal will address current limitations and identify how to modulate specific bone marrow niche alterations for desired clinical goals by identifying how the hematopoietic stem cells, vascular endothelial cells and stromal cells in the bone marrow niche respond to radioimmunotherapy with an alpha- emitter (astatine-211), beta-emitter (yttrium-90), or X-ray radiation, as gauged by stem cell functional assays, architecture restructuring using microscopy, and differential gene expression from RNA sequence analysis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Persons with chronic kidney disease (CKD) are at high risk of fracture; however, medical management requires knowing the underlying bone turnover rate, which currently requires invasive, painful, expensive, and inaccessible bone biopsy and histomorphometry. We propose an imaging-based non-invasive ‘virtual bone biopsy’, which applies time-lapse high resolution quantitative computed tomography (HR-pQCT) to identify and quantify specific areas of new bone formation and resorption throughout a volume of bone over time. We aim to validate a novel metric of bone turnover measured by time-lapse HR-pQCT vs. the gold-standard bone turnover measured by bone biopsy, determine the sensitivity and specificity of time-lapse HR-pQCT for assessment of turnover in a CKD population, and determine whether time-lapse HR-pQCT can detect responses to therapy over time in CKD patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disorders of motivated behavior, such as depression and drug addiction, can be triggered or aggravated by negative experiences. This project will investigate the motivational properties of aversive stimuli and the underlying neurobiological mechanisms. Specifically, the proposed experiments aim to uncover the role of dopamine in mediating aversion-induced changes in drug seeking, negative reinforcement, and punishment learning after chronic stress.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic cancer is characterized by a hypoxic microenvironment and a dense, desmoplastic stroma which is mainly composed of fibroblasts and extracellular matrix. The goal of this proposal is to elucidate the mechanisms by which hypoxia regulates bidirectional interactions between cancer cells and fibroblasts in pancreatic cancer. My studies will provide new insights into the impact of hypoxia on tumor-stroma crosstalk in pancreatic cancer, which can be exploited to devise new stroma-targeting approaches for this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Small-molecule mimics of cyclic GMP-AMP (cGAMP) are a promising new class of immunotherapeutics for the treatment of cancer. Preparation of these drugs is limited, however, by the exceptionally difficulty of their prepa- ration by classic synthetic means. This proposal aims to develop highly direct biocatalytic approaches for the synthesis of cGAMP-mimics, which will enable the rapid preparation of large libraries of novel cancer therapeutic drug targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mechanisms of residual cell survival following initial therapy, one of the leading causes of cancer recurrence, remain under-studied, in part due to the scarcity of tools and models to faithfully study the evolutionary dynamics of residual disease. My doctoral work will focus on designing novel imaging methodologies to visualize spatiotemporal metabolic and vascular heterogeneities during residual disease and recurrence in vivo while my postdoctoral work will focus on elucidating the molecular mechanisms that drive recurrence using faithful PDX models of triple negative breast cancer to identify actionable metabolic and vascular targets. This synergistic approach will provide a holistic understanding of the behaviors of residual tumors, guiding the development of targeted therapies aimed at eradicating residual disease to reduce or delay recurrence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glioblastoma is an aggressive, fast-growing brain cancer that represents nearly half of all malignant brain tumors. Due to the high rate of recurrence, current treatment options only extend survival following initial diagnosis to one year. Building on years of basic research into the biology of glioblastoma identifying nonmuscle myosin II as a potential therapeutic target, an interdisciplinary team has been brought together with the necessary expertise in glioblastoma and myosin biology, drug development and the clinical treatment of glioblastoma to advance a small molecule inhibitor for glioblastoma therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: OVERALL: NARRATIVE Cancer is a deadly disease for which there is no panacea but requires a multi-pronged approach to improve the outcomes of our patients. To that end, the Herbert Irving Comprehensive Cancer Center at Columbia University Irving Medical Center/New York Presbyterian Hospital is dedicated to the vision and mission of reducing the cancer burden in our catchment area. The HICCC spans basic, translational, clinical and population research that is supported by shared resources, community outreach and engagement, training and education, and strategic investments, all converging on cancer screening, surveillance, early detection, prognosis, therapy, survivorship and palliation.

Cancer is the second leading cause of the death in the U.S. The goal of the Fred Hutchinson/University of Washington Cancer Consortium is the elimination of cancer as a cause of suffering and death through more effective prevention, diagnosis, and treatment, deriving from fundamental insights into the biology of the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE MOFFITT CANCER CENTER SUPPORT GRANT Moffitt Cancer Center (Moffitt) is a free-standing 501(c)3 not-for profit institution that was founded by legal statute to address cancer needs in the area, the State of Florida, and beyond, with the singular mission “to contribute to the prevention and cure of cancer.” Fully informed by the cancer burden in our community and catchment area, guided by highly effective, driven and synergistic senior leadership and a rigorous research strategic plan, supported by outstanding institutional funding, and cultivated by its five research Programs that span the basic, population, data, and clinical sciences, Moffitt fosters exceptional cancer research that spans discovery to translation to the clinic, and that has the momentum to accelerate its scientific impact for decades to come. More specifically, Moffitt’s research has provided paradigm shifts in our understanding of the cancer ecosystem, has discovered and advanced new means to prevent, treat and cure some forms of cancer that have led to changes in clinical practice and national health policy, and which over the next award period will be further accelerated by investments in research focused on: 1) our catchment area; 2) health disparities; 3) immuno-oncology; 4) metabolism; 5) data science; and 6) cancer care, delivery, and implementation science.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Director’s Overview and Essential Characteristics Brian Druker, M.D., Center Director The OHSU Knight Cancer Institute has made numerous impactful contributions since its designation as one of the nation’s National Cancer Institute Cancer Centers in 1997. Accomplishments include establishing the paradigm of targeted cancer therapy, now referred to as precision medicine. Through the work supported by our Cancer Center Support Grant, we conduct cancer research that spans basic, clinical, and prevention and control and aims to improve outcomes for individuals in our catchment area and throughout the nation.

PHR: OVERALL: PROJECT NARRATIVE The OU Stephenson Cancer Center fulfills a unique need in Oklahoma and the region by conducting innovative and impactful research that seeks to translate novel discoveries into the clinical or community setting through a transdisciplinary team-based approach. The goal of these efforts is to decrease cancer incidence and improve outcomes for Oklahomans and all individuals, with a special emphasis on promoting cancer health equity among the state’s underserved minority populations.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: OVERVIEW Cancer affects 1 in every 3 people in the US and as our population ages this fraction is expected to increase. Outcomes for cancer patients have improved over the last several decades, but there is still a great burden of cancer-related mortality and morbidity that is borne disproportionately by minorities and the economically disadvantaged. MD Anderson Cancer Center's mission is to eliminate cancer in Texas, the nation and the world through outstanding programs that integrate patient care, research and prevention, and through education for undergraduate and graduate students, trainees, professionals, employees and the public. Our vision is to be the premier cancer center in the world based on the excellence of our people, our research-driven patient care and our science.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The University of Wisconsin Carbone Cancer Center (UWCCC), which is a matrix center within the University of Wisconsin School of Medicine and Public Health (SMPH), seeks to dramatically reduce the burden of cancer within and beyond our catchment. Specifically, the UWCCC will do this by decreasing cancer incidence and mortality among populations within our catchment area and beyond, including our minority and underserved populations. We will facilitate pursuit of this goal through partnerships with other health delivery systems and state and community agencies for dissemination of evidence-based findings. The UWCCC will accomplish our goals through nurturing a diverse and supportive cancer community, reliable infrastructure, and efficient resources. During the current funding period, UWCCC continued to decrease the burden of cancer in our catchment and beyond through prioritized research areas (e.g., innovative therapies and biomarkers, cancer imaging and expanded population-based cancer research), enhanced research platforms (e.g., improved clinical research infrastructure and shared resources), increased efforts to build mission-related philanthropy, and expanded local-to-global partnerships.

PHR: OVERALL: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Alvin J. Siteman Cancer Center (SCC) at Washington University and Barnes-Jewish Hospital is a NCI designated Comprehensive Cancer Center whose mission is to prevent cancer in the community and transform cancer patient care through scientific discovery. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our goal is to improve control of cardiovascular (CV) disease risk factors defined by the American Heart Association’s Life’s Simple 7 (blood glucose, cholesterol, blood pressure, physical activity, weight, diet, and smoking) by engaging patients experiencing health disparities in an innovative technology-based self- management intervention with linkages to health system providers. Using a patient-level randomized pragmatic trial design, we will enroll 6,000 patients from three Federally Qualified Health Centers, Denver Health and Hospital Authority, Salud Family Health Centers, or STRIDE Community Health Center. The study findings will provide evidence regarding the best population-based strategy for universal delivery to engage all patients experiencing health disparities in self-management to improve CV disease risk factors.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Structural ableism drives many of the health inequities faced by disabled people across social determinants of health, healthcare access, healthcare quality, and health outcomes. This project will characterize dimensions of structural ableism, and create measures to assess it which are essential first steps to identifying how structural ableism impacts health outcomes among disabled people. This work will provide measures needed to identify and evaluate novel interventions aimed at dismantling structural ableism, which should be co-created with the disability community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Basement membranes are strong thin sheets of protein and carbohydrates found in all animals, and they lie underneath cell sheets and wrap around muscles, nerves, and organs. Basement membranes have many functions, including mechanical stability, filtering the blood, and insulating tissues so they do not receive inappropriate signals from other parts of the body. Part of the basement membrane appears to be less stable than other parts, and we will investigate what this means for basement membrane overall stability and function.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Title: Determining the relationships between provider bias, experiences of ableism, and health outcomes for people with mobility disabilities Project Narrative The goal of this project is to investigate mechanisms through which ableism in healthcare settings impacts people with mobility disabilities (PWMD) and their health outcomes. The research team will collect quantitative and qualitative data related to both episodic and cumulative experiences of perceived ableism of PWMD, explicit and implicit disability biases of rehabilitation professionals from whom they receive care, and their health outcomes such as self-perceived health status, depression, anxiety, pain, participation, quality of life, and measures of healthcare utilization. This work will fill a critical gap in understanding underlying mechanisms that perpetuate ableism in healthcare so that more effective bias-mitigating solutions may be developed and evaluated in the future, to ultimately reduce disparities and maximize participation, health, and quality of life in partnership with PWMD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to uncover the genetic control of social brain maturation and function during adolescence and how this unfolds differently in males and females. To achieve this, using the mouse as a model, we will mutagenize the transcription factor encoding gene, Foxp2, specifically in the amygdala, a central brain structure driving social-emotional changes that occur during adolescence. As mutations in Foxp2 in humans have been reproducibly associated with neurodevelopmental/behavioral conditions such as autism spectrum disorder, ADHD and language impairment, most of which differ across gender, our understanding of the genetic mechanisms of adolescent brain development is a critical step toward designing rational interventional and therapeutic approaches based on the underlying biology of these conditions. .

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the growing number of women with intellectual and developmental disabilities (I/DD) giving birth, very little is known about the impact of ableism on their access to healthcare and service use during pregnancy, delivery, and postpartum periods. Using 2016-2023 national Medicaid claims linked to community-level information about social determinants of health, state Medicaid policy data, and other data sources, the proposed study will conduct a detailed examination of service access and delivery to birthing people with I/DD aged 14 to 50 who have experienced a delivery and will compare outcomes experienced by this group and their linked infants to those of their Medicaid-enrolled peers without I/DD. Paired with surveys and interviews of obstetric service providers identified through Medicaid claims, this mixed methods study will result in the most substantive work to date to identify the impact of ableism on birthing people with I/DD at both the clinical care (attitudinal ableism) and system (Medicaid policy, structural ableism) levels.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative/Relevance This study will examine changes in the organization of oncology care providers over time and the impact of these changes on the quality of care, diffusion of new therapies, health care utilization, and outcomes for cancer patients overall and for vulnerable/disadvantaged subgroups. The findings will provide oncology practitioners, payers, and policy makers valuable information to improve access, quality and outcomes of cancer care. Our results also will inform policies and practices related to the value of integration of oncology care, quality measurement, design of alternative payment models, and development of innovative delivery models to care for vulnerable/disadvantaged populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: Project Narrative Public Health Relevance: Malaria is a disease caused by protozoan parasites of the genus Plasmodium, which is transmitted by mosquitos. Despite the ongoing eradication campaigns and availability of effective anti-malarial drugs this disease remains a global burden to human health, resulting in over 200 million of deaths per year, primarily in children under the age of five. Thus, an emphasis has been placed on understanding how the immune response, innate and adaptive, provides protection against this infection in order to determine how protective immunity can be enhanced in a vaccine setting to ultimately provide and maintain immunity against this disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ableism as a Mechanism of Physical and Mental Health Inequities Among Children with Visual Impairment Children who are blind or visually impaired (CBVI) experience high rates of physical and mental health disor- ders, which may be driven by ableism. Ableism harms people with disabilities, such as CBVI, by excluding them from full participation in society, but the specific impact of ableism on the physical and mental health of CBVI has not been examined. The proposed study seeks to identify the role of ableism in driving physical and mental health inequities within CBVI in order to reveal how ableism “gets under the skin” and results in poor health outcomes for these vulnerable children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (parent award, R01 CA251110), unchanged Radiation therapy for the clinical management of brain tumors and metastases is linked with severe cognitive decline and neuroinflammation in cancer survivors. We hypothesize that radiation-induced aberrant activation of the glial complement cascade play a causal role in development of cognitive impairments. This proposal will address glial complement activation mechanism and translationally feasible intervention to curtain this unmet medical need.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Gastric (stomach) cancer is one of the top five causes of cancer and cancer deaths worldwide, and about 80% of cases are due to stomach infection with the bacterium Helicobacter pylori. This project will use new mouse models, human samples, and cutting-edge immune profiling and single-cell sequencing techniques to investigate the mechanism(s) through which chronic Helicobacter pylori infection and associated inflammation promote pre- cancerous changes in the stomach. This research will lead to a better understanding of how inflammation causes cancer and may reveal new immunotherapy strategies for infection-associated cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Astrocytes are cells highly abundant in the brain where they play important roles in the maintenance of homeostasis. Recent evidence show that astrocytes are involved in neurological and neuropsychiatric disorders. Astrocytes have been reported to express the dopamine D2 receptors, a major player of the dopaminergic control of brain functions. This proposal aims at determining the role of D2R in astrocytes and possible implication in the control of brain disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Latinx families in the United States (US) are more likely to lose a child to cancer and experience inequities in bereavement and grief outcomes. This study will generate a comprehensive understanding of how the processes of adverse social determinants of health influence these inequities and how resilience could be leveraged to inform culturally and contextually grounded interventions for this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE The proposed studies will investigate mechanisms regulating endocytosis in Lysosome Rich Enterocytes (LREs) in zebrafish. These studies will provide valuable insights into the mechanisms controlling protein absorption in the vertebrate gut. Because LREs and their physiology are conserved between zebrafish and mammals our studies are relevant for human intestinal physiology, particularly infant nutrition and development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed administrative supplement will preserve the objectivity and potential clinical implications of the parent R34 grant by supporting the incorporation of biomarkers of unhealthy alcohol use, Ethyl glucuronide (EtG) and Phosphatidylethanol (PEth), reliable for measuring recent and chronic alcohol use, respectively. When the proposal was submitted, there was a reasonable expectation that the costs of these tests would be indirectly subsidized for research purposes, based on NIAAA-funded colleagues’ previous experience, but this is no longer the case. Accordingly, to preserve the potential benefit of the proposal for the overall research community as well as its potential impact on NIH-funded research, we are submitting this noncompeting administrative supplement proposal to fund the unsubsidized cost of EtG and PEth testing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The “virtual front door”–websites and digital information–is often the first interaction point that patients have with healthcare systems. However, people who are blind or have low vision face barriers using this front door at many academic medical centers, blocking their access to life-saving specialty care. We propose to change academic medical centers to reduce the impacts of structural ableism that block access to healthcare settings, by building dashboards that report on the accessibility of these virtual front doors and creating and testing tools to improve that accessibility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative More than fifty percent of adults and children in the United States suffer from have high arterial blood pressure (hypertension); if left untreated, hypertension leads to cardiovascular and kidney disease and stroke. The purpose of this application is to request travel and caregiver funds to support trainees and junior investigators who wish to attend and participate in the Hypertension Scientific Sessions 2024 to be held in Chicago on September 5–8, 2024. By supporting the travel, education, and development of these promising early-career scientists to this preeminent meeting, we hope to expand and diversify the current workforce, ultimately increasing innovation in hypertension research.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it is the first study to systematically assess the prevalence of medical ableism and its consequences for patient care and health within a large and inclusive national sample of U.S. adults with disabilities. The long-term goal of our research is to develop a nuanced and comprehensive understanding of medical ableism that will ultimately allow us to develop targeted interventions to mitigate its effects on the health of people with disabilities. The project will model best practices in disability inclusion and representation, and further the National Center on Medical Rehabilitation Research’s mission to foster the development of scientific knowledge needed to enhance the health, productivity, independence, and quality of life of people with disabilities.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is an urgent need to address the deleterious effects of ableist practices and policies on the pregnancy-related experiences and outcomes of women with disabilities. While research shows that women with disabilities are as likely to choose pregnancy and parenthood as their nondisabled counterparts, they have a significantly higher risk for adverse maternal and child health outcomes driven by barriers to appropriate care, stigma, and inadequate provider training. This study will develop an online continuing education program for obstetricians with the goal of increasing the timely provision of evidence- based, inclusive perinatal care to women with disabilities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most lethal hematological malignancy, and alternatives to chemotherapy such as differentiation therapy are greatly needed. We recently found that the H3K9 histone acetyltransferase KAT6A cooperates with the H3K9ac reader protein ENL to promote stemness and proliferation in AML. Here, we aim to determine the molecular mechanisms by which KAT6A and ENL cooperate to drive leukemogenic gene expression programs, and to identify the genetic subtypes of AML that are most sensitive to KAT6A inhibition.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative As a result of ableism, people with disabilities (PWD) experience diagnostic overshadowing—attributing symptoms to disability rather than a potentially new or comorbid condition. In our End Diagnostic Overshadowing program our goal is to identify and create understanding of mechanisms underlying diagnostic overshadowing and then develop means to reduce it, specifically targeted education programs and decision supports for healthcare professionals. If successful, we will have developed a system for identifying and creating understanding of mechanisms underlying diagnostic overshadowing and will have created specific means to mitigate and reduce its effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Impaired bile acid homeostasis contributes to the pathogenesis of cholestatic liver disease and liver injury as well as many metabolic diseases including obesity and type-2 diabetes. The SEL1L-HRD1 protein complex represents the most conserved branch of mammalian endoplasmic reticulum (ER)-associated degradation (ERAD) machinery, responsible for the recruitment and retrotranslocation of ER proteins for cytosolic proteasomal degradation. This study will test an exciting hypothesis that hepatic SEL1L-HRD1 ERAD protein complex plays a critical role in bile acids homeostasis by regulating bile acid biosynthesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed clinical trial aims to assess if a glucagon-like peptide 1 receptor agonist, a medication approved for weight management that also improves the body's response to glucose and insulin, can slow kidney growth in adults with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease who are overweight or obese. The study will also evaluate changes in abdominal fat and kidney metabolism using cutting-edge images techniques. Blood and urine samples will provide further insight into biological changes that may be linked to the benefits of the intervention, while ensuring careful monitoring of safety and tolerability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE To correct long-standing racial/ethnic health inequities, research is needed to identify policies that address the structural conditions contributing to persistently high rates of firearm violence. Local alcohol control and economic support policies are two promising sets of such policies. This study will rigorously evaluate their effectiveness in reducing firearm assault injuries and generate actionable evidence on which policies local governments should enact or avoid to reduce firearm violence and promote health equity.

PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-CE-24-030,  Social policies to prevent firearm assault

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) is the leading cause of death in the US. Despite a worse profile of lifetime exposure to many ASCVD risk factors in Japan, ASCVD mortality is less than half of that in the US. Understanding the mechanisms of low ASCVD mortality in Japan could lead to novel preventive and therapeutic strategies for reducing the burden of ASCVD in the US.
