IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The burden of visual disability in the U.S. is substantial and ever-growing; myriad disparities in health and healthcare result in significant inequities, inequities that are not only disproportionately higher for this population but also largely unaddressed. We will use mixed methods to support novel qualitative methods to better understand exactly what is needed with regards to reasonable accommodations and devise an implementation strategy to evaluate and test such services in these populations. Our transdisciplinary and national team will use a patient-centered approach that leverages input from participants with lived experience and disability experts to foster the creation of solutions that promote equity, ultimately benefitting visually impaired persons worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adverse Child Experiences are prevalent for youth receiving intensive mental health services (e.g., partial hospitalization programs; inpatient care) and are a cross-cutting risk factor for peer aggression and teen dating violence. Despite aggression serving as a leading cause for referral to IMHS, most youth do not receive aggression-focused care and there are no trauma-informed aggression interventions designed for youth in IMHS. This study aims to develop and evaluate a group-based trauma-informed intervention to reduce peer aggression, prevent teen dating violence, and improve mental health outcomes in preteens (i.e., 11- to 13-year-olds) receiving IMHS.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Cross-Cutting Trauma-Informed Peer Aggression and Dating Violence Prevention for Preteens Receiving Intensive Mental Health Services

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a critical unmet need for a disease-modifying small molecule drug for Alzheimer’s disease (AD); of the ten leading causes of death in the United States, only AD cannot be prevented or cured and is increasing in incidence. This program is highly important because it is progressing to fill this need with a disease-modifying drug that, if successful, will have a tremendous impact on the more than 6.7 million Americans who currently have AD (projected to be 13.8 million by 2060) and their caregivers, and will also help reduce the current cost of $345 billion (projected to be $1.1 trillion by 2050) to our nation (Alzheimer's Association 2023 Alzheimer's Disease Facts and Figures). This Supplement to the awarded R01 will cover unanticipated incremental costs related to project delays directly attributable to FDA requests for additional toxicology data on the compound prior to progressing to higher doses in human volunteers as well as staff to support these aims, and it is urgent that this Supplement be supported and initiated as soon as possible as currently available clinical supplies will reach their expiry date prior to the anticipated date of completion of clinical activities supported by this grant and cause delay in the completion of the clinical study.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Program Narrative Approximately 12% of men in the United States are subfertile or infertile. Infertility is a pervasive condition that impacts not only the ability to have biological children, but has broader implications for psychological well- being, relationships, finances (assisted reproduction and adoption can be expensive), overall health and life expectancy. The objective of this NCTRI P50 Center for Reproductive Genetics and Therapy is to Improve knowledge about the genetic basis of infertility to aid in the counseling of infertile couples; justify the development of diagnostic screens; and develop patient-specific treatment options.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project II: Narative Despite remarkable advances in high-throughput sequencing and computational genomics, a major problem has been in developing tests to validate the predicted causality genetic variants amongst a sea of other variants in any given person. Whereas mouse modeling of human variants is a gold standard for variant validation, it is expensive and time-consuming, a problem exacerbated by the high false positive rate of in silico predictions. This project will deploy and further develop scalable in vitro gametogenesis platforms that have the promise of enabling functional assessment of large numbers of predicted infertility alleles found in the genomes of infertile patients, thereby enabling more rapid and confident clinical diagnostics and potential gene therapies.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The proposal request funds to purchase an advanced, environmental-friendly, high performing and high- throughput animal cage and rack washer system and a cloud-based environmental monitoring system for UMKC’s Laboratory Animal Research Core facility. These state of the art systems are required to perform the most rigorous and quantitatively accurate experiments and is needed by NIH-funded scientists, who conduct research on diseases that affect significant and increasing portions of the U.S. population including minorities affected by disparities in health care delivery. Access to these systems will increase the impact of innovative research conducted by researchers by accelerating research progress and enhancing the quality and breadth of research results, determining causes, mechanisms of action and subsequently contributing to discovering potential treatment strategies and improving health care in major medical fields.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Metabolically active fat rich in mitochondria (called “brown” or “beige”) maintains insulin sensitivity in healthy individuals, an ability that diminishes with obesity and advancing age in association with a process called fat fibrosis that is closely linked to insulin resistance and type 2 diabetes. Despite HIV medications that have sharply curbed the prevalence of AIDS, the growing population of people living with HIV (PLWH) have concerningly high rates of insulin resistance and diabetes and recent work, including from our group, shows that PLWH also have profound fat fibrosis. We have developed highly innovative tools to monitor brown/beige fat cells in both PLWH and a mouse model of HIV, and propose to use these tools to determine the extent to which a specific subset of fat cells marked by the protein CD81 dictate the propensity of PLWH to develop both fat fibrosis and insulin resistance, providing insight into to new interventional opportunities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Treatment of malignant melanoma has been revolutionized with the introduction of immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICI); however, response to these therapies is not universal. ICI rely on recruitment of T cells into the tumor microenvironment (TME) to perpetuate an anti-tumor immune response. The role of the innate immune system in recruitment of T cells into the TME and how this changes during tumor progression is largely unknown.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: The goal of this proposal is to understand the contribution of abnormal muscle blood flow distribution to decreased functional capacity in DM. Hypothesis: Microvascular perfusion heterogeneity contributes to diabetes mediated muscle fatigue, decreased muscle VO2 and impaired functional exercise capacity and these endpoints will improve with two different agents that improve muscle blood flow distribution -GLP-1 or Nitrites. SA#1: To test the hypothesis that hyperglycemia will cause muscle perfusion heterogeneity, muscle fatigue and decreased muscle VO2 and that GLP-1 and Nitrites will prevent or restore these endpoints. SA#2: To examine the ability of GLP-1 or Nitrites to improve DM FEC and to augment the impact of exercise training. SA#3: To define the importance of GLP-1 receptors for muscle perfusion heterogeneity and function and for the adaptation to exercise training. Impact of these studies on the Veteran Population: Ultimately, improving functional capacity should increase longevity and health-span for people with diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although thousands of RNAs are localized to a variety of subcellular locations, the sequences within those RNAs that regulate their transport are generally unknown. This proposal uses high-throughput techniques to identify and characterize RNA localization regulatory elements with high precision.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The vast majority of ALS patients and roughly half of FTD patients display neuronal inclusions rich in the RNA binding protein TDP43. In previous work, we found that TDP43 splice variants, termed “short” (s)TDP43, are cytosolic in localization and able to sequester full-length TDP43 within disease-like inclusions, pointing to a potential contribution of these isoforms to neurodegeneration. In this proposal, I will define the native RNA and protein interactors for sTDP43 and investigate a potential function for sTDP43 in maintaining RNA homeostasis, thus providing novel insight into the mechanisms by which sTDP43 may drive disease pathogenesis in ALS and FTD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This project will investigate the effects of granzyme K-expressing CD8 T cells on fibroblasts in synovial tissue in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. We have detected CD8 T cells with a similar profile in several other diseased tissues, including kidney in lupus nephritis, inflamed bowel in Crohn’s disease and ulcerative colitis, and lung (broncheoalveolar lavage fluid) in severe SARS-CoV-2 infection. Thus, our findings within the context of rheumatoid arthritis may improve our ability to understand, diagnose, and treat many diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative With staggeringly high relapse and overdose rates and a dearth of treatment access and efficacy, the opioid epidemic is among the most pressing public health concerns of our time; drug craving states can be induced by a number of social, environmental, and contextual cues, there are often comorbidities with mental health issues, and other substance use disorders, and sustained, consistent, permanent behavior change is required to avert potential relapse events. An increasing body of literature identifies United States veterans as extremely vulnerable to opioid addiction and overdose, amongst other mental health related risks; the proposed work entails the development of precision opioid-use related intelligence which presents a unique opportunity to make an impact beyond aiding the process of addiction recovery, to help those struggling with other mental health challenges such as anxiety, PTSD, and suicidal ideation, and includes investigating the potential for physiological and behavioral monitoring of individuals with opioid addictions amongst the US Veteran population in order to improve adherence to treatment for opioid use disorder and aid in reintegration into civilian life. Behaivior will deliver real-time insights from internal and external factors that affect craving states based on wrist wearables and smartphone monitoring technology that can detect high-risk craving states and provide a trusted network of support individuals as well as care coordinators with just-in-time information to facilitate interventions which may avert life-threatening events, including overdoses or suicides.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The dynamic microtubule cytoskeleton plays vital roles in cell division, motility and differentiation. This project aims to provide a fundamental molecular understanding of dynamic microtubule behavior using a multidisciplinary approach that combines biochemical in vitro reconstitution, live-cell imaging and computational modeling. Because microtubules are a common target for chemotherapeutic agents and many of their regulating proteins are implicated in cancer and neurodegenerative diseases, the proposed research bears critical relevance for both basic science and human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Mammalian retinas lack an intrinsic regenerative capability, so loss of neurons cause permanent vision loss in humans with neurodegenerative diseases. Recently, progress has been made in engineering mammalian Müller glia to replace lost neurons, however, we have found that the inflammation that accompanies neuronal loss restricts regeneration. In this proposal, experiments are outlined to determine how the neuroimmune system impacts Müller glia-mediated regeneration, with the objective to identify novel strategies for improving the regenerative potential of the mammalian retina.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: HUNTSMAN CANCER INSTITUTE PROJECT NARRATIVE Huntsman Cancer Institute (HCI) at the University of Utah is the only National Cancer Institute-designated Cancer Center in Utah and the vast area of the five-state Mountain West; HCI effectively promotes research and public policy to address pressing needs of this region, particularly the special cancer burdens of rural/frontier populations. We care deeply about the next generation of cancer researchers and have implemented a portfolio of programs, including special initiatives for rural and disadvantaged youth. Through the Cancer Center Support Grant, we will make high-impact scientific discoveries across basic laboratory; clinical; and prevention, cancer control, and population-based research, and disseminate these findings to improve outcomes for individuals impacted by cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because novel targets and new treatment options for retinal inflammatory diseases are critically needed. Completion of the initiatives proposed will provide new chemical tools that can be employed to advance our understanding of the cGAS-STING pathway in retinal diseases and new hits/therapeutic leads poised for further development/optimization. New therapies with novel mechanisms of action are expected to address the limitations of current therapies, relieve the burden on health care systems worldwide, and improve patient quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Periodontitis (PD), cognitive decline and dementias (CD) are prevalent health burdens, with PD affecting approximately 75% of the US population over 65 years of age and CD occurring in more than 40% of those 85 years and older. PD is a chronic inflammatory condition of the tooth-supporting tissue and compelling evidence highlights the relationship of PD with poor systemic health and contributions to cognitive decline and neurodegenerative disorders, of which the periodontal pathogenic bacteria Treponema are linked. In this proposal, we will study cellular pathways targeted by Treponema to promote dysfunction of Blood Bran Barrier and neurovascular cellular components, with the goal to provide new foundational information to further characterize microbial pathogenic mechanisms driving neurological disease to positively impact public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The biological basis underlying sex disparities in asthma, and specifically the roles of estrogen receptors, remain poorly understood. In this proposal, we explore in depth the mechanisms by which estrogen triggers inflammation in the male and female asthmatic lung via the membrane-bound G Protein-Coupled Estrogen Receptor (GPER). Our results will facilitate an enhanced understanding of the molecular basis of hormonal triggers of asthma exacerbations and lead to the potential development of sex-specific therapeutic options.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cerebral palsy (CP) is the most common life-long neuromotor condition that permanently affects children's physical The etiology of the majority of CP remains unknown, and research focusing on environmental risk factors has been sparse with no study on air pollution, despite being one of the most widespread environmental pollutants that can adversely affect preterm birth and fetal brain development. We propose to establish the largest population-based study of CP and air pollution using California birth records, and CP diagnosis records from the California Department of Developmental Services, and utilize a sophisticated land- use-regression model to investigate whether prenatal exposure to major ambient air pollutants poses a risk for CP development. mobility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project narrative Nearly 2 out of 3 patients with Alzheimer’s disease (AD) experience problems with balance and mobility, which places them at increased risk of falling. The vestibular (inner ear balance) system plays an important role in balance stability, and vestibular therapy is well-known to improve balance function in healthy older adults. In this study, we will conduct a first-in-kind randomized clinical trial to evaluate whether vestibular therapy reduces fall rates in patients with AD, in whom this treatment has never been studied.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Children who are born preterm are at a high risk of development sensorimotor deficits, including developmental coordination disorder (DCD), one of the most common yet least studied developmental motor disorder. This study aims to investigate the predictive relationship between somatosensory processing deficits during early childhood in preterm children, and later motor development. Better understanding of the relationship between somatosensory deficits and motor development will allow us to identify children who experience these difficulties before they show significant motor delays and to develop tailored interventions for them.

PHR: Project Narrative: Elderly individuals and mice have attenuated humoral responses accompanied by a rapid decline in antibody titers. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Despite its high heritability, the genetic foundations of schizophrenia (SCZ) remain largely unknown. While genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have identified loci linked to SCZ risk, our capacity to interpret and pinpoint causal variants and target genes lags behind our ability to identify disease- associated loci. Our lab employs CRISPR-Cas9 technologies to dissect candidate cis-regulatory elements in SCZ-associated loci and elucidate their target genes, promising insights into the genetic basis of SCZ.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE . Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) is the most common type of lymphoma with a very poor prognosis for patients who are diagnosed with relapsed or refractory (r/r) disease. Here we propose to test a promising treatment approach combining a clinical stage intravenously administered oncolytic Vesicular stomatitis virus (VSV) with a novel dually targeted checkpoint inhibitor (ONIx) in dogs with r/r DLBCL, to guide clinical development of this novel combination therapy for patients with r/r DLBCL. Detailed analyses to characterize the impact of combination therapy on the DLBCL tumor architecture and comparison of features of tumor microenvironment in responding versus nonresponding dogs will allow us to identify potential, clinically actionable biomarkers of response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed next generation blood-brain barrier-traversing and brain tumor penetrating nanoplatform addresses autophagy-dependent drug resistance and tumor recurrence and exhibits great potential to be translated into an effective treatment modality that could be easily integrated into the standard of care of high- grade gliomas. Due to the genetic and physiological similarities to humans, dogs with spontaneous high-grade gliomas are an ideal translational model that will accelerate the development of the proposed new therapeutic approaches. The team of experts in neuro-oncology (Dr. Bloch) and veterinary neurology (Dr. Toedebusch) will provide comprehensive expertise to facilitate the clinical development of the proposed novel nano-therapeutics that will ultimately benefit many human and canine patients with brain tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sweeping federal and state policy changes in 2020 brought on by the COVID-19 pandemic led to unprecedented access to telehealth care, allowing hundreds of thousands of people with opioid use disorder to connect to buprenorphine prescribers from their phone, tablet, or computer. However, research has not yet identified which telehealth policies worked best, and whether they worked equally well for people in rural areas, minorities, and low-income individuals. Thus, we will identify which combinations of telehealth policies were most effective at increasing buprenorphine receipt and reducing overdoses, while accounting for other changes in 2020, and then we will interview state authorities and experts to learn how to make these policy packages as effective as possible going forward.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: CE24-012 - Evaluating Telehealth's Role in Buprenorphine Treatment Initiation and Retention, Overdose Mortality, and Access Equity: An Analysis for Policy Development

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. In rare but deadly instances, lung cancer can spread to the cerebrospinal fluid, and this form of metastatic disease is difficult to diagnose and treat. My research focuses on advancing our understanding of how exactly cells enter and survive in the cerebrospinal fluid and the mechanisms by which developing resistance to targeted treatments can increase the likelihood of cells making this journey. The results of this research will hopefully lead to identification of novel treatment targets for this currently incurable disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  The proposed diversity extension will develop zebrafish model for human venous malformation (VM), which shows enlarged vascular lumen, and will test the role of SH2 domain protein E (SHE) and Abelson (ABL) kinase signaling in the zebrafish VM model. The acquired knowledge will promote development of new strategies aimed at treating vascular malformations as well as bioengineering new vessels for regenerative therapies. The diversity extension will also enable a training of a candidate with underrepresented minority background, thus helping to foster diversity in science.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – P01, Clinical Care Gaps and Unmet Needs in AYA Cancer Survivors  This program of research is focused on the cancer care experience of adolescents and young adults (AYAs) who are diagnosed with cancer during the ages of 15 to 39 years. It involves three research projects, focusing on different aspects of care relevant to AYAs: preservation of fertility and impact on cancer care, coordination of care among multiple providers including during the transition from active cancer treatment to surveillance and follow-up, and late effects that AYA cancer survivors may experience. These projects are supported by three cores that provide biostatistical, survey, and administrative support to program activities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Target-directed microRNA degradation (TDMD) is a mechanism by which endogenous target RNAs degrade specific microRNAs to modulate gene expression. Treatment of T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (T-ALL) cells by glucocorticoid induces apoptosis through BIM expression, which can lead to microRNA-221/222 degradation via TDMD. We will examine how microRNA-221/222 degradation may contribute to T-ALL apoptosis, globally profile TDMD events and explore the role of TDMD during glucocorticoid-treatment of T-ALL.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The proposed supplement will provide support and resources to a graduate student to investigate the extent to which developmental changes in cell death regulation drive radiation therapy-induced neurotoxicity, as well as how sensitivity to toxic effects may differ by neural cell type. This proposal aligns well with the objectives of the original R37 award and has the potential to uncover novel mechanisms linking cellular differentiation with apoptosis suppression. The training will help the candidate develop the necessary skills to advance their career in molecular biology research, with a focus on cancer biology, radiation biology and neurotoxicology.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Summary Sumadhur is a group intervention for multiple households of newly married women, their husbands and mothers-in-law aimed to improve women’s status and norms, household relationships, and behaviors and knowledge around nutrition and eating, developed and piloted in rural Nepal. This proposal aims to test the effectiveness of Sumadhur on young newly married, preconception women’s anemia and micronutrient status, combined with access to micronutrient supplements, and measure pathways of change.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE It remains largely unclear which genetic factors underlie well-established sex differences in Alzheimer’s disease (AD). This proposal will fill in this gap by using a series of state-of-the-art innovative approaches to discover sex- specific genetic risk variants for AD, including performing the largest sex-stratified genome-wide association study of AD to date, studying for the first time the role of X-chromosome and sex-specific rare variant effects on AD, and using rich proteomics data to discover new AD risk genes. Findings from this work will help gain important insights into the pathophysiology of AD, identify novel sex-specific risk factors relevant to personalized genetic medicine, and uncover potential new AD drug targets that may more optimally benefit both sexes.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: CCR5 is a chemokine receptor that has a critical role in neuroprotection against a wide range of neurotropic flaviviruses in mice and humans. In this application, we will generate essential tools to investigate the critical role of Ccr5 in mice that will allow us to dissect the precise role of Ccr5 during infection and inflammation. Our proposal seeks to generate tools that will propel our understanding of Ccr5 biology both at homeostasis and during inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project is relevant to public health because it addresses a novel mechanism by which interactions of aggressive cancers such as acute myeloid leukemia (AML) with their niche can promote disease progression. If successful, this work will provide a scientific basis for development of new strategies to treat these aggressive cancers with less than 25% survival rates. This is highly relevant to the NIH mission of developing fundamental knowledge to help reduce the burdens of human disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative I have identified the number of B cell antigen receptor binding sites (BCRbs) as a new parameter that is actively organized at the surface of B lymphocytes to optimize antigen recognition, seeding the production of antibody responses and the development of humoral immunity. Key to this work has been my innovation of a molecular tool to experimentally count the absolute number of BCRbs on the B cell surface. In this proposal, I will apply my tool to define how BCRbs number is enhanced to promote antigen reception during B cell development and how this parameter also serves to organize the antibody affinity-driven selection that follows immune challenge.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This supplemental award will support the research training of Ms. Caitlyn Castellion, a freshman intending to major in Biochemistry at the Colorado School of Mines. Women, particularly Hispanic women such as Ms. Cas- tellion are severely under-represented at Mines, where student demographics skew white male. Over a period of 18 months, Ms. Castellion will be trained in polymer brush synthesis, lithographic techniques needed for na- nopatterning, hMSC Culture and characterization, and polymer-mediated gene delivery, allowing her to acquire meaningful and authentic research experiences in preparation for her PhD and post-graduate training.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE - No Changes have been made Ovarian cancer affects only women for which cisplatin is a commonly used chemotherapeutic drug but it causes neurotoxicity leading to painful neuropathy, cognitive decline, called `chemobrain' and alterations in gait with increased propensity to fall/fractures, which may continue even after the discontinuation of treatment. We hypothesize that the activation of p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase and c-Jun N-terminal kinase plays a critical role in cisplatin-induced damage to the nervous system and that inhibition of these pathways will attenuate cisplatin-induced neurotoxic side effects in female mice with ovarian cancer. We expect that the results of our study will lead to the development of novel therapeutics to reduce the debilitating sequelae of cisplatin in women with ovarian and other cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The prevalence of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (AD/ADRD) is growing and we observe racial disparities where Black Americans have higher incidence than white Americans. Evidence suggests early life exposures may play a role in the development of AD/ADRD. This administrative proposal will allow us to spatially link social and environmental exposures to Health and Retirement Study participant residences in 1940, with the potential to identify key modifiable factors related to ADRD and ADRD disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mounting evidence links perturbations in early life host-microbiota interactions with increased susceptibility to immune-mediated diseases later in life, yet we lack a mechanistic understanding of how mutually beneficial relationships between gut bacteria and the neonatal immune system are formed. Building from our discovery that maternal antibodies, delivered via breastfeeding, are key regulators of intestinal homeostasis, this proposal seeks to define the cellular and molecular mechanisms by which maternal antibodies restrain aberrant immune responses to gut bacteria in early life. The resulting data will advance our understanding of the immunological processes that regulate nascent host-microbiota interactions, thereby aiding in our ability to manipulate mucosal immune responses in early life to promote long-term health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Withdrawal from persistent opioid use causes an intense negative emotional state, but we do not fully understand the brain systems involved in this response. Prior work identified increased excitatory transmission into a brain region known for producing stress-induced anxiety. The goal of this proposal is to better understand how fentanyl withdrawal modifies this excitatory brain system to drive negative emotional states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: This proposed project will lead to a novel two-photon miniaturized microscope that can simultaneously record and manipulate neural activity in freely-behaving mice with high spatial and temporal resolution over a large brain volume. The microscope will be compact and light-weight, and can be mounted on the mice head. This project will enable neuroscientists to mechanistically study the brain circuit under the mice’s natural behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease will affect an estimated 14 million Americans by the year 2050, contributing to economic burden and reduced quality of life for patients and caregivers. As the U.S. population ages, it is critically important to identify who is at greatest risk for Alzheimer’s disease-associated cognitive decline. Studying novel markers of risk for cognitive decline in cognitively normal older adults may identify those who would benefit most from early detection and treatment strategies for Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Many cancers have alterations in genetic pathways for repairing DNA damage that leave them sensitive to specific treatments. However, we are currently unable to reliably determine which genetic defects are present in a given cancer sample, which limits our ability to exploit these therapeutic vulnerabilities. Here we will make use of hitherto unexplored genomic features and novel statistical techniques to distinguish between cancers with different genetic alterations and identify clinically relevant biomarkers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: Project Narrative There exists a large gap in the scientific evidence base related to how state-level, economic supports (ES) policy options (i.e., state-level refundable Earned Income Tax Credit, paid family leave, child care subsides, Child Tax Credit, and minimum wage) collectively impact violence against children (i.e., child maltreatment [CM] and intimate partner violence [IPV]) (Fortson et al., 2016; Niolon et al., 2017; Puls et al. 2021). We propose a rigorous evaluation of the combined effects of state-level ES ‘policy ecosystems’ (i.e., multiple, co-occurring, ES policy options) on rates of CM and IPV through a through a systematic review of the extant literature linking state-level ES policy options with CM and IPV (Aim 1), a data-driven, landscape assessment of within and between state variation in ES policy ecosystems across time (2002- present) (Aim 2), and quasi-experimental, multilevel time-series analyses examining the impact of shifting state-level ES policy ecosystems on the within-state reduction of CM and IPV (Aim 3). Results from these analyses will provide new insights into the collective effects of state ES policy options, furthering evidence for addressing societal factors as a strategy in the primary prevention of CM and IPV.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-CE-24-034: Evaluating the Effects of Ecosystems of State Policy Strategies on Preventing Multiple Forms of Violence Against Children

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The parent research project and proposed supplement is highly relevant to public health in its ability to determine the role of motherhood biographies as a key mechanism in explaining racial-ethnic and socioeconomic health disparities among midlife women, particularly aging Black women. This proposed supplemental research will identify the most health-disadvantaged subpopulations of midlife mothers and nonmothers with attention to differences at the intersec- tion of race-ethnicity and socioeconomic status. In doing so, this R01 informs interventions and public policies designed to improve women’s health and reduce racial-ethnic health disparities in midlife and beyond, a key goal of NIA, while contributing to the development of a minority junior scholar specifically in the area of aging and life course research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alterations of a microtubule-binding protein tau are one of hallmarks of Alzheimer’s disease (AD), with progressive memory deficits being one of its major symptoms. Tau is key facilitator of neuronal transport, mediated by microtubules, and regulation of the microtubule cytoskeleton and microtubule-mediated transport is implicated in AD. Because changes in microtubule stability are critical for synapse function and memory and are disrupted in AD, we propose to examine how manipulations of microtubule stability affect microtubule- mediated synaptic protein localization, synaptic function and memory in mice modeling some of the AD-related mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative/Public Health Relevance for Parent Grant Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease is a major cause of morbidity worldwide and the 3rd leading cause of death in the United States. There are no cures for this disease and the standard forms of treatment often do not provide adequate relief, as much of the morbidity and mortality is due to mucus obstruction of the airways. There are currently no specific and effective therapies available for excess mucus production. The proposed work aims to identify new ways to treat this disorder by investigating the source of inflammation and mucus overproduction in the airways, thereby addressing a previously unmet need for treatment of a major public health problem. Project Narrative/Public Health Relevance for Supplement Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease is a major cause of morbidity worldwide and the 3rd leading cause of death in the United States. There are no cures for this disease and the standard forms of treatment often do not provide adequate relief, as much of the morbidity and mortality is due to mucus obstruction of the airways. The proposed work aims to identify new ways to detect and potentially treat this disorder by investigating the source of inflammation and mucus overproduction in the airways, thereby addressing a previously unmet need for treatment of a major public health problem.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: Project Narrative PHLHousing+ -- a housing-focused guaranteed income experiment – provides a unique opportunity to test whether unconditional monthly cash payments, Housing Choice Vouchers, or both reduce exposure to violence for low income renters who, in the City of Philadelphia, are disproportionately Black. Data from randomized controlled trials of housing programs are sorely needed to evaluate effects on exposure to violence in the family and the community. Study findings will have immediate implications for the City of Philadelphia's model for providing housing assistance, will inform efforts to establish similar programs in other cities as well as federal approaches to rental assistance, and will provide actionable information about the effectiveness of targeting housing security in efforts to prevent exposure to violence.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-CE-24-034 :Evaluating the impact of PHLHousing+ on child welfare involvement

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Infantile rhabdomyosarcoma (RMS) is a newly identified and poorly understood aggressive pediatric muscle cancer that affects young children. There is one single mutation that causes the disease, but we do not have specialized treatments targeting this genetic event, and patients are treated with general strategies that are often ineffective or have harsh life-long side effects. We will leverage novel zebrafish and mouse cancer models to help young children with cancer by understanding the biology of how infantile RMS develops and implementing these models to identify clinically tractable therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Persistent no-show rates contribute to the oral health disparities and inadequate access to dental care that disproportionately affect underserved populations. The proposed research will test the impact of three different strategies on no-show rates using an innovative full factorial design and a standardized implementation approach called the NIATx model. Findings from this study seek to provide an evidence-based approach to reducing no-shows and increasing access to dental care for underserved populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Inflammation underlies the pathology of almost all diseases and can be both resolving and damaging in tissues. In inflammatory lung diseases, cells of the immune system are recruited and migrate into tissue, where they can perform complex functions. A better understanding of the migration of these cells into the lungs during inflammatory airspace lung diseases may improve our ability to understand and treat conditions like bronchopneumonia and gastric aspiration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE Ovarian cancer is a significant cause of morbidity and mortality that affects nearly 300,000 women worldwide each year, and its poor outcomes are related to delayed diagnosis and development of resistance to conventional therapy with carboplatin, paclitaxel and PARP inhibitors. We have discovered that GRN-300, a SIK-2 inhibitor, enhances PARP inhibitor olaparib activity. The proposed research will improve outcomes for women with ovarian cancer by understanding the underlying mechanisms by which GRN-300 overcomes olaparib resistance in ovarian cancer and will provide initial proof-of concept for a novel therapeutic approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (from Parent Grant) Latinos have the highest risk of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) in the United States, and inferior outcomes compared with non-Latino whites. In this study, we will leverage the unique evolutionary history of Native Americans to carry out a comprehensive study of the role of germline genetic variation in the increased risk of childhood ALL in Latinos. Our results will help to elucidate the causes of this significant ethnic disparity and to identify children most at risk of developing ALL.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Wildfire smoke has become a major source of particulate matter under 2.5 microns diameter (PM2.5) emissions and is expected to increase in the future because of climate change. Although the effects of ambient wildfire smoke inhalation on the development of chronic disease are largely unknown, toxic plumes resulting from the combustion of building materials, vehicles, and electronics in conjunction with biomass burning are likely to be a significant threat to human health. The goal of this R21 application is to investigate a potential mechanism for lung cellular toxicity resulting from ambient wildfire smoke exposure, which ultimately may lead to the identification of biomarkers and preventative measures to protect human health, particularly in vulnerable populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Uveitis results in significant economic burden worldwide and can lead to long-term vision impairment. Main challenges have been the lack of adequate diagnostics and mechanistic understanding of the underlying uveitis entities. This project takes advantage of recent advances in genomic and programmable phage display technologies to identify important autoantigen and autoantibody profiles to address those gaps with the overall goal of improving patient visual outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mexican American older adults are expected to demonstrate the largest increase in dementia cases over the next 20 years, but little is known about the specific environmental, biological, individual, and sociocultural factors contributing to this risk. While participation in physical, cognitive, and social activities has been shown to influence the likelihood of developing dementia, the reliance on self-report questionnaires to assess these outcomes has prevented the development of specific recommendations regarding the necessary type, amount, and length of activity. We now propose to evaluate real-world physical, cognitive, and social activity patterns in Mexican American older adults using a validated digital technology platform to provide insights into targeted dementia prevention within this high-risk, underserved demographic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In August 2023, the deadliest wildfire in United States history incinerated the historical town of Lāhainā in Maui, Hawai‘i, which caused significant physical, mental, and environmental health problems that have strained the island’s already fragile health, social, and emergency systems. This study will use community engagement, interviews, focus groups, a survey, and analysis of administrative data to understand how the experiences and perceptions of residents, responders, and other frontline stakeholders have shaped Maui’s disaster-related (1) preparedness, response, and recovery; (2) individual, community, and health, social, and emergency system resilience, and (3) population health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer incidence is expected to increase to 23.6 million by 2030 worldwide, and cancer is the leading cause of death for Asian Americans whose numbers are rapidly rising to reach 40 million by 2050. Despite instances of greater cancer-specific mortality compared to other Asians and likely limited access to high- quality care due many experiencing language barriers (~50%), very little is known about supportive care needs in Chinese-, Vietnamese-, and Korean-Americans with metastatic cancers. This project will fill a critical gap in our understanding, and develop culturally relevant psychosocial resources/interventions aimed at improving the quality of life of Asian Americans with metastatic cancers.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Spinal cord injuries (SCI) and related disorders affect over 300,000 Americans, and the VA treats over 27,000 veterans with SCI every year. After SCI, rapid bone loss in the lower limbs greatly increases bone fragility and fracture risk. Current strategies to reduce post-SCI bone loss have shown limited success, thus novel approaches are needed. Irisin is a hormonal factor released from active muscle with potent effects on bone formation. Though irisin has been shown to prevent or reverse bone loss in animals, the relationship between irisin and bone health in humans with SCI is largely unknown. Determining whether factors related to irisin release are impaired by SCI, establishing a relationship between irisin and lower limb bone health, and identifying viable methods to effectively increase circulating irisin through exercise, could improve musculoskeletal rehabilitation strategies to combat post-SCI bone loss.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Women Veterans are a fast growing population in VA and one that has healthcare needs distinct from the rest of the predominantly male population. In order to provide high-quality care for women, the VA has developed a specific program for women’s healthcare which includes designated women’s health providers and separate clinic structures for women. While the quality of women’s health care in VA has improved significantly in the last few decades, barriers to optimal care exist. Specifically, women Veterans face obstacles to receiving health care due to disproportionate caregiver responsibilities, work-life balance issues, and exposure to discrimination such as stranger harassment on VA grounds. Providing women Veterans the opportunity to use virtual care for the right health care concerns at the right time could create new ways for women to access timely needed care. This project seeks to create a package of approaches to improving when and how virtual care is offered to women Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is increasing in incidence due to the sequalae of chronic liver disease, with no significant recent improvement in patient survival due to a lack of biomarker-driven therapeutics. ꞵ-catenin- activation (mutated CTNNB1 oncogene) represents a molecular subset of HCC cases which are resistant to current immunotherapies. This proposal will investigate mechanisms of ꞵ-catenin activation driving immunosuppression in the tumor immune microenvironment, with our results paving the way for precision medicine therapeutics for ꞵ-catenin-mutated HCC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Compared to European American (EA) men, African American/Black (AA/B) men have a 4x higher risk of metastatic prostate cancer (PCa) and 2-3x higher death rate from the disease. To identify which individuals are at the highest risk of developing aggressive PCa, we developed an adductomics approach to measure markers that are produced from altered metabolism and inflammation. We are now working to develop a multicomponent framework to determine the risk of PCa onset and progression in AA/B and EA men and to identify the important cellular components in this process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Overall NARRATIVE. Women are at twice the risk of the co-occurrence of depression and autonomic dysregulation, which is associated with a 3-5-fold risk of death from heart disease later in life, often with unrecognized and untreated depression. This SCORE will conduct a set of basic science and clinical studies that are synergistic for understanding the risk for sex differences in depression and associated health outcomes over the lifespan. We will identify pathways that will lead to translation into sex-selective therapeutics and will train the next generation to incorporate knowledge of sex differences into how we think about and treat disorders of the brain and their impact on general medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal is relevant to public health because ALS has few therapies with only modest benefits despite decades of research. Barriers arise from multifarious pathologies and conflicting literature, often due to inconsistent methods and unaccounted for biological variables. This project will develop advanced 3D quantitation of immunohistochemistry images to rigorously examine somatic morphology and potassium channel structure in normal vs. ALS motoneurons, to elucidate pilot data from the parent grant suggesting that Kv2.1 and SK contribute to functional changes in ALS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: The proposed studies will determine whether there are causal effects of exposure to air pollutants and temperature on mortality, heart attacks and strokes and whether those effects persist below current ambient standards. They will also identify whether there are interactions between the different exposures, whether some particle components are more toxic that others, and whether error in exposure estimates either prevents the identification of effects at low levels or biases effect estimates upwards. This will be done using state of the art mixture, causal modeling and measurement error methods, uniquely combining them for the first time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Midwest Microbial Pathogenesis Conference (MMPC) is a distinguished regional scientific meeting that promotes research at the intersection of disease and pathogenesis mechanisms. The focus of MMPC aligns with the mission of the National Institutes of Health to research the causes of diseases to improve human health and to develop fundamental and innovative scientific resources for the biomedical community. MMPC brings together hundreds of researchers with an emphasis on trainees and junior investigators to develop connections to nurture career development and research progress, all while fostering an environment of diversity, equity, and inclusion for the exchange of scientific ideas and collaborations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative. Taste disorders can have detrimental effects on a person's health and quality of life. The underlying mechanisms of these disorders are not understood but may result from disruption of the connections between taste buds and the neurons carrying taste information to the brain. Here, we are exploring the relationship between taste neuron structure, connectivity, and function to elucidate the role of connectivity in taste disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Hypertension shortens life expectancy and increases the risk for cardiovascular disease and stroke. This project examines how social adversity or the chronic relegation to low social status may impact specific brain areas to induce sustained hypertension. We hypothesize that the disruption within a specific angiotensin sensitive neural circuit contributes to high blood pressure and may therefore be targeted to treat the disease

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative A recent outbreak of eye infections stemming from the use of contaminated bottles of artificial tears - these infections were caused by a particularly dangerous bacterium that is resistant to the antibiotics that clinicians generally use to treat eye infections. Unusually, these infections have spread beyond the eye resulting in death in some cases. The goal of this study is to learn more about how the bacteria causes infection and how to treat it.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: The proposed research will lay a foundation for developing innovative, individualized interventions to improve nonverbal communication (NVC) experiences for autistic adults, based on the values and first-hand experiences of our target population. Improvements in NVC are necessary for downstream improvements in a range of func- tional contexts, resulting in overall improved life outcomes associated with autism in adulthood. This project is relevant to NIDCD’s mission pertaining to intervention, and to the NIH’s Interagency Autism Coordinating Com- mittee’s dual missions related to intervention and lifespan issues. This project will produce a set of specific, stakeholder-driven recommendations for designing and prioritizing NVC intervention development, opening new horizons for how NVC is conceptualized and addressed in autism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative (parent grant) The overall goal of this proposal is to dissect the molecular mechanisms of metabolic regulation of ATP-citrate lyase (ACLY) and to characterize ACLY inhibitors for cancer therapy. Together, these studies will elucidate how cellular metabolites, and posttranscriptional and posttranslational modification, tune ACLY activity and will lead to the rational development of ACLY drugs to treat cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cervical cancer incidence rates are increasing in Puerto Rico, while screening uptake remains suboptimal. The proposed diversity supplement will promote Jeslie Ramos Cartagena's career development in cancer health disparities and health services research. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative of Parent U01 AG071450 The overall goal of this project is to collect and disseminate critical data on cognitive, physical, and sensory functioning and risk for Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD) in Wave VI of the National Longitudinal Study of Adolescent to Adult Health (Add Health), when participants will be in their mid-40s. These new data, when combined with Add Health’s existing collection of extraordinarily rich multi-level and longitudinal measures and its new Wave VI data, will facilitate the scientific community’s understanding of the interplay of social, economic, behavioral, and biological factors that influence cognitive, physical, and sensory functioning in midlife and lead to ADRD in later life. Moreover, because Add Health is a diverse nationally representative sample, adding these data to Wave VI will greatly increase understanding of cognitive, physical, and sensory functioning within key health disparity populations in the United States.

PHR: Project Narrative Intimate partner violence (IPV) contributes to maternal morbidity and pregnancy-associated deaths, particularly among populations with health disparities, but remains understudied. The Remap-IPV training aims to address this evidence gap through hybrid instruction and mentorship of underrepresented early career researchers. Training a diverse cohort of new investigators around IPV ethics and measurement rigor will contribute to IMPROVE goals of health equity and reducing preventable causes of maternal morbidity and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposed research is relevant to human health because clinical pharmacogenetic testing may improve the personalization of drug therapy which should improve patient outcomes. Better understanding of the effectiveness and feasibility of clinical pharmacogenetic testing in the emergency department will inform when and how this innovative healthcare technology is implemented into clinical care, particularly in acute care settings. The combined proposed research are relevant to the parts of the NIH’s mission pertaining to protecting and improving health and developing scientific human resources that will ensure the Nation's capability to prevent and treat disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Mechanical properties and forces the body are often modulated during disease initiation and progression. However, little is known about the response of immune cells to these mechanical cues, particularly at the tissue- length scale, and even in normal physiological settings. Establishing an omics-based understanding of functional immunological changes in response to mechanical perturbations will broaden our knowledge of “mechano- immunology” – a burgeoning subfield in basic biomedical sciences that in the near future will reveal new pathophysiological insights and targetable vulnerabilities for human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: The purpose of this R01 supplemental proposal is to deepen our knowledge of the primary cause of drug overdose deaths in the U.S. today: novel psychoactive synthetic opioids, the majority of which are fentanyl analogues. Using a nationwide registry of patients who present to emergency departments, novel fentanyl analogue overdose will be studied in terms of its epidemiology, analytical confirmation, clinical risk factors, and treatment needs, by a uniquely qualified multidisciplinary team with an extensive track record of collaboration in the field. The overall specific aims of this proposal, are three-fold: (1) state-of-the-art toxicology analytics, as well as biomarkers of clinical severity; (2) treatment requirements such as naloxone, need for critical care and/or mechanical ventilation; and (3) regional and temporal trends nationwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Identifying and targeting signaling pathways regulated by the mitotic kinases Nek2 and TTK, which are overexpressed in non-Hispanic Black (NHB) and Hispanic/Latina (H/L) with breast cancer will reduce breast cancer health disparities by preventing early metastatic progression in NHB, Caribbean-H/L, and other H/L breast cancer patients. The investigators aim to elucidate these pathways using cell lines, and PDX models of breast cancer established from NHB and H/L patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cervical cancers are a leading cause of death among women worldwide, and in the U.S. affects more Black and Hispanic women than other groups. Treatment by implantation of radioactivity into the tumor with MR-guidance (MR- brachytherapy) has significantly improved survival. We accelerate MR-brachytherapy with better tumor detection and will integrate in Dr. Gardner’s overall goal to improve access to advanced radiation therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In collaboration with Eolas Therapeutics and the NIH Blueprint Neurotherapeutics Network, AstraZeneca developed AZD4041, a novel treatment for opioid use disorder. In preclinical studies, AZD4041 decreased the motivational properties of opioids and has proven safe in a single ascending dose Phase 1 clinical study. In this proposal, we will conduct the additional clinical safety and early proof-of-concept clinical studies necessary to advance AZD4041 to the clinic as a potentially transformative treatment for opioid use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Parents, pediatricians, and clinicians are concerned when children begin to talk late, a condition that affects 15% to 20% of children. Yet, little is known about bilingual late-talkers, their ability to learn information in both languages, and persistence vs. resolution of their language delay. This project examines how Spanish-English bilingual toddlers with typical language, bilingual late-talker, and bilingual children with Developmental Language Disorder (DLD) learn novel words in English and Spanish and what conditions can best facilitate their learning, with a particular interest in identifying risk and protective factors in bilingual late-talkers’ language outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PHS Relevance Statement Colorectal cancer (CRC) prevails as the third most common and deadliest cancer worldwide, affecting both men and women. Despite scientific breakthroughs, gaps in knowledge remain due to the multiple accumulation of molecular alterations occurring at onset and during disease progression. This study will investigate the role of the transcription factor STAT2 as a signaling mediator in the communication exchange between cancer cells and fibroblasts in the tumor microenvironment to accelerate disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE. Juvenile-onset recurrent respiratory papillomatosis (JoRRP), caused by human papillomaviruses, are benign airway tumors whose repeated growth requires young patients to undergo frequent surgeries and can lead to malignancy and death. Using surgical specimens from dozens of JoRRP donors, we recently established rigorous laboratory models that, for the first time, allow for the studies required to develop much needed cures/drug treatments and also predictive biomarkers. With these break-though models, we propose to build on our substantial preliminary data to determine how viral and cellular factors coordinate to promote RRP disease, and to use the resulting data to explore diagnostic tools and therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE GATA1 is a gene that is essential for red blood cell development, and mutations in GATA1 cause a spectrum of blood diseases in humans. In this proposal, we study the effect of one type of GATA1 mutations that lead to the loss of the N-terminal domain. We seek to define the function of this domain in red blood cell development and to understand how it controls metabolism and differentiation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Poverty and income inequality have wide-ranging and disproportionate effects on children and families, including environmental, social-emotional, and behavioral health sequela that elevate risk for community violence. At the same time, limited evidence suggests that strategies addressing structural and social determinants of health by enhancing economic opportunity and helping families avoid financial stress can prevent violence and promote well-being and intersectional racial equity. This project evaluates whether and how two of the largest anti-poverty public policies in the United States—the Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC) and Additional Child Tax Credit (ACTC)—affect the determinants, consequences, and prevention of community violence and racial/ethnic inequities in community violence among low-income families.

PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-CE-24-030, Preventing Community Violence and Advancing Racial and Health Equity:  The Role of Anti-Poverty Policy

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Fibrotic lung disease is responsible for significant morbidity and mortality, with very few treatment options other than lung transplantation. Abnormal alveolar epithelial differentiation pathways have been implicated in many of these diseases, suggesting that impaired alveolar regeneration may be an important driver of fibrogenesis. We propose to better characterize metaplastic differentiation pathways of the resident epithelial stem cell of the lung alveolus, the alveolar type II (AT2) cell, by using a combination of novel lineage tracing approaches and advanced techniques for epigenetic profiling, with the goal of identifying putative targets for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hair growth is driven by the tightly regulated proliferative behaviors of hair follicle stem cells, which behave differently based on biological sex. The proposed research will investigate the molecular mechanisms that drive sexually dimorphic hair follicle stem cell behavior. This work will reveal how genetic and physiological sex differences are integrated into stem cell biology, opening novel avenues for targeted treatment of skin conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Tick-borne diseases are arthropod-borne illnesses of public and veterinary health relevance. In the next phase of this project (R01 competing renewal), we will examine how tick feeding impacts skin homeostasis during microbial transmission and continue to provide exciting discoveries in the field of arthropod vector biology. Specifically, we will: (i) investigate the influence of tick EVs on the interaction between dendritic epidermal T cells and keratinocytes; and (ii) assess the effect of tick EVs on keratinocyte proliferation, migration, and differentiation during microbial transmission.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Clostridioides difficile is a major public health concern that can cause intestinal diseases including diarrhea and pseudomembranous colitis. C. difficile develops two colony morphologies that exhibit differences in multiple virulence-associated phenotypes. The objective of the proposed study is to identify and characterize genes necessary for colony dimorphism, which may reveal new targets for development of therapeutics for C. difficile infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE - No Changes have been made Ovarian cancer affects only women for which cisplatin is a commonly used chemotherapeutic drug but it causes neurotoxicity leading to painful neuropathy, cognitive decline, called `chemobrain' and alterations in gait with increased propensity to fall/fractures, which may continue even after the discontinuation of treatment. We hypothesize that the activation of p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase and c-Jun N-terminal kinase plays a critical role in cisplatin-induced damage to the nervous system and that inhibition of these pathways will attenuate cisplatin-induced neurotoxic side effects in female mice with ovarian cancer. We expect that the results of our study will lead to the development of novel therapeutics to reduce the debilitating sequelae of cisplatin in women with ovarian and other cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In rheumatoid arthritis (RA), delaying initiation of treatment for ≥12 weeks is associated with irreversible joint damage due to greater difficulty in achieving remission, but navigating the hurdles of the US healthcare system in this short timeframe can be challenging for rural residents due to the closure of rural hospitals nationwide extending the distance to healthcare facilities and the time to travel and obtain care. The growing rheumatology workforce shortage further aggravates these issues, as <10% of rheumatologists practice in rural or micropolitan areas yet 30% of the US population lives in these areas. Our goal is to reduce healthcare disparities to improve outcomes in patients with RA by (1) identifying rural healthcare disparities in the diagnosis and treatment of early RA, (2) developing and validating an AI algorithm to enable early identification of RA, and (3) assessing long- term outcomes in patients with RA living in rural vs. urban areas compared to those without RA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Global mortality among immunocompromised and HIV+ populations by Cryptococcus neoformans (Cn) remains high but development of novel immunomodulatory therapeutics is hampered by 1) poor understanding of the immune responses against Cn and 2) a lack of mouse models that recapitulate human Cn disease. The proposed research addresses this through development of a new Cn-infection mouse model that produces human-like lung granulomas and defining the immune response in these protective granulomas. We also mimic disease in advanced HIV patients to understand how immune deficiency causes granuloma breakdown leading to disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Osteoarthritis affects over 250 million people worldwide, and despite extensive research, a lack of under- standing of the molecular mechanisms underlying its risk factors has hindered the development of effective treatments. This study aims to identify novel genetic variants and splicing events that influence osteoarthritis risk by correlating genetic background, splicing patterns, and disease status. The results of this study are expected to provide new genes and pathways for future research and therapeutic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (unchanged from Parent R37) Plasticity is emerging as a crucial hallmark of advanced cancer, but the molecular mechanisms that enable dynamic cancer cell adaptation to the stresses of metastasis are not understood. We will leverage patient samples, organoids, and insights we have generated to define key epigenetic nodes that determine the emergence of regenerative plasticity in MetSCs, and define the phenotypic consequences of transcriptional reprogramming during metastatic outgrowth. Results will define mechanisms of cancer progression and identify putative therapeutic targets to limit regenerative plasticity, with the potential to impact clinical outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: This proposal describes work in which a biologic scaffold composed of mammalian extracellular matrix will be used as an inductive scaffold for the in vivo generation of the temporomandibular joint disc. This inductive template will stimulate the rapid endogenous formation of a fibrocartilaginous disc that closely mimics the structure, composition and function of native disc material. The proposal will provide the first safe treatment following disc removal, improving outcomes for patients by preventing joint damage from long term bone-on-bone articulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To understand the mechanisms of acute and long-term antiviral antibody responses elicited by invading pathogens or vaccines would be useful for the design of vaccines. This project aims to study mechanisms of B cell responses to virus-like particulate antigens, or mock viral particles, and provide training to a minority PharmD/PhD candidate. The successful completion of this project will fill in a gap in our knowledge regarding the initiation of antiviral antibody responses and prepare the candidate for the next step of his career.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Differentiation is a fundamental process evident in a variety of cell states and transitions. Differentiation is a common feature in tumors, which is most pronounced in colorectal cancer, a vexing health problem. We seek to elucidate how LIN28B, an mRNA binding protein, fosters differentiation in colorectal cancers and concurrently, promote metastasis in this differentiated state.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Advanced lethal prostate cancer (PC) exhibits high chromosomal instability (CIN), yet the role of CIN in PC remains poorly understood. This proposal will investigate how CIN shapes transcriptional reprogramming and gene bookmarking, identify new proteins and mechanisms of CIN adaptation, and study CIN impact on the immune cell microenvironment in advanced PC. Combining epigenomics, transcriptomics, proteomics, high- resolution microscopy, and genetics in in vitro and in vivo models our studies will help define novel PC vulnerabilities arising with CIN and uncover new targetable mechanism that may improve PC patients outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immigrants experience significant health disparities which are exacerbated by a heavy stress burden which in turn affects the epigenetic profiles of the immune system leading to chronic diseases. Ethiopians form one of the largest groups of African immigrants in the US, yet this is the first study of this kind among Ethiopian American immigrants. This study will quantify cumulative stress burden and determine DNA methylation associated with stress among Ethiopian American immigrants providing new insight to address health disparities among the steadily increasing US immigrant populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fatigue is the most distressing symptom for individuals with breast cancer, but the physiological pathways associated with fatigue are unclear. This study will inform whether the oral microbiome, a biologic pathway posited to impact fatigue, is associated with fatigue in individuals with breast cancer receiving chemotherapy. The study findings will provide important information that can inform mechanistic underpinnings of fatigue and guide the development of tailored interventions to manage fatigue for individuals with breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As overdose among people experiencing homelessness surges, it is critically important to identify effective strategies to stem the tide of overdose deaths for this highly marginalized population. The proposed community-partnered study will use advanced epidemiological and data science methods together with qualitative interviews to rigorously examine the implementation and effectiveness of a novel, systemwide Harm Reduction Strategic Plan suite of interventions administered across homeless shelters in New York City. The study will produce new practice- and policy-relevant evidence to inform local and national programmatic and policy interventions, laying the groundwork for widespread implementation of place-based overdose prevention strategies to meet the unique needs of individuals experiencing homelessness, a population at disproportionate risk of overdose death.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: CE24-013 - Community-based evaluation of a novel, system-wide harm reduction strategic plan for people experiencing homelessness in New York City

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Pregnancy conditions such as prediabetes, obesity, and gestational diabetes mellitus can exacerbate maternal insulin levels causing changes such as placental inflammation, which can mal-program fetal metabolic tissues and predisposing the offspring to metabolic disease in childhood and adulthood. Yet, very little information is known about the role of insulin signaling in placental inflammation in the offspring of dams with hyperinsulinemia. We expect that the results from the proposed work will ultimately lead to new understanding of the effects of high maternal insulin during pregnancy on placental inflammation that may cause programming of metabolic disease, and this new knowledge could improve clinical management of patients, and thus improve women's reproductive health and pregnancy outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project seeks to identify and develop novel small molecule degraders of FoxP3 to target Tregs, diminishing Treg suppressive function, and increase the anti-tumor immune response. Our short-term goal is to provide rationale for targeting FoxP3 by small molecular glue degraders; and our long-term goal is to develop immunomodulatory therapeutics by harnessing the ubiquitin pathway.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Neuregulin-1β (NRG1) is a promising recombinant protein therapy for myocardial infarction (MI) which suffers from rapid loss of function during conventional intravenous administration, necessitating high dosing, repeated administration, and/or long treatment periods. In this study, I present the development and evaluation of a new engineered injectable liposome-crosslinked hydrogel for sustained NRG1 delivery into the infarcted myocardium. Success of this proposed study would enhance the outcomes of NRG1 therapy for MI and provide a novel approach for sustained, direct delivery of protein therapeutics into the heart.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Prostate cancer in African Americans exhibits distinctive features, including heightened aggressiveness, more widespread metastases, earlier onset, and elevated mortality rates compared to those in Caucasian Americans. This diversity supplement aims to provide support for a graduate student candidate, facilitating the exploration of an overlooked yet significant aspect: the development and enhancement of computerized decision support tools to elevate the performance of prostate cancer diagnosis specifically for the African-American population.
