IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the clear link between intimate partner violence (IPV) and adverse maternal health outcomes, including maternal mortality, IPV is understudied in maternal health research. This R25 grant proposal seeks to bridge this gap by developing, implementing, and evaluating a comprehensive web-based research education program and resource toolkit to equip maternal health researchers with the essential skills to effectively measure and address IPV in their research. Empowering maternal health researchers with these skills will build their capacity to generate translatable evidence-based solutions to address the intersection of IPV and maternal health, thus strengthening the ability of health professionals to provide comprehensive care and, ultimately, contributing to the reduction of maternal mortality and IPV among vulnerable populations.

PHR: Project Narrative Antibiotics severely alter the gut microbiome producing a state of microbial imbalance called dysbiosis. How dysbiosis affects cancer progression is largely unknown. This project will expand our understanding of the crosstalk between the gut microbiome, the tumor microenvironment, and cellular immunotherapy during antibiotic-induced dysbiosis.

Our proposed work will provide evidence of the impact of a virtual platform for telegenetic consultation service with low-cost genomic sequencing to reduce this disparity, as well as determine best practices for implementation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed K23 supplement aims to evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of a linguistically adapted mobile health parenting stress intervention for caregivers of legally youth, a population with high rates of substance use and low rates of treatment engagement. Findings will contribute to the public health and juvenile legal fields by providing crucial information about the equitable and ethical use of mobile health interventions with Spanish speaking caregivers of legally involved youth. The proposed work will also expand the investigator's capacities as an independent health services investigator striving to improve behavioral health outcomes for marginalized youth and families by advancing the linguistic and cultural accessibility of her work.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the second leading cause of cancer death in American women and is commonly diagnosed in Black women under forty. There is currently no targeted therapy for TNBC. The overexpression of androgen receptors (ARs) and histone lysine demethylases (KDMs) are vital to the viability of TNBC. Interestingly, AR overexpression is the most important driver of prostate cancer (PCa). This Diversity Supplement application proposed to test the hypothesis that antiandrogen drugs used to treat PCa, when effectively integrated into KDM inhibiting moieties, could furnished novel new treatment modality for TNBC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE MDM2 and its numerous isoforms are key regulators of the expression and function of the p53 gene, a critical tumor suppressor that prevents inappropriate cell growth and proliferation. The proposed research will study the molecular connection between DNA damage, MDM2 isoform switching, p53, and cancer. Unraveling this pathway could lead to the discovery of novel therapeutic intervention points and thus be a crucial stepping-stone for cancer drug discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pediatric high-grade gliomas (pHGG), which include diffuse midline glioma (DMG), are among the most lethal of all pediatric cancers, with survival rarely exceeding two years. Mutations in the histone variant H3.3 and loss of ATRX are two of the most common mutations in pHGG, but it is not known how the two interact with each other to impact re-expression of early brain development genes. This proposal aims to look at how the two different histone mutations interplay with ATRX loss to affect developmental gene expression and tumor formation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Project Narrative As we age, physical activity becomes more important to maintain health and well-being. Interventions to support patients to be more active are not routinely incorporated into clinical practice and patients often do not meet national physical activity guidelines. In a sample of WTCHP participants with cancer, this project proposes to test the effectiveness and implementation of a brief motivational intervention to support physical activity.

PROJECT_TITLE: Effectiveness and Implementation of a Brief Motivational Intervention to Increase Physical Activity for World Trade Center Health Program Cancer Survivors

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: 1 Percutaneous lung biopsies (PLB) are a minimally invasive method for workup of suspicious lung nodules  2 with nearly 30,000 biopsies performed by interventional radiologists in the VHA between FY 2017-2022.  3 Between 5-15% of PLBs result in a severe pneumothorax requiring chest tube placement and frequently  4 inpatient care. Prior work found wide variation in hospital rates of severe pneumothorax, indicating sites with  5 better performance may have PLB practices that improve outcomes. The proposed mixed methods study will  6 1) interview interventional radiologists regarding best practices for patient selection and pneumothorax  7 prevention, 2) mine VHA electronic data to determine diagnostic yield and provider referral behavior, and 3)  8 integrate Aim 1 and 2 findings to identify best practices associated with low rates of severe pneumothorax and  9 high rates of meaningful diagnostic results. We will submit an HSR&D IIR proposal based on our pilot study 10 findings to establish consensus on PLB best practices and test implementation of these practices in the VHA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We have identified 2.5-fold higher prevalence of doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity (DIC) in African American (AA) than European American survivors yet the biological basis of this racial disparity in DIC is poorly understood. We will use human induced pluripotent stem cell-derived cardiomyocytes derived from AA survivors to discover novel genetic variants for DIC and validate the mechanisms by which these genetic variants influence this potentially fatal drug complication. This knowledge will provide clinicians with a validated genomic tool to predict if a patient will experience DIC and a route to discover genotype-specific cardioprotective drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Aneuploidy is very frequent in cancer but its role in tumorigenesis and as a potential target for cancer therapy is poorly understood. Within the scope of the funded parent grant, this application aims at performing computational analyses on existing data on colorectal cancer patients to better define the cancer driver genes located on chromosome 7 and at validating experimentally these predictions. The other main goal of this application is to foster scientific and educational training for Elaine Camacho-Hernandez to promote her future academic career.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: Project Narrative There is an urgent need to identify modifiable structural drivers of youth community violence that can be leveraged for long-term primary prevention efforts. By examining the role that housing policies play in community violence, findings from this project will provide actionable knowledge about the structural determinants of youth community violence and related disparities, including insight into the mechanisms underlying these relationships. This research will also provide policy-relevant findings to local and state governments interested in far-reaching, sustainable reductions in violence through a strategic approach to housing policy.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Exploring the Effectiveness of Housing Policy as a Structural Intervention to Reduce Community Violence: An Evaluation of Choice Neighborhoods and Source of Income Anti-Discrimination Laws

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Falls are a major public health concern in persons with Multiple Sclerosis (MS), resulting in expensive medical costs, serious injuries, reduced quality of life, and loss of independence. Fear of falling (FOF) is both a cause and consequence of falls that traps individuals in a vicious cycle of reduced balance confidence, avoidance behavior, physical deconditioning, increased fall risk, and subsequent greater FOF. This study aims to comprehensively examine neural, motor, cognitive, and psychological contributions to FOF and determine their long-term impact on future falls and physical activity, with an overarching goal of identifying targets for rehabilitation strategies to break the vicious FOF cycle and ultimately reduce falls in the MS community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cocaine use disorder is one of the most challenging disorders for society to address due to its rapid progression and lack of approved treatments/therapies. Identifying the neurochemical changes arising from this chronic disorder will be beneficial for providing early medical intervention for those affected; however, current technology is not capable of discovering these chemical alterations. In this project, we will develop new instrumentation and data analysis techniques that enhance our ability to monitor neurochemicals in the living brain and address questions relating to the underlying cause of cocaine use disorder within an animal model for addiction.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Drugs of abuse drive addiction by inducing long lasting changes in the function of brain regions that underlie motivated behaviors. Here we will use novel molecular genetics technologies to test the role of chromatin regulation at synaptic plasticity genes in a mouse model of cocaine craving. These studies will deepen mechanistic understanding of the neuronal plasticity that leads to addiction.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Narrative The Common Fund Visualization Hub project aims to develop a transformative cloud-based integrative visualization platform to enable interactive exploration of multimodal biomedical data, using large omics and imaging datasets sourced from CFDE DCCs and external consortia. The Hub's innovative architecture, focusing on user-driven visualization construction and storytelling, promises to accelerate discovery and improve the accuracy of predictive models in genomic research. The Hub will be used to evaluate models predicting the target genes of candidate cis regulatory elements, which is of great importance to dissecting the biological function of noncoding genetic variants in human traits and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Myeloproliferative neoplasm (MPN) is a hematologic malignancy driven by a somatically acquired mutation most commonly in JAK2 (JAK2V617F), which currently lacks effective therapies for early stage patients, thus necessitating the development of novel treatment modalities. Preliminary clinical and experimental work has identified inflammation as an important factor that influences the relative growth rate of mutant cells, and preliminary collaborative mathematical modeling work indicates that this can potentially have a variety of consequences for the evolution of mutant cells at homeostasis. Novel computational methods, in combination with experimentation, are used to identify mechanisms of JAK2V617F mutant selection, to predict the evolutionary trajectories of JAK2V617F mutant cells under various inflammatory conditions, and to identify and test therapeutic targets to steer cellular evolution away from disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. A current challenge in cancer research is understanding tumor heterogeneity, a major cause of resistance to chemotherapy drugs as well as metastasis development. APOBEC3A and APOBEC3B have been identified as two of the major drivers of tumor heterogeneity by promoting the deamination of cytosine to uracil on DNA and inducing genomic mutations. The goal of this proposal is to uncover the molecular mechanisms that govern APOBEC3A and APOBEC3B regulation in cancer cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Alternative pre-mRNA splicing is a crucial component of establishing appropriate gene expression programs that are unique to tissues and differentiated cell types. Defects in alternative splicing are known to associate with many human diseases. In this project we will analyze the mechanisms of regulated alternative splicing using a combination of experimental and computational approaches to provide detailed molecular insights into the control of gene expression and to identify novel disease targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: This grant application will investigate how truncated O-glycans on oncogenic glycoproteins promote pancreatic cancer progression and metastasis. Specifically, it will elucidate the role of Core 1 β1, 3-Galactosyltransferase (C1GALT1) in aberrant glycosylation of membrane-bound mucins and cancer stem cell markers and induce the early onset of metastasis in pancreatic cancer. Success in this study can be translated clinically by developing therapeutics (glycopeptide vaccines), and quantitative evaluation of truncated carbohydrate antigens in pancreatic cancer tissue can predict disease severity and help better manage pancreatic cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Individuals 65 and older can suffer from central or “hidden” hearing loss, which makes localizing sound and detecting speech in noise difficult, but does not affect hearing in quiet environments. This type of hearing loss is difficult to treat because of our lack of understanding about the mechanisms that lead to this hearing loss. In this proposal, we will look at age-related changes in the auditory brainstem and cochlea that may correlate with a decrease in spatial hearing performance to better understand the mechanisms of age-related hidden hearing loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will contribute to the ongoing investigation of diet’s role in the association between air pollution exposure and type 2 diabetes. Using the comprehensive data collected by the Hispanic Community Health Study/Study of Latinos, our analysis centers around the Hispanic/Latino community, a historically underrepresented community in research. Understanding the interactions between diet and air pollution could help reduce incidence of T2D by identifying persons at higher risk and linking a healthy diet as a protective factor.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research project will contribute to public health by providing essential data on the effects of recreational cannabis legalization on substance use and overdose rates. In an era where cannabis policies are rapidly evolving, understanding these impacts is critical for developing informed public health strategies. The findings will guide policymakers in creating interventions that improve health outcomes, lengthen life, and reduce illness and disability, especially among individuals most affected by these policies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative For cells to grow and divide, protein complexes called ribosomes must be produced in a nuclear compartment called the nucleolus. The structure of the nucleolus is altered in many human diseases including more than 20 cancers, necessitating the need to understand how cells regulate nucleolar structure. The proposed study uses new imaging tools and genetic approaches to identify regulators of nucleolar structure in fission yeast, providing fundamental knowledge that can be applied to future studies in human cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immunotherapies hold immense potential to provide cures for many cancers and metastatic disease, but the complexity of activating and sustaining anti-tumor immune responses will necessitate combinatorial treatment regimes and a better understanding of how the tumor microenvironment (TME) affects response. Here we develop a in vitro model of the tumor-immune circuit which allows precise control over spatial, molecular, cellular, and mechanical aspects of the TME that affect response to immunotherapy, and use it for both mechanistic studies as well as high-throughput predictive screening of immune therapies in a tumor- or patient- specific manner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Prolonged exogenous opioid exposure leads to dysregulation of brain regions associated with reward and motivation. In this proposal, we seek to characterize the gene expression changes resulting from chronic opioid intake at single-cell resolution, and to map alterations to neuronal activity patterns throughout the brain after a period of withdrawal and drug re-exposure. These experiments will expand upon the current understanding of opioid use disorder, with the goal of identifying novel therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Adenomas are early lesions of colorectal cancer, but only a subset of adenomas progress and become cancer. In light of the well characterized clinical natural history of adenomas, we plan to study them as early lesions and to determine the mechanisms involved in the formation and progression of early precancerous lesions. We hypothesize that adenoma progression requires a suite of hallmark behaviors and that these behaviors are induced by adenoma autonomous factors (e.g. cancer driver gene mutations) and adenoma nonautonomous factors from the “primed colon” or adenoma microenvironment. Our proposed studies will integrate basic and translational cancer research projects to iteratively examine the direct causal relationships and interactions of adenomas, the colon “primed” microenvironment, and host-systemic factors as “co-organizers” of adenoma initiation and/or progression.

PHR: Project Narrative: Malic enzyme 2 is frequently deleted in pancreatic cancer and its deletion correlates with poor patient prognosis. Here, we propose experiments that will explore the molecular basis of malic enzyme 2 loss-induced oncogenesis of pancreatic cancer. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The overarching goal of this study is to identify effective metabolic based diagnostic and therapeutic strategies to improve the overall survival of patients with Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). We propose to investigate the positron emission tomography (PET) tracer, 18F-BnTP as a novel metabolic diagnostic and to develop metabolic based therapeutic strategies targeting oxidative mitochondrial metabolism in therapy resistant KRAS/LKB1 and EGFR mutant lung tumors. This work represents a new approach to overcoming therapy resistance in KRAS/LKB1 and EGFR mutant lung tumors – one in which the tumor’s metabolic and bioenergetic dependencies are profiled and then selectively targeted.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Through this work, we aim to understand how site-, region-, and network-specific brain dynamics during sleep change in relation to the clinical and pathologic trajectory of Alzheimer’s disease. Characterizing these patterns will be integral in early detection of AD using sleep-related biomarkers, development of sleep interventions to slow disease progression, and electrophysiological monitoring of amyloid/tau-centric treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Medications for opioid use disorder (MOUD) can reduce overdose mortality risk in patients with opioid use disorder, and emergency department (ED) have been urged to prioritize MOUD initiation for patients with untreated OUD. In California, a novel program emphasizing low-barrier ED-initiated MOUD (the CA Bridge program) disseminated to most EDs statewide from 2018-2022. This project will use California Medicaid data linked to death records to evaluate the impact of CA Bridge dissemination on short- and long-term MOUD use, outpatient engagement, and fatal and non-fatal overdose risk, elucidating the potential public health impacts of ED-based substance use services in the vulnerable Medicaid population.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: CE24-012 - Rigorous Evaluation of California Policies to Disseminate Emergency Department-based Services for Opioid Use Disorder

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is an urgent need for a better vaccine to combat the global threat of Tuberculosis. Gamma delta (γδ) T cells, which can recognize mycobacterial lipids and interact with diverse cell types to initiate a protective response, are an interesting target for vaccination. In this proposal, we will use advanced computational techniques and novel in vitro systems to analyze mechanisms used by γδ T cells to promote control of Mtb infection, which will inform future vaccination efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our “real-world” approach to the study of visual perception is relevant to public health because it will provide fundamental new insights into how realistic stimulus displays can improve perception, learning, and cognition, in healthy adults and children, and in brain-damaged individuals. The research will shed new light on perceptual abilities that are spared, but as yet poorly understood, in patients with visual agnosia, ultimately leading to the development of more effective assessment and rehabilitation approaches for patients with sensory, perceptual, and motor deficits, thereby reducing the burdens of human disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Among the 40% of patients with an HLA-B44 supertype allele, greater clinical activity of programmed cell death 1 (PD-1) inhibitors is seen when mutations lead to peptides in which a neutral or positively charged amino acid is substituted with a negatively charged amino acid, presumably based on favorable binding to the positively charged HLA-B44 binding pocket. We propose comprehensive studies to characterize the effects of these specific mutational events on the tumor microenvironment in early stage non-small cell lung cancer. This will serve as a vehicle to develop the career of Maria Velez, a junior faculty member, facilitating her ability to become competitive for career development awards, and eventually, a career as an independent investigator directing her own research team.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Premature birth places infants at risk for movement disorders as a result of abnormal motor and sensory experiences with an immature brain. The goal of the current proposal is to use rigorous measurements to track motor and sensory development in relation to brain activity to understand movement deficits. Understanding how sensorimotor systems develop will provide important information for developing evidence-based therapies for infants at-risk for developmental disabilities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Object sensing and manipulation require selective focus of tactile sensory signals from specific locations on the hand. Here, we determine how selective attention implements mechanisms of gain suppression to filter out irrelevant tactile information, and enhance sensory representations encoding attended cutaneous stimuli. Results from this study will provide fundamental insights into how distracting sensory information is discarded in brain, which may lead to a better understanding of the underlying circuits mediating tactile perceptual deficits in Autism and Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder populations. Our studies will also have a direct translational impact on Brain-Machine-Interface (BMI) solutions that are specific to neuroprosthetic applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The use of cocaine or methamphetamine often leads to poor health outcomes, including cardiovascular dysfunction and overdose-related mortality. Discovering treatments for stimulant use disorder (SUD) is a pressing task for researchers, as there are currently no FDA-approved medications to treat SUD. Our group has identified a brain protein, RGS12, that may hold promise as a potential target for SUD medications, and we propose work that will validate the utility of RGS12-targeting medications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal seeks to identify the effects of the 20 proteinogenic amino acids and other related compounds on cellular processes. The experiments described in this proposal will begin to enlighten us on such effects and may provide insight into amino acid sensing and metabolism. Additionally, the data collected will provide a valuable resource to the scientific community to pursue alternate treatments in conditions with amino acid imbalances, such as cancer, diabetes, and inborn errors of metabolism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  Peripheral nerve injuries (PNI) put motoneurons (MNs) at risk of cell death, thereby limiting an individual’s potential for a full functional recovery. This project aims to identify microglial-MN interactions and cellular communication mechanisms that may govern MN fate following a PNI. Our research is critical for therapeutic advancement in MN disease, improving patient outcomes, and may be transferable to other neuropathologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) infects nearly all adults on the planet and can alter host cell function to maintain a latent or lytic life cycle, promoting recurrent infections in the oral mucosa that can lead to tumorigenesis in immune compromised individuals. While diverse stimuli can reactive EBV, the response is often heterogeneous and what governs this process at the single cell level is poorly understood. Therefore, the proposed studies will elucidate host factors that restrict complete EBV lytic reactivation, which can help lead to better therapies for EBV- associated diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: In 2020, our research team completed a multicenter phase III randomized controlled trial for primary stroke prevention in children with sickle anemia, demonstrating that children with an annual 10% stroke risk because of a high velocity of blood flow in their brain could be treated with either low or moderate dose hydroxyurea for a significant decrease in strokes. We propose an open-label, single-arm, type I hybrid trial (phase IV trial) for primary stroke prevention initially with low-dose hydroxyurea and subsequently with moderate-dose hydroxyurea based after at least two severe pain events requiring physician contacts during the trial and assessment of ways to maintain the sustainability of stroke prevention programs. We will conduct a cost- effective analysis to determine the sustainability, relative cost, and effectiveness of the hydroxyurea dose on stroke prevention and healthcare utilization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heart failure (HF) affects over 6.2 million adults in the United States and is implicated in more than 300,000 deaths per year. Identifying novel biomarkers and biology of early-stage heart failure using non-invasive, circulating biospecimens would aid in the development of advanced HF prevention strategies and help reduce disease burden. Leveraging cutting-edge machine learning methodologies would contribute to knowledge of techniques that optimize identification of biomarkers and biology broadly across cardiometabolic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: The proposed research applies computational models of the human auditory system to better understand how listeners can detect sounds of interest against a background of competing sounds, such as a target talker speaking in a noisy room. The proposed models can simulate the effects of hearing loss and will be used to investigate how hearing loss at the peripheral level impacts neural coding of sound at higher levels of the auditory system, such as the inferior colliculus in the auditory midbrain. The results of this research will inform strategies to ameliorate perceptual changes associated with hearing loss in next-generation hearing aids and cochlear implants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Recent studies in mice suggest that specific types of retinal ganglion cells, the neurons that degenerate in glaucoma, are more susceptible to injury. However, translating these findings to the human condition is not straightforward since the mouse and human eye differ in several major ways, including the ocular structures and types of retinal ganglion cells found in the two species. Here we propose a detailed multi-modal assessment of the mechanisms underlying ganglion cell susceptibility in a highly clinically relevant model of glaucoma, which will lead to improved understanding of the disease, novel targets for earlier diagnosis and treatment, and in turn, better options for glaucoma patients to preserve and potentially improve their vision.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neonatal, border zone cardiomyocytes can proliferate and survive post-injury in the mammalian heart, but this ability is rapidly lost as the cells mature with age. This proposal will investigate how border zone cardiomyocytes will respond to the loss of SPRR1A following cardiac injury in regenerative and non-regenerative neonatal hearts, and whether this will alter their proliferative capacity and their survivability. This work will highlight differences between the older, non-regenerative cardiomyocytes compared to the proliferative, neonatal cells, and these findings will improve our understanding on how to enhance cardiomyocyte survival in non-regenerative injury settings, such as myocardial infarction in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Understanding the complex gene regulatory network controlling axon growth is a critical step to meet the challenge of poor axon regeneration in the central nervous system. The proposed study will combine RNA-seq and ATAC-seq in purified retinal ganglion cells at various developmental stages and use advanced integrative multi-omics analysis to identify core transcription factors regulating axon growth during retinal ganglion cell development, and functionally test the identified transcription factors in optic nerve regeneration model. The study will not only provide a comprehensive view of the transcriptional regulatory network that governs neuronal axon growth, but also reveal novel therapeutic targets for glaucoma and other neural injuries and neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Although both men and women are affected by alcohol use disorder (AUD), women often progress through AUD disease milestones faster and experience more severe health consequences than men; however, little is known about the synaptic and molecular mechanism driving these sex-differences. The sexually dimorphic prefrontal cortex (PFC) integrates excitatory glutamatergic inputs from subcortical structures to modulate cortical excitation, yet the mechanism by which ethanol alters these inputs remains unclear. This proposal seeks to investigate how ethanol alters glutamatergic strength and plasticity at discrete excitatory inputs to the PFC in female and male mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative  The proposed study seeks to use multiple state-of-the–art molecular and cellular profiling platforms to construct a three-dimensional spatially resolved Ovarian Cancer Atlas using treatment naïve formalin fixed paraffin embedded (FFPE) ovarian tumor tissue samples obtained from the primary ovarian site and metastatic sites in racially diverse patients who are diagnosed with chemo-refractory or chemo-sensitive advanced high- grade serous ovarian cancer (HGSOC). We expect that the results will be used by academic researchers, clinical researchers and industry partners to improve our understanding of the molecular basis of the disease and better strategize disease management of patients. In addition, the results of this study would have the potential leading to the development of clinical trials testing novel agents against new molecular targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Staphylococcus aureus is a Gram-positive pathogen that relies on nutrient metals to respond to stress and cause infections. The proposed research will define the importance of zinc during S. aureus pathogenesis by determining the function of two putative metallochaperones CrzA and ZigA that we hypothesize bind and activate zinc-dependent S. aureus proteins implicated in DNA maintenance and DNA damage repair. The proposed work will establish the importance of CrzA- and ZigA-dependent metal allocation during the pathogenesis of infection and establish the regulation of DNA repair as a target for the development of new anti-microbial agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Donor organ shortage in kidney transplantation can be greatly mitigated by effective control of early alloimmunity and late organ fibrosis. Our preliminary studies suggest that recipient monocytes and macrophages play critical roles along the temporal line of this process. The overall goal of this proposal is to identify novel time-specific and pathway-specific targets for modulating recipient monocyte and macrophage functions post-kidney transplant, and ultimately pave the road for future designs of therapeutics for enhancing long-term kidney allograft survival.

PHR: Project Narra+ve The research proposed in this project aims to signiﬁcantly enhance our understanding of the gene7c links between childhood cancers and structural birth defects, which are among the leading causes of pediatric morbidity and mortality. In the long term, this research has the poten7al to inform more eﬀec7ve diagnos7c and therapeu7c strategies, thereby improving health outcomes, prolonging life, and reducing the burden of illness and disability in aﬀected children and adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The Human Tumor Atlas Network (HTAN) aims to leverage the power of human genome sequencing and other state-of-the-art profiling technologies, to analyze spatial and temporal molecular changes in individual tumors. The HTAN Data Coordination Center (DCC) will ensure that all data generated by HTAN use the same data standards, that all data is hosted in one centralized location, and that all data is shared within HTAN and eventually with the wider scientific community. To maximize the research impact of the data generated, the DCC will also provide powerful analysis and visualization features, and these services and tools will enable researchers to make novel discoveries about the initiation and progression of cancer, as well as the development of resistance to cancer therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cancer-related thrombosis is the second leading cause of death for cancer patients and glioblastoma (GBM), the most common primary malignant brain tumor, is associated with approximately a 30% risk of venous thromboembolism, deep vein thrombosis, or pulmonary embolisms. While this remains a major clinical issue, the role that the hyper-thrombotic state plays on contributing to the immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment in GBM has not been explored. This study aims to understand how platelet hyperactivity and the thrombin-PAR4 signaling axis contributes to the immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment in a sex-dependent manner.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Metabolites are often endpoints and markers of human physiology, and a collection of metabolites can potentially define homeostatic states of human health. We bring together metabolomics measurements on human subjects from three defined perturbations, namely, exercise, diet, and environmental exposome, from the three national projects, MoTrPAC, NPH, and HHEAR, respectively, in defining the metabotypes (homeostatic states) through exploration of the metabolomic hyperspace. We hypothesize that, from large-scale metabolomic measurements on humans, we can define metabotypes that define the homeostatic state of a collection of metabotypes and define how perturbations from this state can be addressed through targeted interventions and provide the metabotype calculator as the most valuable product from this project.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Integrated Stress Response (ISR) regulates a wide range of host cell functions in response to environmental and infected-induced perturbations through transcriptional and translational control. We find that the bacterium Salmonella enterica serovar Typhi induces the macrophage ISR during infection and macrophage lacking key ISR components are impaired in their innate immune functions. This study will define how the ISR governs macrophage function, polarization, and metabolism in response to S. Typhi infection and will reveal novel targets for future targeted therapeutic development against this global pathogen.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Since cochlear synaptopathy is a common cochlear pathology in aging humans, it is crucial to understand what effects this condition has on the auditory system and how to detect it. The current study in an animal model will determine how auditory-nerve response properties are affected by synaptopathy and to develop tools for detecting this cochlear pathology. These results can help guide strategies to treat cochlear synaptopathy and ultimately improve quality of life in people with this common health problem.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Barth syndrome (BTHS) is an ultra-rare, life-threatening genetic disease that affects ~320 individuals globally, making development of treatments challenging due to limited commercial interest and resources. The mission of the Barth Syndrome Foundation (BSF)–a patient advocacy group for those affected by BTHS–is to save lives through education, advances in treatments, and finding a cure for the disease. The Science and Medical Conference on Barth Syndrome will stimulate new clinical and scientific progress, convene affected families with scientists and clinicians and bring discoveries from the benchtop to treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

PHR: Project Narrative: Although immune checkpoint blockade (ICB) therapeutics have proved the possible efficacy of immunotherapies in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), most patients do not respond to these treatments durably. This proposal aims to use spatial functional genomics in coordination with highly-multiplexed imaging to illuminate the specific roles of SOCS1 and all other interferon gamma (IFNy) stimulated genes (ISGs) in generating an immunosuppressive environment within the tumor microenvironment (TME) and regulating resistance and response to ICB.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is relevant to the mission of the NIH because Cryptococcus neoformans is an important human pathogen, and this project aims to understand the molecular processes involved in fungal disease development. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: NMDA receptors are glutamate-gated excitatory ion channels with essential roles in the central nervous system, whose activation mechanism remains incompletely understood, thus preventing the development of rational approaches for the treatment of a variety of neuropsychiatric disorders. The parent project uses an integrated approach that integrates computational modeling of structural changes that represent the receptor activation reaction and comprehensive testing of the computationally-generated hypotheses with electrophysiological measurements. In this supplement we propose do delineate electrophysiological properties of a truncated NMDA receptor protein that we used successfully to model the gating reaction, but for which functional information is unavailable.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Transgender women have disproportionally high rates of sexually transmitted infections including human immunodeficiency virus, which is maintained after adjusting for high-risk behaviours. Little is known about the neovaginal microenvironment following gender affirming vaginoplasty, which could have important implications for mucosal health in transgender women. In this project we will profile the neovaginal microbiome and its’ association with inflammation, bacterial functions, and gynecological symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The severity of bacterial infections is often influenced by the complexity of the infecting community and interactions among members of the community. Many of these interactions are regulated by quorum sensing, a type of cell-cell signaling. The primary objective of this proposal is to define how quorum sensing alters the dynamics of populations in multispecies communities and patient infections, with the long-term goal of informing efforts to target quorum sensing to control infection populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neurodevelopmental disorders encompass a range of intellectual, social, and behavioral deficits, and are increasingly prevalent in the child population. Functional insulin/insulin-like growth factor (IGF) signaling is required for proper brain growth and function and, thus, is closely regulated by IGF binding proteins. Since dysregulation of IGF signaling is strongly linked to developmental diseases, this project seeks to uncover regulatory mechanisms of IGF binding proteins in central brain circuit formation and function while exploring potential avenues for therapeutic intervention in neurodevelopmental disorders.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed project aims to identify patterns of nonfatal firearm-related intimate partner violence (IPV) involvement as well as examine the demographic characteristics and modifiable risk and protective factors that characterize subgroups of individuals who have experienced or perpetrated firearm-related IPV. The aims will be addressed through secondary analysis of three data sets: (1) middle and (2) high school youth, and (3) a nationally representative sample of adults. The results will broaden our understanding of how firearm-related IPV behaviors fit within the context of IPV across development, identify subgroups of individuals at the highest risk of firearm-related IPV involvement, and examine the modifiable risk and protective factors associated with patterns of firearm-related IPV involvement to prevent firearm-related injury and death among young people.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lung transplant is associated with high morbidity and mortality with complications such as acute cellular rejection (ACR) ultimately resulting in chronic lung allograft dysfunction (CLAD). The proposed experiments will reveal much-needed early indicators of CLAD where there are none and serial sampling will provide stronger evidence for the causality of biomarkers. Ultimately, elucidating early signs of ACR and CLAD for timelier intervention and revealing therapeutic targets will reduce lung transplant failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is characterized by chronic inflammation of the digestive tract and though there are treatments for IBD, there are currently no cures. This proposal aims to define how certain cells of the intestinal epithelium help repair tissue injury using mouse and organoid models. Findings from this work may identify novel pathways to new therapies for healing the intestinal epithelium in patients with IBD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Carbapenem-resistant Klebsiella pneumoniae is an urgent public health threat with limited available treatments. Central to maintaining long-term treatment efficacy is an improved understanding of the clinical practices, patient populations, and bacterial factors that drive the emergence and spread of resistance. In this proposal, the PI will leverage isolate and data collections from a regional healthcare network before and after the clinical deployment of two recently approved β- lactam/β-lactamase inhibitor combination therapies to understand how baseline clinical practices and circulating bacteria can inform the subsequent emergence and spread of resistance once an antibiotic is clinically deployed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Breast cancer is the most common malignancy in women, and the primary cause of breast cancer-related deaths is when tumor cells spread to other organs, a process known as metastasis. Sensory nerves, which are more abundant in breast tumors compared to healthy breast tissue, can increase breast cancer metastasis. The goal of this project is to reveal the mechanisms by which breast cancer cells attract sensory nerves into the tumor, potentially enabling new therapeutic targets to reduce metastasis and improve patient survival.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Angelman syndrome (AS) is a neurodevelopmental disorder with a high incidence of debilitating seizures. There is an urgent and unmet clinical need to treat these seizures because they are often refractory to antiepileptic drugs. Here, I propose to identify novel seizure-relevant molecular targets that may inform therapeutic strategies to treat epilepsy in AS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Seizures are one of the most common reasons why bystanders call an ambulance for a child, and current practice frequently fails due to under-dosing and delayed delivery of anti-seizure medication (midazolam). Reducing the respiratory failure and brain damage that this causes requires equipping paramedics with a simplified method for rapidly determining and administering a therapeutic dose of medication. If this study demonstrates that standardized, age-based midazolam dosing is both safe and more effective than current practice, the potential impact of this study is a paradigm shift in the treatment of pediatric seizures that can be easily implemented in emergency medical services (EMS) systems across the country.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Common Fund program brings together diverse collections of valuable biomedical datasets capable of facilitating discovery and enabling future innovation. As a central hub of protein sequence and functional information, the UniProt will partner with the Common Fund Data Ecosystem resources to support data integration and reuse and build new capabilities to interrogate and understand complex biological systems and cell networks. Our deeper understanding of responses to perturbations at the systems level will accelerate the development of new diagnostics and therapies and overall health-related research and discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Individuals with schizophrenia and related psychotic disorders have greatly increased rates of obesity and obesity-related comorbidities, compared to the general population. A major factor impeding the development of effective treatments for this major health concern is the limited understanding of the underlying neurobiological mechanisms. This proposal attempts to address this knowledge gap by examining the relationship between obesity in schizophrenia and brain connectivity disruptions found in both schizophrenia and obesity in the general population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project will evaluate the association of lifecourse obesity with cognitive decline and Alzheimer’s Disease and related dementias (ADRD) in a cohort of racially and ethnically diverse older adults. Findings from this project will address survival, selection, and competing risk biases to better understand the etiological role obesity has on ADRD and cognitive decline at different periods over the lifecourse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Women’s Health Initiative Dietary Modification (DM) Trial randomized 48,835 postmenopausal women to an intervention group (DM-I) whose participants followed a low-fat/high fruit and vegetable dietary pattern or a usual diet comparison group (DM-C). Following the ~8.5 y intervention, women in the DM-I experienced numerous clinically meaningful intervention effects on important measures of metabolic health and long-term health and mortality outcomes. Leveraging data and samples from the trial, we will measure metabolomics biomarkers in baseline and year 1 blood from n=1000, and end-of-intervention blood from n=465 WHI-DM participants to identify metabolites and biochemical pathways that explain the clinically meaningful effects of the intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is designed to fill a gap in our understanding about how the muscle cells of the right ventricle grow in fetal hearts with reduced left ventricular inflow, as occurs in hypoplastic left heart syndrome, and how we can improve this growth. Completion of the project will help us know and shape the forces that determine the cardiomyocyte endowment of the right ventricle, which is destined to be the systemic ventricle for life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF) is a progressive and fatal fibrotic lung disease with no known cure, resulting in respiratory failure and a median survival of only 3-5 years. Our preliminary data suggest a potential role of the Notch signaling pathway in the differentiation of lung alveolar epithelial cells (AECs), a regenerative process that becomes disrupted in the development of IPF. This project aims to investigate whether AECs utilize the Notch pathway to restore the alveolar epithelium after injury and, in doing so, will provide novel insight into potential therapeutic targets in the Notch pathway that may be leveraged to inform the development of curative IPF therapies.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Loss of P53 activity triggers the activation of cell type-specific signaling networks, a number of which become tumor drivers. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Water creates an enabling environment for good nutrition but the ways by which water insecurity negatively impacts diet and health are not known. This proposed project uses qualitative and quantitative data from 2 islands with substantial water issues to understand if and how water insecurity, an increasingly common public health issue, contributes to poor diet quality and adverse changes in body composition. Findings from this project have the potential to identify upstream determinants of nutrition that can be targeted to address growing global malnutrition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Abnormal activation of the complement pathway, which regulates innate immunity and inflammation, is associated with blinding diseases such as inherited and age-related macular degenerations. This research will investigate how a novel pathway of intracellular complement activation endangers the health of the retinal pigment epithelium, a key site of insult in macular degenerations. We will study the impact of intracellular complement on the function and integrity of the retinal pigment epithelium, and identify potential points of therapeutic intervention that can be targeted to preserve vision.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The noncoding genome has long been considered important to human health and disease, however, little direct evidence exists to support this claim. This project proposes to use a novel technology to systematically perturb noncoding genetic elements in vivo and at scale to assess their functions in animal development and behavior. The proposed work will be transformative and will result in a significant leap in our understanding of how the noncoding genome regulates various biological processes, dysregulation of which underpins many human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE We propose to construct the Myeloma Multidimensional Pre-Cancer Atlas (MMPCA); as multiple myeloma (MM) is almost always preceded by monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS) and smoldering myeloma (SMM), with a transformation rate of ~1% and ~10% per year, respectively. Large racial disparities exist in MM and its premalignant conditions; compared to Whites, African-Americans have a two- fold increased prevalence of MGUS/MM and are diagnosed with MM at younger ages. We will leverage our large collection of samples from two cohort studies that are racially diverse to create a comprehensive spatial and temporal atlas of precursor MM to understand genomic and microenvironmental alterations across the spectrum of disease evolution from healthy to MM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dendritic cells (DCs) have been implicated as the critical mediator of the demonstrated efficacy of lipid nanoparticle (LNP)-based COVID-19 vaccines but the exact molecular and cellular mechanisms of LNP immunogenicity in DCs remain unclear. The outlined proposal seeks a) to elucidate such mechanisms by characterizing changes in transcriptional program, phenotype and function of dendritic cells (DCs) upon LNP uptake and payload expression of LNPs and b) to devise bi-specific antibody-based strategies to improve DC- targeting in vivo. In achieving the aims of the proposal, we hope to pave the way forward to more rational designs of LNP formulations as well as enhanced targeting strategies to modulate DCs to enhance anti-tumor immunity.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: This proposal will detail my progress and future plans to examine the function of meiotic histone reader ZCWPW1 in ovarian reserve formation, genomic fidelity, and oocyte quality. Through this work, I hope to identify the keystone factors that regulate oocyte quality and characterize their impact on ovarian physiology and fertility. This proposal has applications to our understanding of human infertility, early embryonic miscarriages, and primary ovarian insufficiency.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The most functionally important features of protein molecules are their atomic structure and the dynamics of how that structure moves. This project will directly address two major barriers to progress of biomedical research by (1) enabling investigation of protein structure not just in the test tube but in the native living environment and (2) revealing dynamics of much larger proteins than is currently feasible. Successful completion will advance a plethora of biomedical research and development efforts, most immediately the design of new antibiotics for bacterial pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Secretion of saliva is tightly regulated, as it is critical for ease of everyday tasks such as speaking, digestion, and maintaining oral health. While autonomic neuronal control of the major salivary glands has been well described, the role of direct trigeminal sensory innervation of the glands has not been explored. The proposed research will explore the function of Trp-positive trigeminal sensory neurons innervating the submandibular salivary glands, providing a foundation for new therapeutic targets for those affected with salivary issues such as Sjogren’s disease (i.e., autoimmune disease that attacks the salivary and lacrimal glands) and xerostomia (i.e., dry mouth).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (Award Period 03/01/2023-02/29/2024) The University of Rochester and Wilmot Cancer Institute has a long-standing history of conducting clinical research through the NCI’s National Clinical Trials Network. Our commitment to clinical trials and the impact they have on clinical care is evidenced by our increasing accrual rates leading to recognition as a High Performance Site and expanded involvement of Wilmot investigators within the NCTN. This award will continue to support our research activities, develop impactful clinical trials, mentor the new researchers, and provide cutting edge treatment options for patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Pre-saccadic attention has been related to enhanced neural responses before saccades and while several visual areas (V1, V4, and MT) have shown pre-saccadic enhancements in firing and neural sensitivity, much remains unknown about the underlying neural pathway. This fellowship proposal aims to tests if FEF drives pre-saccadic enhancement through feedback pathways to superficial and deep layers in extra-striate visual cortex, specifically in visual areas MT/MTC. Completing the aims of this proposal will provide greater insight into the circuitry controlling pre-saccadic enhancements.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Deficits in chemosensory processing are associated with normal aging as well as numerous neurodegenerative disorders including Alzheimer’s Disease (AD). This proposal will investigate how taste processing and taste memory are affected by aging and AD. A functional investigation into the mechanisms regulating age- and AD- associated decline in taste and memory will further our understanding chemosensory processing, aging, and neurodegenerative disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic pain is both a leading cause of disability and the primary reason for seeking out medical attention in the US, making it a significant socioeconomic burden on healthcare systems, particularly given the rapidly aging population. Recent evidence suggests that acupuncture is an appropriate and effective long-term non- pharmacological treatment for chronic pain; however, there are large gaps in our understanding of how acupuncture may be streamlined and integrated equitably into the American healthcare system. This proposal uses ethnographic, implementation science, and health equity approaches to better understand pain management plans that include acupuncture, identify gaps in continuity of care within integrated pain management plans for older adults, and evaluate randomized controlled trial study designs to advance this area of research forward.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (Relevance Statement): We have developed the largest fully integrated database that is shared with researchers around the world to help identify promoter–enhancer interactions (PEIs) that contribute to complex patterns of gene expression in the retina. Using this database, we identified evolutionarily conserved enhancers for each of the early retinal transcription factor network genes that regulate developmental stage– and cell type–specific gene expression. Discoveries from this study will advance our understanding of complex gene regulation mechanisms that are directly relevant to human retinopathies and bridge a fundamental gap in our knowledge about gene regulation in retinal development and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cardiomyocyte calcium dysregulation is a well-established contributor to cardiovascular disease, yet few advances have been made in understanding the mechanisms underlying this dysregulation. The experiments proposed in this application aim to define the role of a novel microprotein, ALN, in cardiomyocyte calcium regulation in health and disease. The successful completion of this work will expand our current knowledge of calcium handling in the heart and contribute to the long-term goal of developing new therapeutics aimed at restoring cardiomyocyte calcium homeostasis to alleviate the major health burden of heart disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will elucidate fundamental mechanisms that ensure the faithful inheritance of chromosomes during meiosis, the specialized cell division program that produces sperm and eggs. Errors in the inheritance of chromosomes are the primary known cause of miscarriage and birth defects and are also a major factor contributing to the development and progression of many cancers, making the study of meiosis informative for human health at multiple levels. My approach will focus on a newly discovered component of the meiotic machinery that provides an exceptional opportunity to investigate the formation and regulation of meiotic crossovers, which are needed to direct faithful chromosome segregation during meiosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative There is some evidence that World Trade Center (WTC) rescue/recovery workers considered to have high- level WTC dust exposure have a greater risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD) events compared with workers with lower exposure. Inconsistencies in prior WTC CVD study results could be due to the use of different definitions for WTC exposure and for CVD. The goal of the current proposal is to clarify whether WTC exposure leads to an increase in risk of CVD events in rescue/recovery workers and to evaluate the temporal pattern of post-9/11 CVD incidence, using a large unified cohort of 69,100 WTC-exposed rescue/recovery workers, harmonized exposure definitions, and consistent outcome definitions.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Cardiovascular Disease among WTC-exposed Rescue/Recovery Workers

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are a half-million open heart surgeries annually in the United States, and roughly 165,000 of these patients will develop postoperative atrial fibrillation (poAF). As the risk of chronic AF is eight-fold greater in poAF patients, developing safe and effective targeted therapies that work within the relevant timeframe would significantly reduce rates of chronic atrial fibrillation, which is the most common arrhythmia worldwide and a leading cause of ischemic stroke that currently has no disease-modifying therapies. Thus, this research is relevant to the NHLBI’s mission as it will enhance the health and lives of the many individuals who undergo cardiothoracic surgery by reducing the risk of poAF as well as future AF and stroke.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The World Health Organization and 2030 United Nations Agenda for Sustainable Development have urged research aimed at reducing cancer mortality rates. Plant peptide natural products with macrocyclizations, such as moroidins, are an important source of anticancer agents, but their synthetic production and diversification has been challenging due to complex macrocyclization chemistry. Metabolic engineering of moroidin biosynthesis in transgenic Nicotiana benthamiana will generate a small library of moroidin analogs for high- content screening and mechanistic elucidation in cancer cell lines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Staphylococcus aureus infections are a major public health concern due to their high prevalence and significant morbidity and mortality. This proposal will investigate a novel facet of S. aureus peptidoglycan processing that promotes recognition by the host immune system. It is anticipated these studies will aid in our understanding of how immune cells sense peptidoglycan and its relevance to host-pathogen interactions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A fundamental feature of perception is the ability to recognize objects or object features despite changes in presentation, such as size, position, or context. By investigating the population and circuit mechanisms underlying how the cerebral cortex builds neural representations that are invariant to these manipulations, we will begin to untangle the basic biological mechanisms underlying perception. This proposal specifically aims to investigate how invariance is computed for motion encoding in visual cortex with the goal of elucidating fundamental principles of sensory information processing in the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Respiratory viral infections and interstitial lung diseases are characterized by the large-scale expansion and migration of ectopic cells to alveoli, where they participate in a dysplastic form of remodeling, leading to long- term reduced lung function as well as increased mortality in cases of Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis. The signals facilitating this dramatic proliferative/migratory event and whether these cells contribute to pulmonary fibrosis is unknown. This proposal will therefore investigate the role of NF-κB signaling in dysplastic remodeling and the pro-fibrotic function of these ectopic cells, thereby providing insight into the underlying mechanisms governing their migration and fibrotic pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the high prevalence of epilepsy in the United States, current anti-seizure medications are limited because a significant proportion of patients develop drug resistance and experience significant off-target side effects. This proposal will determine whether pathological neuronal expression of the SUR1-TRPM4 channel, a potential disease-specific therapeutic target I’ve previously found to upregulate in epileptic human and rodent brain, contributes to elevated seizure susceptibility in chronic epilepsy. Direct inhibition of SUR1-TRPM4 has high therapeutic potential, especially with the availability of an FDA-approved inhibitor glyburide, as an effective mechanism for seizure reduction in patients with epilepsy and other pathologies associated with seizures in which neuronal SUR1-TRPM4 expression has been characterized such as stroke, traumatic brain injury, neonatal hypoxia, and intracranial hemorrhage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The majority of mammals rely on a placenta for in utero gas, nutrient and waste exchange. This organ must grow and vascularize to nourish an embryo whose metabolic demands it cannot directly sense, but the mechanisms underlying placental vascular development are poorly understood. The proposed studies will investigate the role of a cardio-placental BMP10-ENG/ALK1 endocrine signaling axis in instructing the formation of the placental labyrinth to improve our understanding of how this process is regulated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to leverage three advanced techniques in single-cell and spatial omics profiling to construct a comprehensive spatiotemporal molecular and cellular atlas of human lymphomas. Furthermore, it seeks to assess the utility of this tumor atlas in examining the progression of lymphomas and uncovering potential biomarkers, thereby constituting a profoundly valuable data resource for mechanistic discovery. The outcomes of this project are anticipated to significantly enhance our understanding of lymphomagenesis and treatment responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Heart failure is a leading cause of death worldwide, in part because the adult mammalian heart lacks the ability to regenerate after injury. Cardiomyocyte and endothelial cell interactions are known to regulate cardiac growth during development. This proposal aims to use cardiac organoids to model myovascular growth niches, with the goal of identifying endothelially secreted factors that can stimulate cardiomyocyte proliferation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative:  Motor learning is fundamental for humans to become proficient in daily activities and includes two fundamental components, motor adaptation and skill learning, which are both critical for learning new competencies in daily life and in rehabilitation. This study will use non-invasive brain stimulation to examine the neural mechanisms that underlie motor learning, including whether both components of learning are lateralized to the left brain-hemisphere. The information gained from this study should prove essential for the optimal translation of non-invasive brain stimulation techniques to motor learning in rehabilitation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The primary goals of the parent award HL 163085 are: to understand the mechanisms of accelerated structural degeneration of implantable biomaterials in pediatric and young adults by assessing the role of protein absorption on implanted biomaterials and to test mitigation strategies to extend the lifespan of these biomaterials in vitro, ex vivo, and in vivo by using juvenile and adult rat models. In this revision we address how systemic vs pulmonary circulation conditions (including the different blood biochemistry and hemodynamic conditions) is impacting the materials used for reconstructive heart surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is a subtype of breast cancer that is associated with particularly poor outcomes and chemotherapy has been the mainstay of TNBC treatment for many years. With the recent advent of immunotherapy, certain patients with TNBC have experienced improved outcomes, although most patients fail to respond initially or develop resistance due to an immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment. This proposal investigates a molecular mechanism by which TNBC cells induce immunosuppression in their tumor microenvironment, paving the way for future development of new immunotherapeutic approaches to improving outcomes for patients with this challenging cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hyperphosphorylation of tau, a microtubule associated protein, is a hallmark of neurofibrillary tangles (NFT) that correlate with cognitive impairment in Alzheimer's disease (AD) patients. I propose to utilize unbiased single-cell transcriptomic profiling and electrophysiological measurements of brain slices to elucidate the cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying the neurotoxicity and cognitive effects of hyperphosphorylated tau. The proposed studies will provide greater insights into the pathogenic mechanisms of AD and tauopathies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative RNA is cut into pieces that are either included or excluded from a final product that is made into protein, and can lead to changes in protein function and abundance. Transposable elements are parts of the genome that have copy-pasted themselves to constitute >50% of our DNA, with their expression implicated in inflammation. We will study these two mechanisms in the aging muscle to uncover insights that may help prevent muscle function decline with age with the ultimate goal of improving our health as we age.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Group B Streptococcus (GBS), a frequent colonizer of the vaginal tract, is also a leading cause of neonatal sepsis and meningitis and can be transmitted to a newborn during vaginal delivery or by ascension into the uterus during pregnancy. We have found that GBS is associated with the Gram-negative mucin-degrading obligate anaerobe Akkermansia muciniphila, a novel vaginal commensal, and in pregnant females the presence of both GBS and A. muciniphila coincide with pre-term birth. This proposal aims to characterize the properties of A. muciniphila that contribute to GBS persistence and how mucin-degradation alters the vaginal environment to promote GBS ascension.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. World Trade Center (WTC) general responders (GR) carry a significant public mental health (MH) burden related to their work in the WTC collapse. Many have increasingly moved to Florida, representing a substantial and ethnically diverse number of GRs who are away from their NY-based WTC support system, creating a need for personalized, accessible MH care. Responsive to the need to (a) develop efficacious MH treatments for the WTC responders (Zadroga Act, Title 42 USC §300mm–51) and (b) advance health equity, this research application from MPIs from a Hispanic-Serving Institution, proposes to assess the feasibility, acceptability, and efficacy of Clinician-Supported (CS) PTSD Coach, originally developed for English speaking military veterans but never tested with WTC responders, for reducing symptoms of PTSD, depression, anxiety, and sleep disturbance among English and Spanish speaking WTC GRs. If successful with the Florida cohort, CS PTSD Coach will be a readily deployable intervention to reduce PTSD, depression, and related symptoms among the dispersed English and Spanish-speaking WTC GRs.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Clinician-Supported Mobile App to Reduce Mental Health Symptoms Among World Trade Center Responders in Florida.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE Pathogenic germline mutations in the CDH1 gene significantly elevate the risk of hereditary diffuse gastric cancer, prompting many carriers to undergo prophylactic total gastrectomy at a young age due to the disease’s poor survival rates. However, the lack of fundamental understanding of the molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying premalignant disease initiation and evolution poses a barrier to precision approaches for early interception. To address this gap, we propose to construct a multimodal, spatial, and 3-dimensional (3D) atlas utilizing advanced techniques in 3D reconstruction, visualization, and artificial intelligence-driven predictive modeling.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative South Africa (SA) is home to the largest number of people with HIV (PWH) in the world. Community Health Worker (CHW) programs have been rolled out to improve HIV care engagement in SA, yet mental health (MH) conditions, particularly depression and harmful alcohol use, are prevalent non-communicable diseases that remain significant barriers to care engagement, which CHWs often lack training for addressing. This study will develop home-based CHW training program to improve HIV care engagement among patients with common MH challenges and understand how to shift clinic-based interventions to home-based delivery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Patients with craniosynostosis often require surgical correction but their treatment outcomes are highly variable and there are no methods to quantitatively characterize continuous process of head shape normalization after corrective surgery. Therefore, the choice of the most appropriate surgical procedure for each patient is highly dependent on expert qualitative evaluation and the experience of the clinical team. This proposal aims to quantify how patient-specific factors such as age, sex, and pre-surgical severity of anomalies affect head shape normalization after surgical treatment using a large retrospective dataset, to quantitatively compare outcomes between different surgical approaches, and to determine the optimal surgical approach personalized to each patient.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neurodegenerative Diseases: Biology & Therapeutics December 4 - December 7, 2024 Neurodegenerative diseases exert a staggering cost to governments and societies, and thus have become an urgent concern to public health worldwide. The cost of Alzheimer’s disease in the U.S. alone in 2023 has exceeded a quarter trillion dollars. Unfortunately, detailed understanding of the disease processes critical for effective therapeutic interventions for many such disorders remains sketchy. Thus, basic research of the disease process is needed to develop novel diagnostic strategies and new therapeutics that might halt or stem disease progression. The Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory conference on Neurodegenerative Diseases: Biology & Therapeutics will advance knowledge in the field by bringing together top scientists with expertise in disparate aspects of neurodegeneration in an excellent venue that will provide an ideal forum for catalyzing scientific interactions and collaborations to accelerate discoveries of effective therapeutics for the treatments of neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vision loss impacts millions of people globally and can lead to significant socioeconomic burden and reduced quality of life. Retinal imaging, especially functional imaging, is vital for the diagnosis and management of vision loss, however, existing methods poorly account for the astounding variety and diversity of retinal structural characteristics, such as differences within foveal specializations and differences within photoreceptors themselves. This project seeks to address some of these limitations by assessing how variations in retinal structure impact measures of visual function such as visual acuity and optoretinography.
