IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Bone-metastatic lesions will develop in approximately 65-75% of patients with metastatic breast cancer and are associated with high morbidity and mortality. Despite our limited understanding of how breast-to-bone metastases form, the recent emergence of metabolic adaptation as a critical factor in metastasis is a promising development. This work will fully examine the putative intrinsic and extrinsic mechanisms by which glutamine metabolism may promote breast-to-bone metastasis as well as the possibility of using pre-existing cancer therapies targeting glutamine metabolism to ameliorate bone metastatic burden in breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Despite technological improvements and strategic initiatives (e.g., hospital outcomes reporting), major complications following general thoracic and adult cardiac surgery remain common, vary by hospital, increase the risk of mortality and add considerably to healthcare expenditures. Emerging data linking surgeon operative performance, encompassing technical and non-technical (e.g., communication, decision-making) skills, with patient outcomes after non-cardiac surgery reveals that surgical technical skills are necessary yet alone are insufficient for achieving high performance. This study, leveraging a partnership with a professional sport association (given their pioneering work in advancing data-driven performance parameters for athletes) and our expertise conducting real cardiothoracic surgery video-based ratings of operative performance, has the following aims: (1) Develop a multidomain cardiothoracic surgeon operative performance index; (2) Identify biomarkers associated with a surgeon’s operative performance; and (3) Qualitatively assess determinants of a surgeon’s optimal operative performance.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research addresses a crucial gap in the understanding of two, interconnected crises among U.S. adolescents – intimate partner violence (IPV) and depression – by conducting longitudinal, person-centered analyses to identify distinct patterns of IPV experiences and depression symptom trajectories during the transition from mid-adolescence to young adulthood. Results will for the first time elucidate several key findings: 1) types and extent to which adolescents experience IPV; 2) longevity and degree to which adolescents who experience IPV also experience depression symptoms; 3) effect of adolescents’ IPV experiences on depression symptom trajectories into young adulthood; 4) how these findings contrast by sociodemographic and background indicators. Findings will identify adolescents with outreach needs for IPV and/or depression support, and precisely when the need is most dire.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disorders of gut-brain interaction (DGBIs) like irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) collectively affect around 15% of US adults. Patients suffering from DGBIs suffer significant disability and have few successful therapeutic options. Dietary modifications are the first line therapies and have been most successful at alleviating symptoms. One such dietary modification is the elimination of FODMAPs. FODMAPs are highly osmotically active, driving luminal volume shifts in the small bowel, but mechanistic understanding of osmotic signal transduction remains unclear, and how it affects cellular, multicellular, and systemic processes to alter GI physiology remains unknown. Our lab discovered a population of enteroendocrine cells (EECs) that sense non-nutritive stimuli such as mechanical force, thereby opening the door for EECs to be sensors of other non- nutritive stimuli, such as osmoles. In this proposal, we seek to uncover the role of EECs in sensing osmotic stimuli and how these pathways alter signal molecule release and GI motility. This knowledge may pinpoint targets for the treatment of DGBIs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pleural mesothelial cells are often not included in the discussion of cells involved in lung injury and repair, largely because their role has yet to be thoroughly investigated. Intriguingly, these cells appear to be activated in both conditions. This project will study the involvement of pleural mesothelial cells in injury, repair, and regeneration and will investigate their direct impact on specific cell types in the lung to determine their contribution as pathogenic or reparative.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Twenty years after the World Trade Center (WTC) terrorist attack on September 11, 2001, there is a rapid increase in the number of diagnoses and mortality of women’s breast cancer and other cancers. To improve cancer surveillance and treatment for WTC cancers, we propose to conduct integrated analyses of cancer risk and mortality and associated risk factors in WTC survivors enrolled at the New York City Health and Hospitals WTC Environmental Health Center (NYC H+H WTC EHC), Williams Street Clinic and National Provider Network, three CDC/NIOSH-designated treatment and surveillance programs for exposed community members (i.e. survivors). We propose to integrate data on WTC exposures and other risk factors and test their associations with the breast cancer characteristics, and survival using individual-level patient exposure, clinical, outcome data available at the Survivor Data Center (SDC) which hosts the pan-cancer database.

PROJECT_TITLE: Integrated analysis of cancer risk and mortality in WTC survivors

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We aim to construct a three-dimensional molecular atlas to study the progression trajectories of colorectal cancer (CRC) across different ages of onset. We will employ multimodal imaging technologies to characterize the genetic, transcriptomic, metabolomic, microbial, and architectural features of CRC. Our three-dimensional mapping of precancer-to-cancer transitions of each tumor category will elucidate cellular and molecular factors contributing to the rise of earlier onset of cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The midbody is a microtubule rich organelle packed with proteins and enriched for specific RNAs required for proper cell division. This proposal will uncover mechanisms that regulate how those RNAs are localized to the MB, shedding light on this vital regulator of mitosis. This study focuses on experimental and computational approaches to identifying regulatory elements driving mRNAs to the MB, and the completion of this work will lead to novel insights into mechanisms of mRNA localization to other subcellular locations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Type I interferon is a signaling molecule, produced and secreted upon a cell’s detection of virus, that creates an antiviral state in nearby cells to prevent further infection. AMOTL2 is a gene with no previously described antiviral role that appears to contribute to the type I interferon response against Zika virus. A better understanding of the mechanism and breadth of AMOTL2’s antiviral phenotype will improve our basic understanding of the type I interferon response against viruses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A large body of evidence from epidemiological studies suggests that a significant contribution of environmental toxicants, such as World Trade Center (WTC) airborne particulate matter (PM) and heat stress (HS) are associated with poor cognitive health and elevated risk of Alzheimer's Disease (AD). Our proposed studies will characterize age-dependent cascades in response to WTC airborne PM and climate changes and will advance our understanding of gene-environment interactions in the late-onset Alzheimer's Disease (LOAD) mouse model relevant to WTC first responders.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: WTC Airborne Particulate and Climate Change as Risk Factors of Late-Onset Alzheimer's  Disease

ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose “Microbiome Targeted Treatment of WTC- Lung Injury” to address fundamental gaps in knowledge in the potential of utilizing bacteriotherapy in treatment of WTC-related exposure and lung disease. We examine the role of RAGE and IL-17-related inflammatory pathways in a longitudinal cohort of firefighters who participated in our FIREHOUSE trial, and further develop murine models to test the utility of bacteriotherapy to mitigate World Trade Center Lung Injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute kidney injury in sepsis is common, costly, and responsible for high mortality and long-term morbidity. In preliminary studies of experimental sepsis and hospitalized patients, we have discovered that the gut microbiome plays an important but poorly understood role in sepsis-associated acute kidney injury. This project aims to understand how the gut microbiome contributes to the pathogenesis of kidney injury in sepsis, which will help provide insights that may lead to advances in its prevention and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative In this proposal we will test the hypothesis that T cell receptor ligation in the epidermis augments “fitness” of resident memory T cells through cell-intrinsic epigenetic modification thereby allowing for augmented persistence and effector function. We will also determine if stromal cells determine to size of the epidermal memory T cell niche. Both hypotheses will also be examined in the context of chronic antigen stimulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recreational cannabis legalization (RCL) is swiftly expanding in the United States, but virtually nothing is known about its long-term effects. Our original grant suggested that adults living in RCL states used cannabis 20% more frequently within approximately five years of legalization, even after controlling for pre-legalization risk factors. This renewal project would examine whether elevated use persists and is associated with the development of psychosocial and physical health consequences approximately ten years after legalization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The Cancer Moonshot Blue Ribbon Panel Report laid out a roadmap for accelerating cancer research and clinical application of findings, one of the necessary components being the generation of tumor atlases. We propose to combine our expertise in clinical oncology, cancer biology, omics, imaging, and bioinformatics to establish a research center that will create a molecular1y resolved spatial PCa atlas. This atlas will provide a unique resource and unprecedented opportunities for research and clinical communities to better understand the key transitions in PCa progression and the biologic underpinnings of PCa disparities among African American patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The development of effective therapies for the treatment of autoimmune diseases requires a lucid understanding of the mechanisms by which T cell responses to self-antigens are effectively controlled. Here, will perform a clonal analysis of naturally occurring "Tr1" cells, which are characterized by production of the immunosuppressive cytokine IL-10 and exhibit potent regulatory activity capable of preventing or stifling T cell- driven autoimmune reactions. Ultimately, these insights will be crucial for the development of new strategies to mobilize Tr1 cells for the treatment of human autoimmune disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: Narrative This project focuses on links between circulating glucose metabolism and age-related processes occurring in the cells in the brain that support the neurons. These studies will test the idea that these support cells lose some of their ability to move glucose from the circulation to the neurons, which contributes to the cognitive problems associated with aging and further exaggerated in Alzheimer’s disease. Ultimately, it is anticipated that this study will help us understand changes that occur during aging that make the elderly more vulnerable to disorders such as Alzheimer’s disease, and perhaps even the mental deterioration that sometimes occurs in diabetes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Pathway damage from the brain to the spinal cord and brainstem leads to motor impairments in the upper limbs of individuals experiencing a one-sided stroke. This may result in the use of indirect motor pathways and greater output of the transmitter norepinephrine. Elevated norepinephrine heighten motoneuron excitability and increases the use of indirect motor pathways, exacerbating impairments. In this study, we explore the impact of a drug-induced reduction in norepinephrine on motoneuron excitability, the diminished use of indirect motor pathways, and the consequent improvement in functional use of the affected arm.

PHR: Project Narrative Our previous research suggests the differential adverse effects and quantitative chest CT imaging characteristics of the longitudinal lung function trajectories of the WTC workers, and markers suggesting early chronic disabling lung disease. We thus propose to test the use of added respiratory surveillance tools and explore functional markers of disease progression, explore alternate methods to investigate longitudinal functional trajectories, and novel spirometry calibration methods that might facilitate the implementation of spirometry in nonspecialized settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardio-renal vascular dysfunction is a serious global public health challenge and may be associated with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and environmental toxins including world trade center-particulate matter (WTC-PM) have great impact on these two end organ diseases. This project will explore cardiovascular and renal vascular dysfunction/injury due to WTC exposure in WTC exposed first responders (Fire Department of the City of New York) and in murine WTC-PM exposure, specifically the role of macrophages and transforming growth factor-beta in the pathophysiology of renal dysfunction/fibrosis will be assessed. Successful completion of this project may identify biologically relevant biomarkers of WTC-PM-induced cardio-renal vascular injury.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: World Trade Center Particulate Matter-Associated End Organ Dysfunction: Targeting Early Vascular Dysfunction and Injury

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The  collective  burden  of  various  neurodegenerative  diseases  is  large,  yet  no  active  therapeutics  exist  to  effectively  slow  disease  onset  or  progression.  The  studies  proposed  in  this  application  will  allow  us  to  determine  the  molecular  and  cellular  mechanisms  through  which  ataxin- 1  regulates  oligodendroglial  differentiation  and  function,  and  will  elucidate  the  non- neuronal  contributions  to  neurodegenerative  diseases,  revealing  novel  potential  entry  points  for  therapeutic  intervention  in  disorders  associated  with  ataxin- 1  mutations  such  as  spinocerebellar  ataxia  type  1,  frontotemporal  dementia,  amyotrophic  lateral  sclerosis,  and  Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hepatitis C is a widely prevalent bloodborne viral infection that may lead to chronic liver disease and accounts for an estimated 1.1 million annual global deaths. Within the last six years, direct acting antivirals have demonstrated high cure rates across all genotypes in 8 to 12 weeks of all-oral treatment; however, the lack of nucleic acid amplification tests available to outpatient clinics has hampered the ability to link patients to available treatment and confirm their viral suppression after treatment. We propose to develop and validate a point-of- care, pan-genomic Hepatitis C nucleic acid test that can provide results in less than 30 minutes and be used by untrained users in a wide range of outpatient clinical settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: An estimated 20,000 deaths each year are attributable to skin cancer. There is a major need to better understand the molecular evolution of skin neoplasia, and to address this need, we propose development of a pre-cancer atlas of skin cancer. Completion of these studies will reveal diagnostic and prognostic markers of progression and open new avenues of therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative There are strong correlations between the bacterial communities that grow in the digestive system (the gut microbiome) and immune responses in the lungs in settings of chronic diseases. However, we understand very little about how this gut-lung axis regulates responses to acute bacterial infections in the lungs. My studies will reveal how the gut microbiome promotes respiratory host defense lung-derived signals that stimulate homeostatic Th17 immunity.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mass drug administration (MDA) of azithromycin (AZ) for children under 5 has the potential to reduce infections and mortality. In recent years, MDA AZ is being widely implemented across sub-Saharan Africa; yet there is little evidence on how its benefit in reducing child morbidity and mortality may be affected by the routine administration of seasonal malaria chemoprevention (SMC) and by contextual and socioeconomic factors that may affect access to treatment. This study will use rigorous intervention research and epidemiologic methods to examine if the effect of mass AZ is modified by SMC, and distance from health facilities and community wealth (as it relates to access to treatment/antibiotic) and provide new evidence on whether administering MDA AZ with SMC, and for communities with less access to healthcare is more effective in improving outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mutations in our genome often give cancer cells a fitness advantage to divide and survive uncontrollably, but, by virtue of their unique appearance in cancers, can also stimulate an anti-cancer immune response. The goal of this project is to dissect how the most common mutation in Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor, designated L858R, stimulates an anti-tumor immune response through activating T cells, key players of the immune system. Knowledge gained from this project will inform the development of wide-reaching, off-the-shelf immunotherapies for cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative As the World Trade Center general responder cohort ages, the implementation of healthy aging interventions that target health priorities of WTC general responders becomes increasingly important. The goals of this study are to: (1) examine the implementation of an intervention to improve medication use in WTC general responders; and (2) identify health priorities of aging WTC general responders that can inform future efforts to support healthy aging in this population. This work will enable the timely development and implementation of interventions to promote healthy aging that take into account the unique structure of the WTC clinical center of excellence programs as well as the characteristics and needs of the WTC general responder population.

PROJECT_TITLE: Promoting healthy aging and improving medication use in World Trade Center general responders

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project assesses how messaging about the tobacco product continuum of risk impacts adults who use combustible tobacco products (including those who have not yet been able to quit) and youth/young adults (those who have never used tobacco products and those who use non-combustible products). We will assess each audience's immediate response and receptivity to such messaging, psychophysiological effects highly predictive of behavior change, and immediate and longer-term (6-month) tobacco use behaviors using a series of six interconnected studies. This work has an adaptive and nimble design that will provide FDA with comprehensive, rigorous and organized evidence regarding message effects and effective message features for future public health communications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although cannabis use for both therapeutic and recreational treatment of mental health concerns is increasing, especially among emerging adults, a research gap assessing the cognitive and psychobiological mechanisms underlying cannabis use behaviors following a traumatic event remains. Two important cognitive processes involved in cannabis use decision-making are inhibitory control and reward motivation. The proposed project utilizes a multi-modal approach (i.e., psychophysiology, behavioral tasks, ecological momentary assessment, computational modeling) to identify and isolate idiographic profiles of these decisional processes and develop longitudinal models of posttraumatic stress and cannabis use behavior in emerging adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative: Early life sleep lays the foundation for the neural circuitry that facilitates affiliative behavior. This work will investigate how early life sleep disruption impacts the developmental trajectory of inhibition in brain regions involved in the display of affiliative behavior in the highly social prairie vole (Microtus ochrogaster). Finally, we directly probe a mechanism by testing whether an enriched sensory environment rescues impairments in circuit development and affiliative behavior induced by early life sleep disruption.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Somatic hypermutation and affinity maturation are critical parts of the development of highly specific antibodies in natural immune responses in addition to biomedical technology for development of new therapeutics. Agnathans (i.e., jawless vertebrates) and gnathostomes (i.e., jawed vertebrates) have functionally convergent but structurally divergent antibodies utilized and antigen receptors (antibodies) for the recognition of pathogens. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will further our understanding of the flexibility and limitations of SHM-mediated diversification and affinity maturation of structurally very different but functionally very similar antigen receptors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Degeneration of the stria vascularis within the inner ear leads to a major type of age-related hearing loss affecting hearing sensitivity and speech perception for many older adults. The proposed research will investigate how age-related changes in mitochondrial function within the stria vascularis impacts the inflammaging phenotype identified by cochlear macrophages. The results may highlight mitochondrial dysfunction as a key target aimed to ameliorate or slow the progression of chronic inflammation known to be associated with age-related hearing loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The axon initial segment is the site of action potential generation and requires high densities of voltage-gated ion channels to carry out this function. In contrast to other axon initial segment ion channels, it is unknown how Kv1 potassium channels are targeted to this subcellular domain. The goal of this project is to elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which Kv1 channels localize at the axon initial segment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over half of World Trade Center (WTC) exposed Fire Department of New York (FDNY) rescue and recovery workers developed gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), a risk factor for Barrett’s Esophagus (BE) and subsequent esophageal cancer. There is diminished health-related quality of life and productivity associated with aerodigestive diseases such as GERD and BE. Our research will continue to leverage the longitudinally phenotyped WTC exposed cohort, identify/validate novel biomarkers of WTC-aerodigestive disease, develop novel, noninvasive disease phenotyping to promote early diagnosis of premalignant disease, and identify potential targeted therapeutics; goals that are in line with the James Zadroga 9/11 Health & Compensation Act.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Aerodigestive Disease in the World Trade Center Exposed FDNY Cohort: Validation of Biomarkers and Defining Risk to Tailor Therapy

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Asthma is one of the most common physical health conditions in World Trade Center (WTC) responders, affecting approximately one third of individuals and it is a major source of morbidity and poor quality of life. In this study we will enhance and adapt an evidence-based asthma self-management support model for WTC responders with asthma and conduct a pilot randomized controlled trial to determine feasibility and preliminary impact, in preparation for a fully powered trial.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Comprehensive Self-Management Support for WTC Responders with Asthma

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As a social determinant of health, language barriers put patients who speak a language other than English (LOE) at increased risk for worse health outcomes in critical care. Yet, there is a significant gap in the science regarding prevention of ICU delirium for LOE patients. The proposed study will address this gap by exploring facilitators and barriers to ICU delirium prevention care for LOE patients in the ICU by interviewing key stakeholders in ICU delirium prevention care. Findings from this study will contribute to developing interventions in ICU delirium prevention for linguistically diverse patients that will improve health equity for this population of underserved patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Lung diseases represent an enormous worldwide health burden and most share old age as their primary risk factor, yet age is rarely studied as a variable in the lab. Age negatively impacts the repair function of alveolar type 2 cells, the crucial cells that protect the gas exchange surface, but it is unclear why. This project will improve our understanding of the contribution of immune signals in the aging lung to the repair dysfunction of alveolar type 2 cells; knowledge crucial to understanding the causation of lung disease and developing more effective medical care in older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Understanding the social and environmental determinants of mental health is a key objective for current clinical psychological research given the impact that such factors have on the emergence and maintenance of costly mental health disorders such as psychosis spectrum disorders. The proposed study will utilize an innovative multimethod approach combining census tract neighborhood databases, virtual neighborhood audits, ecological momentary assessment, geographical information science methodology, and virtual neighborhood visits by naïve raters to illuminate how neighborhood environmental factors contribute to momentary experiences of paranoid ideation and to examine whether these environments play an independent role in increasing paranoid ideation. Gaining understanding of how localized contextual factors contribute to momentary paranoid ideation is vital to accurately assessing psychosis spectrum symptomatology in the community and individually adapting community-based mental health treatments to maximize both short and long-term benefits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ovarian cancer is the deadliest gynecologic cancer with 80% of tumors diagnosed at a late stage though there is dras9cally higher survival for early-stage disease. This study proposes to develop novel methodologies to study the >50% of the genome comprising repeat elements in the context of ovarian tumor evolu9on and cell-free DNA, and to use genome-wide approaches to enable a non-invasive screening technology for ovarian cancer. Development of accessible screening and characteriza9on techniques for ovarian cancer has the poten9al to revolu9onize clinical prac9ce for this devasta9ng disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project seeks to understand the role of immune cells in the brain in multiple sclerosis, a central nervous system disorder with unclear causes and no cure. These immune cells, known as microglia, undergo profound changes in activity in the context of disease and have the ability to support nerves damaged by MS. Identifying how these immune cells are regulated in the context of MS may help pinpoint the causes and potential treatments for a disease that currently affects 3 million people.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE An estimated 53 million children under five years of age have developmental disability with 95% of these children living in low- and middle-income countries. This project leverages data from an ongoing R01 aimed to characterize the human milk components, and infant gut microbiome, growth and neurodevelopment in Kenya. The proposed aims will address gaps in knowledge of influence of maternal factors on child neurodevelopment, with an important focus on the varying breastmilk composition by maternal factors and provide the F32 candidate with the opportunity to acquire new methods and scientific expertise and develop necessary skills to become independent researcher.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Chronic alcohol consumption (CHD) has been shown to poise myeloid cells towards a hyper-inflammatory phenotype and impair key pathogen defense mechanisms. Aberrant myeloid cell responses, specifically tissue- resident macrophages, have been shown to significantly contribute to the pathophysiology of CHD-induced organ damage and alcohol use disorder. Since monocytes are precursors to tissues resident macrophages, and tissue-resident macrophages in organs and organ systems affected by CHD are hard to study longitudinally, this proposal seeks to gain insight into changes that occur in complex organs subsequent to CHD by investigating the effects of repeated bouts of abstinence and post-abstinence drinking on the functional, transcriptional, metabolic, and epigenetic profiles of circulating monocytes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The nervous system is composed of cell classes of varied form, function, and genetic profile, yet often these cells originate from the same population of multipotent progenitors. Here, I propose to elucidate the genetic networks regulated by the microRNA, miR9-2 and its distal enhancer, using an in vivo miR9-2 knockout mouse model which has been found to have retinal structure perturbations. This project will fill a gap in our knowledge regarding the specific role of miR9-2 in cell types of the developing retina, its function as a genetic regulator, and its potential contribution to disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In patients with aortic stenosis (the most common heart valve disease), imaging of the heart and aorta with Computed Tomography Angiography (CTA) allows doctors to noninvasively assess the aortic valve. The researchers propose to accurately characterize aortic stenosis by novel computerized measurements of fibrotic and calcific components of aortic valves, as well as their progression over time. They propose to further develop and validate new computerized risk scores, derived from these CTA measurements and clinical patient data using artificial intelligence, that will automatically identify the patient’s risk of suffering death or stroke, following minimally invasive transcatheter aortic valve replacement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Targeting signals integral to pancreatic cancer suppressive tumor microenvironment (TME) is an unmet need and an essential goal for achieving complete and durable responses to current therapy including immunotherapy. Here, we investigate a novel mechanism by which JAG1, a pancreatic cancer worse prognostic marker, regulates the suppressive TME by impairing the anti-tumor immune response of immune cell infiltration, metabolic fitness, and function. The overarching goal of this study is to test if targeting JAG1 could overcome pancreatic cancer immunotherapy-resistance and to reinvigorate anti-tumor response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) is a ubiquitous and medically significant pathogen which masterfully evades and manipulates host immune responses. As part of its life cycle, HCMV enters a quiescent state known as latency, which it accomplishes using a combination of viral and host factors. This project seeks to determine the ways HCMV manipulates the human immune system to its own advantage, to enhance viral latency and persistence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Parkinson’s disease is often treated with medications that affect brain dopamine and with chronic deep brain stimulation, but these can result in excessive movement, known as dyskinesia. We aim to understand the brain signals related to dyskinesia in humans, and how modulation of these signals by deep brain stimulation impacts benefits and side effects of stimulation. This work will provide mechanistic insight into medication-induced and stimulation-induced beneficial and adverse effects, and may provide physiological guidance adjusting brain stimulator settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: High blood pressure, a leading cause of heart disease and the primary cause of death in the world lacks a complete understanding of its root causes and mechanisms of often-seen recurrence. Recent studies have indicated that the immune system may contribute to this rise in blood pressure, with our lab revealing immune cells interacting with kidney cells, leading to increased salt and water retention. This study aims to identify factors triggering immune cell residence in the kidney and understand their role in long-term blood pressure elevation and recurrence, offering insights for improving medications and ultimately aspiring toward a cure for hypertension.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative This proposal seeks to engineer a targeting ligand for molecularly-specific treatment via peptide targeted radionuclide therapy (PTRT) in pancreatic cancer. Spatial sequencing of human pancreatic tumors with both spatial transcriptomics and CODEX (protein) allowed us to identify claudin-4 as a promising target and we will assess peptides with high affinity for this target through preclinical studies to create both an imaging agent and therapeutic radiopharmaceutical.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The dismal prognosis of pancreatic adenocarcinoma (PDAC) is in large part due to >80% of newly diagnosed cases being advanced in stage. Therefore, a better understanding of the progression of PDAC could inform earlier detection and interception strategies for PDAC. Herein, we will use a multi-disciplinary approach (the BForePC Team) to develop a 3D model of PDAC progression, focusing on a unique High-Risk population who carry mutations in relevant DNA repair genes (BRCA1, BRCA2, PALB2), as a first step, to understanding this heterogenous, complex devastating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The GTPase RAS serves as a critical molecular switch involved in cellular signaling, with mutations driving approximately 30% of human cancers. Despite persistent efforts over four decades to target RAS, once deemed undruggable, questions surrounding the spatiotemporal regulation of RAS remain. This proposal tackles these challenges by developing and applying of chemical genetic tools, protein engineering, and chemoproteomic methods to unravel how spatiotemporal compartmentalization governs RAS-driven signaling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Malignant gliomas represent 60% of all CNS tumors and are responsible for about 80% of all primary malignant brain tumors; yet despite recent efforts to identify genetic and molecular risk factors for glioma progression, we still do not have predictive markers to stratify clinical outcomes. We aim to understand the molecular and cellular mechanisms at the low-grade stage that are predictive of malignant transformation by constructing a comparative spatial atlas of LGGs with distinct progression outcomes. The atlas and the computational tools will allow us to not only predict the progression outcomes of the low-grade gliomas based on the tumor microenvironment, which is applicable to clinical risk assessment and early detection, but also to suggest therapeutic targets for intervention at an early stage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Our proposal brings a unique resources and technologies to create a Pediatric Tumor Microenvironment Atlas by focusing on novel single cell spatial biology tools to identify extrinsic effects attributable to tumor microenvironment on lineage plasticity and therapy resistance of childhood solid tumors including rhabdomyosarcoma, Wilms tumor, and neuroblastoma. Through spatial transcriptomic and proteomic technologies, the project will focus on classification of immune and non-immune cells comparing diagnostic samples among responders versus non-responders, and evaluating effect of therapy on TME and lineage plasticity that could aid in identifying resistant tumor phenotype. Identification of shared TME-induced pathways and networks across pediatric solid tumors could provide insights in devising novel immunotherapy approaches that would improve outcome and reduce reliance on chemotherapies and their long-term toxic sequala in children with solid tumor cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Prenatal alcohol exposure can cause a wide range of neurocognitive, behavioral, and functional impairments that persist throughout the lifespan. However, it is unknown how the postnatal family environment influences developmental trajectories in individuals with prenatal alcohol exposure. The proposed research will use a mixed methods approach to identify postnatal risk and resilience factors in the family environment and explore the impact of these risk factors on developmental outcomes in order to inform targeted interventions that address the unique needs of children who have been prenatally exposed to alcohol and their families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: SANFORD BURNHAM PREBYS MEDICAL DISCOVERY INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Age is a major risk factor for pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) with the median age at diagnosis and death being around 70 and 72 years old, respectively. It is not clear why PDAC is a disease of aging, but like other age-associated pathologies there are likely multiple variables at play. Using our preliminary data as a launching point, in this application we will develop new experimental models and decipher the mechanisms of how aging accelerates PDAC initiation and progression.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE An estimated 3 in 10 people with tuberculosis (TB)/HIV in sub-Saharan Africa have a suboptimal TB treatment outcome despite receiving effective anti-TB and anti-retroviral therapy (ART) regimens. Monthly health facility visits to collect anti-TB drugs and ART refills present several challenges due to both direct and indirect costs, resulting in poor healthcare access, continuity of care, and treatment adherence. The proposed studies will evaluate whether integrating TB treatment into community pharmacies (a well-established differentiated ART delivery model) can improve access to both anti-TB drugs and ART refills and enhance TB/HIV treatment outcomes, hence contributing to the End TB Strategy goals (zero TB deaths, zero TB infection, and zero catastrophic costs) and the UNAIDS target of ≥95% viral load suppression among people living with HIV.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the close link between depression and suicide, and the high prevalence of depression in transgender Veterans, the mental healthcare utilization patterns of transgender Veterans with depression are not well understood, nor the barriers to care this population faces. This project aims to identify an approach to address barriers to mental healthcare for transgender patients with depression The objective of this proposal is consistent with VA research priorities in mental health and health equity. The lessons learned will inform efforts to improve care for transgender Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  The development of catalytic methods for the synthesis of complex molecules from simple building blocks ultimately impacts the efficiency and cost at which pharmaceutical drugs can be made. This proposal outlines the development and mechanistic interrogation of a new method for the synthesis of enantioenriched amine- containing compounds, which are ubiquitous motifs found in many life-saving medicines. It is anticipated that the successful execution of the proposed research will reveal a general method for the conversion of simple building blocks to valuable products, which will be of interest to practicing chemists engaged in the synthesis of bioactive molecules.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Opioid use disorder (OUD) and associated overdoses are public health crises of increasing urgency in the United States, where overdose rates have skyrocketed in recent years. This F31 research proposal investigates the protection offered by a novel vaccine targeting oxycodone, a commonly abused prescription opioid. Based on the results of this research, we will inform effective vaccine design as a new treatment strategy in the face of the growing opioid epidemic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative (3 sentences) The incidences of several devastating age-related neurodegenerative diseases (NDDs) are on the rise as improved therapies for other conditions such as cancer and coronary artery disease have resulted in an aging population. Recent work has suggested that shared neuroinflammatory mechanisms play a crucial, although still somewhat unclear role in multiple NDDs. The current proposal focuses on understanding the role of the MS4A family of genes in neuroinflammatory processes in the context of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), with the hope that this will provide mechanistic insight across a number of distinct NDDs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVE Defects and diseases of bones and teeth affect a large portion of the population and significantly reduce the quality of life of individuals, yet current therapies lack efficacy and predictable outcomes, therefore identification of novel factors and approaches for repair and regeneration is a critical goal. Bone sialoprotein (BSP), an extracellular matrix protein found in mineralized tissues, is important in proper skeletal and dental development. We aim to define the mechanistic functions of BSP in periodontal and skeletal development and repair and test the efficacy of BSP as a novel therapeutic for treating bone defects and injuries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute traumatic brain injury (TBI) is causally linked to chronic neurodegeneration and is the leading environmental risk factor for Alzheimer’s disease (AD), yet the reasons why are not understood. In this study, I will investigate the role of hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) dysfunction in mediating the transition from acute TBI to chronic neurodegeneration, and will examine HSC dysfunction in AD and TBI-accelerated AD. Through this research, I aim to contribute to our understanding of the pathophysiology of these neurodegenerative diseases and guide future treatments by unveiling novel therapeutic targets to counteract progressive neurodegeneration.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In South Africa, people with HIV (PWH) face synergistic psychosocial and situational stressors that increase their risks for suicide and adversely affect outcomes across the HIV care continuum, including delayed antiretroviral therapy initiation, poor treatment adherence, increased risk of transmission, and lower life expectancy. This study aims to 1) explore primary healthcare-level suicide treatment practices, gaps, and needs among PWH; 2a) develop a brief behavioral intervention addressing suicide and HIV care engagement (MI-Cope-Care); 2b) refine MI-Cope-Care in an iterative, sequential pre-pilot study; and 3) evaluate the feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary effectiveness of MI-Cope-Care in a pilot randomized controlled trial. If MI-Cope-Care is found to be feasible and acceptable, it will produce the first intervention in South Africa that addresses the dual burdens of suicide and HIV, which could be further examined for effectiveness and application in other resource-constrained settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative While growing fully functional skin in culture would greatly benefit a diverse array of patients, including those with severe burns, slowly healing wounds, and advanced forms of scarring alopecia, developing skin in culture with hair follicles that are correctly arranged in a spatial pattern has been particularly difficult to accomplish. Turing’s Reaction-Diffusion model has long been employed to theoretically explain periodic pattern formation; however, data from our lab has unveiled striking plasticity in hair follicle placode formation, uncovering a robust program for developing a periodic pattern. In this project, we will test the hypothesis that long-distance cell migration, rather than local signaling, serves as an underlying mechanism for hair placode induction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over 60% of T cell acute lymphoblastic leukemias (T-ALLs) harbor mutations in the NOTCH1 signaling pathway; however, pan-Notch inhibitors are associated with significant toxicities. We previously showed that the lymphoid- restricted transcription factor ETS1 is essential for Notch-activated T-ALL survival, but not essential for overall health. Here, we propose a study to define the downstream oncogenic pathways and cis-regulatory elements of ETS1 in T-ALL, which may lead to new anti-leukemic strategies without intolerable toxicities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glioblastoma (GBM) is a highly malignant primary brain tumor and with a median survival of 15 months despite aggressive surgical and chemotherapeutic interventions. Glioblastoma stem-like cells (GSCs) are the key cells responsible for initiating this tumor and they can adapt to the complex environment in the brain, even areas of low oxygen. This project will help us develop a deeper understanding of GSC biology, especially the tools of translation regulation (mRNA-to-protein), as they are corrupted for use in stressful low-oxygen conditions thereby revealing a novel list of targets for future therapy in GBM patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Copy number variations (CNVs) of Apolipoprotein L1 (APOL1) are associated with nondiabetic kidney diseases, albeit the allelic architecture of the APOL1 kidney disease risk variants within CNVs remains unclear. Our studies aim to discriminate the non-risk and risk variant copies within APOL1 CNVs and determine the functional consequences of APOL1 CNVs. This research will provide insights into risk variant dosage mechanisms of APOL1 CNVs as a driver for the phenotypic variability observed in APOL1-associated nondiabetic kidney diseases in African Americans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are numerous retinal and systemic conditions that negatively impact the development of the fovea, a specialized anatomical region of the retina that supports high-acuity vision. This project aims to investigate structural and functional specializations of the fovea, including one such condition, using a combination of clinical and research-grade non-invasive ocular imaging tools. The training environment is particularly suited to support my interests in translational research and my development into a successful, independent vision scientist.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mammalian embryogenesis is a robust process with numerous checkpoints and corrective processes in place to ensure proper development. The proposed project sets forth to examine how morphogenesis regulates cell cycle remodeling during early postimplantation development and identify how this paradigm may contribute to cell number regulation in the mammalian embryo. Increased understanding of the details of developmental transitions in normal and perturbed conditions will reveal novel insight into the mechanisms regulating developmental robustness in mammalian embryos.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Mutation to WW-domain containing adapter with coiled-coil (WAC), an adapter in the deposition of histone H2B ubiquitination (H2Bub), leads to DeSanto-Shinawi Syndrome, a neurodevelopmental disorder with autism-like characteristics. The proposed studies will leverage genomic and behavioral analyses to define the role of WAC in H2Bub-dependent gene regulation in neurons, exploring the hypothesis that WAC facilitates proper neuronal activity-dependent transcription. This work will establish H2Bub as a novel epigenetic regulator of neuronal activity and provide insight into the molecular etiology of neurodevelopmental disorders driven by dysfunction of H2Bub regulators.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative CADASIL (Cerebral Autosomal Dominant Arteriopathy with Subcortical Infarcts and Leukoencephalopathy) patients often experience strokes and cognitive impairment, and while disease causing mutations in the protein NOTCH3 have been studied deeply in brain blood vessels, a key cell type that envelops brain blood vessels known as the pericyte is virtually unstudied in this disease despite ample NOTCH3 presence. The goal of this proposal is to improve our understanding of pericyte contributions to early brain blood flow deficits seen in this disease as pericytes contribute to multiple blood flow control mechanisms. Determining the role that pericytes play in disease progression can lead to identification of targets for early therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A new ligament surgery that stimulates the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) to heal has shown promise in reducing post-surgical posttraumatic osteoarthritis. We believe the reason behind this is that the new surgery restores the native ACL and its neural elements that normally provide information about joint function to the central nervous system, while conventional surgery does not. The parent randomized clinical trial will tell us whether the new surgery is at least as good as the conventional one, and the ancillary study will tell us whether, and how, the new surgery restores muscle and joint function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recently, we have demonstrated that patients with heart failure have decreased acyl-carnitines in heart biopsies as compared to controls, but still have normal (HFpEF) or increased (HFrEF) acyl-carnitines in the blood. This project tests the hypothesis that extracellular acyl-carnitines are taken up and oxidized by cardiomyocytes and intact hearts, that this rises under hemodynamic or metabolic stress, and is impaired by reduced transporters in HF. Understanding how extracellular acyl-carnitines are (or are not) utilized in the normal heart, and hearts under acute or chronic stress could lead to better strategies to metabolically counter heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will reveal how the brain integrates information about speech over time, both in silence and in the presence of background noise. The results of these experiments will further our knowledge of the computations that enable speech recognition in noisy real-world conditions, as well as how auditory cortex flexibly adapts to changing environments. Answering these questions is a critical step towards understanding the deficits in listening in noise that are present in auditory neurodevelopmental and attentional disorders.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Women participating in shift work are more likely to develop premenstrual disorders, indicating an overlooked opportunity to understand how light-induced disruption of biological rhythms, sex hormones, and mood impact women’s reproductive health. This project aims to uncover the connection between mood and menstrual cycle abnormalities using both shiftwork-like lighting conditions and site-specific viral approaches. This new knowledge is a first step towards future studies to understand and mitigate the harmful effects of shift work on women’s reproductive health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Arousal is a ubiquitous influence on the brain that continuously fluctuates during wakefulness and enables sensation and perception. This project aims to elucidate the arousal-dependent effects on subpopulations of excitatory cortical neurons in terms of their response properties and subsequent impact on behavior. Results from these experiments could advance our understanding of the neural correlates of optimal performance and motivate novel theories on decision-making, sensory encoding, and the function of specific cortical cell-types.

The proposed work is to use the nematode C. elegans as a model system to investigate how several novel Slo2 channel regulators perform their physiological functions, with the long-term goal being to better understand Slo2 channel physiological functions and diseases caused by Slo2 channel mutations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Seasonal malaria chemoprevention and RTS,S vaccination are new interventions available to prevent malaria in children under five years of age in malaria-endemic countries. We need to understand their impact on the risk of malaria as the children get older because school-age children already have a high burden of malaria infection. We propose a longitudinal cohort study of four groups of children with exposures to different combinations of interventions to evaluate their impact on the risk of malaria as the children get older and examine the sustained effect on the human immune responses and the parasite.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Myeloid malignancies are prevalent and result in significant morbidity and mortality, yet patient outcomes may differ substantially even when the same driver gene is mutated. Exploring the dysregulation of alternative polyadenylation, a post-transcriptional regulatory mechanism, in AML will enhance our comprehension of disease heterogeneity and contribute to our understanding of molecular drivers of hematologic malignancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Transfer (t)RNAs are a class of small regulatory RNAs required for protein synthesis. Aberrant tRNA processing, modification, and expression has been associated with rare and common genetically complex neurological diseases, however, tools to measure tRNAs at the single cell level are lacking. We propose to develop a novel single nuclei tRNA sequencing method to profile tRNAs in human stem cell based organoid development and disease to reveal new pathophysiological mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Preeclampsia (PE) is a pregnancy-specific disorder that is characterized by hypertension and proteinuria (maternal syndrome) developing after the 20th week of gestation, and PE is the leading cause of maternal morbidity and mortality in the United States, affecting about 5-7% of pregnancies. Given the great health and economic burden of PE, there is tremendous importance for better understanding the mechanisms involved in the progression of preeclampsia especially since mother and child are impacted by this disease. The studies in this proposal will help understand the progression of the disease by testing the hypothesis that maternal syndrome in Dahl SS rats is an outcome of improper placentation resulting in an increased oxidative stress due to infiltration of T cells into kidneys and placental tissue causing subsequent endothelial dysfunction that contributes to the development of hypertension and renal damage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over 10 million women in the United States have reported experiencing reproductive coercion, a form of intimate partner violence involving deliberate actions to undermine a person’s reproductive choices, such as sabotaging contraception, thereby increasing women’s risk for sexually transmitted infections, including HIV. The proposed mixed methods study will explore social determinants of health influencing reproductive coercion prevalence, focusing on neighborhood socioeconomic status, healthcare access, and state contraception policy. Findings are anticipated to inform the development of an intervention to address the health information and support needs of affected women to prevent further violence and the acquisition of sexually transmitted infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Humans and other mammals use strong nasal inhalations, or sniffs, to smell the world, providing them with information about nearby foods, animals, and the local environment. This project aims to understand how the parabrachial nucleus, a part of the brain implicated in respiratory control, may contribute to the generation of sniffing behaviors in mice. This work will ultimately contribute to our understanding of smell and active sensing in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The concomitant presence of chronic kidney disease (CKD) substantially increases the risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD) for persons with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM). Yet, widely available therapies that can vastly lower this risk remain markedly under-prescribed. In response, this proposal seeks to design, implement and evaluate an educational intervention to increase prescription of cardio-renal preventive therapies among patients with T2DM and CKD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE More than seven million Americans are currently living with Alzheimer's disease (AD) and related tauopathies, and although significant progress has been made in delineating critical innate immune receptors involved in disease progression, much of the downstream signaling molecules modulating this immune response remain inadequately described. In our preliminary studies using a tau-based model of AD and frontotemporal dementia, we have identified an integral role for the immune signaling kinase, SYK. This project aims to further characterize the role of SYK in the exacerbation AD pathology through the regulation of microglia activation and to also evaluate if delayed SYK deletion is therapeutically efficacious in limiting tauopathy onset and progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Generating hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) in vitro represents a central aim in regenerative biology due to their significant therapeutic potential for the treatment of blood diseases, including leukemia and lymphomas. In vitro derivation of HSCs for use in the clinic still remains challenging, in part due to incomplete understanding of the steps leading to blood development in vivo. This proposal aims to use next-generation molecular recording technologies to shed light on the biology of developmental hematopoiesis, focusing on the origin, molecular drivers and extrinsic triggers of the process, with the overarching aim of informing and improving strategies for HSC derivation in vitro.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Advancing methods of prevention and early detection for melanoma, the deadliest skin cancer, is critical. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is relevant to public health because healthcare discrimination is common, inequitably experienced, and associated with worse health outcomes. One way discrimination and stigma manifest in the healthcare system is through electronic health record (EHR) documentation; the prevalence and impact of EHR stigmatizing language in cancer care has not been investigated but may contribute to disparities in clinical decision-making and patient outcomes. Thus, this research aligns with the NIH’s mission to lead research in cancer survivorship, reduce health disparities, and help all people live longer, healthier lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Chlamydia trachomatis (CT) causes roughly 128 million sexually transmitted infections globally each year. There are currently few interventions to protect people from infection with CT. This project will use data from research and disease surveillance to assess the feasibility of antibiotic treatment shortly after exposure to prevent CT infection and to estimate the population-level health impacts and cost-effectiveness of a hypothetical vaccine delivered before exposure to CT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Multidrug-resistant bacterial pathogens pose a serious public health problem that requires new solutions. I propose a strategy to combat Gram-positive pathogens through manipulation of the bacteria’s own chemical signaling system. This work will provide valuable insights into how bacteria produce the signals that trigger virulence along with new tools to fight pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genetic variants are typically transmitted from the parents to their offspring, but they can also arise after conception (post-zygotically acquired) during embryonic development. Genetic variants in SLC35A2 arising during brain development have recently been implicated in intractable focal epilepsy. In this study, we seek to: (1) determine the brain cell types involved in SLC35A2 epilepsy, (2) study effects of the variants on neuronal glycosylation, neuronal development, and neuronal activity, and (3) assess the ability of galactose supplementation to reverse the deleterious effects of the variants on neurons.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) is a promising neuromodulatory intervention for major depressive disorder (MDD), but the mechanism by which rTMS alters glutamatergic activity and functional connectivity to improve MDD symptoms is not fully understood. Here, we address methodological limitations in the extant literature by leveraging ultra-high field glutamate chemical exchange saturation transfer (GluCEST) imaging, resting-state functional magnetic resonance imaging (rsfMRI), and research-grade clinical phenotyping before and after a clinical rTMS intervention to elucidate clinically relevant glutamatergic and functional changes induced by rTMS. This proposal, rich with valuable training opportunities for the applicant, has the potential to generate unprecedented mechanistic insight that could lay the foundation for developing new and more personalized rTMS interventions for MDD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This study aims to investigate how antigen-specific immunotherapy can selectively inhibit autoreactive T cells in autoimmune diabetes. Specifically, the research focuses on how induction of tolerance to a hybrid insulin peptide impacts the differentiation and function of autoreactive CD4 and CD8 T cells and how IL10+ regulatory T cells influence tolerance induction. The results of this study could provide important insights into the mechanisms underlying autoreactive T cell suppression following antigen-specific tolerance induction, potentially leading to the development of more effective immunotherapies for autoimmune diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative: Over 40 million people in the United States suffered from substance use disorder (SUD) in 2020. Exposure to chronic, unavoidable stress is a major contributor to drug misuse and high rates of recidivism for individuals with SUD. The goal of this fellowship is to further understand the harmful interaction between chronic stress and drug use in the context of altered neuroimmune communication to identify novel targets for attenuating stress effects in SUD.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the United States, over 4 million births occur each year, and opioids are commonly prescribed to pregnant individuals for acute pain following surgery and childbirth. However, opioid prescribing is highly variable and often excessive, and few guidelines exist to direct postoperative pain management that are tailored to the needs of pregnant patients. In this prospective study, we will develop evidence-based, patient-centered guidelines to support postoperative pain management for pregnant and birthing individuals, create pragmatic strategies for guideline dissemination and implementation, and examine the effectiveness of guidelines and adaptive implementation strategies on the optimization of clinical and patient-reported outcomes for postoperative pain management.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Clinical Practice Guidelines for Postoperative Pain in Pregnancy: Evidence, Dissemination, and Impact

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The sensory cells that respond to sound and gravitational stimuli have specialized structures on both their apical surface to detect mechanical stimuli and on their basal end to convert this stimulus to an electrical signal. This work aims to understand the functional maturation of human hair cells in stem-cell-derived human inner ear organoids. It also aims to study the dysfunction of these cells in a genetic disorder known to cause hearing and balance disorders and prevent their onset with viral-mediated gene therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Dengue virus (DENV) causes millions of infections every year. The development of innovative disease control programs and forecasting methods requires an understanding of which DENV lineages cause outbreaks and of how these lineages spread and persist within communities. Through the proposed aims, we will determine how long it takes for DENV to cause an outbreak from the point of introduction and what environmental factors increase or decrease the time to outbreak.

PHR: This time-sensitive ancillary study to the TRUST trial will provide novel samples, matched samples of immune cells from blood and from synovial fluid of affected joints in active gout flare. These mechanistic studies of gouty inflammation may lead to new therapies that target the molecular basis of gout flares.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol use disorder is characterized by the inability of controlling or stopping alcohol use, even in the face of negative consequences or after long-term abstinence. Research shows that ventral tegmental area (VTA) dopaminergic neurons drive reward-seeking behavior and increased value of reward-associated cues while related studies show GABAB receptors and baclofen constraining behaviors like cue-induced reinstatement and compulsive alcohol use in the presence of an aversive stimulant. However, which receptors control the activity of VTA dopamine neurons on cue-related behaviors and which specific neuronal populations in the VTA are responsible for baclofen’s effects has yet to be determined, therefore, we are proposing test the role of GABAB receptors in VTA dopamine neurons on cue-induced reinstatement, aversion resistant drinking, and on the previously seen effects of baclofen.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Glymphatic activity (specifically the movement of neurofluid in extracellular and extravascular space that drains soluble neural metabolites from the nervous system) is essential for brain health, and development of interventional approaches to enhance glymphatic activity has great implication to care of neurological disorders including Alzheimer’s disease. We propose to 1) assess the feasibility of modulating glymphatic system through electromagnetic field-based slow wave entrainment in pigs anesthetized with propofol, and 2) measure the impact of slow wave entrainment on glymphatic activity using multi-contrast MRI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is characterized by progressive deterioration of the aortic wall and catastrophic aortic failure resulting in sudden death in >80% of acute ruptures leading to the death of at least 15,000 Americans every year. Unfortunately, there are no pharmacological treatments available for the prevention of AAA progression and the only option for these patients is surgical intervention. Our proposal seeks to evaluate platelets as the source of protective transforming growth factor β (TGFβ) and adventitial fibroblasts as the target cell type mediating this protection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Cardiovascular disease accounts for 1 in 3 individuals in the US, often resulting from pressure-overload induced growth of the heart and consequent heart failure, a chronic condition for which we have no cure and a great unmet clinical need. The proposed work will study newly discovered aspects of vital cellular processes that are disrupted during pathological growth and contribute to progressive heart failure. Our studies will provide insight into whether targeting these disrupted cellular processes can serve as an effective therapeutic strategy to reduce mortality from heart disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Food insecurity disproportionately affects people with diabetes mellitus and is associated with suboptimal diabetes self-management behaviors and poor diabetes outcomes such as hypoglycemia, poor glycemic control, and increased acute healthcare utilization. A diabetes self-management education and support program tailored to the needs of people with food insecurity may improve these outcomes. The proposed research will use quantitative and qualitative methods to determine the nutritional, behavioral, and psychological barriers to diabetes self-management for people with food insecurity and type 2 diabetes to inform the adaptation and development of a DSMES program tailored for this population.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Disruptions to gastrulation, namely the formation of the three main germ layers of the body, are a threat to reproductive success and children’s health. Mounting evidence points to metabolic environment as a key regulator of cell fate, yet even the impact of known epigenetically active metabolites like 2-hydroxyglutarate (2- HG) have yet to be interrogated in post-implantation development. By elucidating the impact of maternal 2-HG accumulation on mammalian gastrulation, this project will offer valuable insight into the role of metabolic environment in early development and reproductive fitness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  Up to 50% of the variance determining who develops Posttraumatic Stress Disorder following a severe trauma may be genetic; however, most successful analyses to date suggest that risk arises from multiple common genetic variants of small effect size, and that very large sample sizes will be needed for detection. This proposal aims to uncover the genomic architecture of PTSD through large-scale, collaborative genome- wide association studies. Identifying the pathways underlying PTSD will lead to an improved neurobiological understanding, enhanced prevention, and improved treatment of this debilitating and prevalent syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Supplement to Parent Grant Dysregulation of Cav1.2 by beta amyloid peptide The L-type Ca2+ channel Cav1.2 constitutes one of the most important influx pathways for Ca2+ into neurons. Ca2+ in turn is a potent regulator of neuronal excitability and gene expression. During our work on the role of b amyloid peptide 1-42 (Ab) on LTD via regulation of Cav1.2 by the beta 2 adrenergic receptor we realized that in adult mice standard LTD can only be induced during the active circadian phase of mice and requires the regulation of Cav1.2 by the b2 AR by its natural ligand, norepinephrine (NE), which mediates wakefulness. For the Supplement we propose to test whether LTD in adult mice has a circadian rhythm that is driven by the established increase NE during active (night) phase and acts via b2 AR – Cav1.2 signaling. This work will help elucidate molecular mechanisms that mediate alertness and are likely important for attention and constitute potential targets for treatment of ADHD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The principal goal of the Simian Collective is to showcase the significance of nonhuman primates in neuroscience research, including the unique significance of nonhuman primates as translational models of human neurological and neuropsychiatric diseases, disorders, and healthy and impaired aging. The meeting is organized to emphasize that realizing the maximal impact of nonhuman primate models in the 21st Century necessitates complementing cutting-edge research with neuroethical considerations, as well as educating our young investigators and the broader scientific and general communities about the importance of nonhuman primate neuroscience research. This meeting will provide an important forum to build the community involvement needed to take these critical steps in the next chapter of the field and to train the next generation of nonhuman primate neuroscientists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As the aging US population increases and interventions for dementia become available for early stages, there is a growing need for low-cost sensitive tools to detect early cognitive decline in large samples. Digital phenotyping, a novel approach involving passive data collection from sensors on personal devices, such as smartwatches, could fill this gap to estimate early autonomic dysfunction and health behaviors associated with early cognitive decline. This project will examine the validity of several metrics from a commercially available and low-cost smartwatch in a diverse sample of older adults, which could have broad implications for health behavior monitoring, early detection of cognitive decline, and targeted interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Most cancer deaths result from spread of the primary tumor to distant sites, a process called metastasis, and patients with osteosarcoma are no exception. A major limitation in the development of targeted anti-metastatic therapies in osteosarcoma and other types of cancer is a lack of understanding of common biological contributors to this process. This study seeks to apply recent advances in the understanding of epigenetic gene regulation and OS biology to the study of lung metastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People with obesity experience physiological, neural, and behavioral changes resulting in decreases in metabolic rate and increases in appetite, making weight-loss extremely challenging. As to why obesity pathology is persistent, my overarching hypothesis is that obesity strengthens feeding neural circuits driving the continued consumption of palatable foods in excess of caloric requirement. To inform novel therapies for producing robust weight loss, it is critical to understand the mechanism for how these foods alter neural circuits involved in initiating and sustaining pathological overeating behavior.
