IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVE We will develop an in vitro salivary gland Sjögren’s syndrome (SS) tissue chip (SSTC) platform that will enable mechanistic studies of the disease pathogenesis which is predominately diagnosed in older woman. The proposed studies will investigate the effect of endocrine disrupting chemicals exposure on salivary gland function which may be important in the pathogenesis. The SSTC will enable future high throughput drug discovery studies. Currently there are no disease modifying drugs to treat SS patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE Eukaryotes depend on the faithful delivery of protein cargo to the correct subcellular location and perturbations to the factors directing these processes give rise to various human diseases. This project will characterize novel regulators of membrane trafficking, that function across a diverse range of cellular processes, using a combination of in vivo and in vitro experiments. The unique insights gained from this research will contribute to our fundamental understanding of membrane biology and will impact the treatment of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the clear link between oxidative stress and cardiac disease, antioxidant treatments have been unsuccessful in lessening the high morbidity and mortality rates of cardiac disease alluding to the fact that increased oxidative stress may be secondary to disease pathology rather than causative. This application aims to assess whether upregulation of DRP1 contributes to the development of vascular endothelial dysfunction that subsequently progresses to cardiac damage, mitochondrial dysregulation, and metabolic dysfunction independent of increased formation of reactive oxygen species (ROS). The proposed studies use a novel rodent model to test the hypothesis that increased endothelial DRP1 leads to increased mitochondrial fragmentation, changes in metabolism, increased ROS production, and functional changes in the microcirculation and the heart.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bacteria belonging to the genus Streptococcus are responsible for various human diseases and phosphorylation of proteins plays a major role in bacterial physiology and virulence. In this study, we propose to unravel the role of arginine phosphorylation, a novel form of phosphorylation, in the pathophysiology of streptococci. Our study could potentially identify a novel bacterial arginine kinase and shed new molecular insights into how arginine phosphorylation modulates streptococcal proteome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pediatric frequent asthma exacerbators, defined as those experiencing >1 hospitalization for asthma in a calendar year, are responsible for an outsized proportion of asthma morbidity and mortality. This project aims to characterize the molecular pathways and cell-specific responses dysregulated in this important subgroup. Deeper understanding of these pathways and their potential mediators will uncover new knowledge critical for further mechanistic study and identification of targets for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In many animals, the propensity to preferentially engage in certain behaviors along day/night cycles is primarily attributed to central circadian clock neurons; however, it remains undetermined whether and how peripheral sensory neurons can contribute to this behavioral rhythmicity. Using Drosophila as a model, this project identifies a neuromodulatory mechanism by which the day or night condition rhythmically regulates peripheral olfactory acuity to external social cues via the antagonistic actions of biogenic amines.The mechanistic insights expected from this research will shed light on the critical roles of peripheral sensory neuromodulation in gating odor-guided behavior by day/night cycles.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic pain affects nearly 100 million people in the US. Managing pain with opiates has increased the incidence of opioid use disorder and overdose deaths, and therefore effective pain therapeutics with lower abuse potential are needed. This proposal will isolate how Δ9-tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) functions in pain circuits during chronic neuropathic pain and provide new insight into how the endocannabinoid system may regulate and be used to target chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative A Disintegrin and Metalloprotease 10 (ADAM10) is an enzyme that catalyzes the ectodomain shedding of critical signaling and adhesion proteins including Notch, amyloid precursor protein, and cadherins, and its dysregulation is implicated in the development of varied pathologies including neurodegenerative diseases and several cancers. ADAM10 is tightly regulated by the C8 subclass of tetraspanin proteins (TspanC8s) according to mechanisms that are incompletely understood. This proposal aims to combine structural and functional studies of an ADAM10-Tspan5 complex to elucidate mechanisms by which TspanC8s influence ADAM10 substrate selectivity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative 79% of flu-related deaths between the 2010/11-2019/20 seasons were of people 65 years or older, and although vaccinations are strongly encouraged in this group, elderly vaccine responses are consistently impaired. This study will define the role of CXCL13 as an aging-associated defect in memory T cell homeostasis using CRISPR-engineered tonsil organoids. Results obtained here will improve our understanding of aging immune memory, thus providing the potential for future therapies directed at this axis and limiting the number of deaths to vaccine-preventable diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Our proposed work seeks to improve the efficiency and accuracy of endodontic diagnosis even for those who have communication challenges, such as children, using quantifiable physiomarkers of pain. Dental caries is one of the major causes of endodontic infection in the pulp or soft tissues of the tooth and is estimated that at least 2 billion adults and 520 million children suffer from dental caries worldwide. Endodontic infection can cause hypersensitivity, severe pain, and even death, but its diagnosis is currently difficult and dependent on qualitative patient input.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed studies will fill the knowledge gap in understanding the biomechanical interplay between peripapillary sclera and optic nerve head, a critical factor influencing the eye’s mechanical susceptibility to intraocular pressure. Combined with the development of a translatable technique to image such interplay in vivo, this knowledge will lay the groundwork for developing novel diagnostic and therapeutic strategies to better mitigate glaucoma-related vision loss.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative The Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act (EMTALA) established a duty for hospitals to screen and stabilize patients presenting to emergency departments with emergent medical or psychiatric conditions regardless of ability to pay. A multidisciplinary team of sponsors, co-sponsors, and key advisors will provide support and guidance as the applicant develops and completes projects to 1) identify and characterize EMTALA citation events involving psychiatric emergencies, 2) explore novel measures of hospital capacity to care for patients with psychiatric emergencies, and 3) evaluate the association between hospital capacity to care for patients with psychiatric emergencies and receipt of EMTALA citations. Through didactics and completion of these projects, the applicant will learn about and gain experience with health policy/analysis, qualitative methods, quantitative methods, impactful dissemination of findings, and grantsmanship, as he trains to become an independent health services researcher.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Patient Dumping and EMTALA Enforcement Involving Psychiatric Emergencies

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Glomerular disease is responsible for a large part of the chronic kidney diseases cases around the world but have very few specific and effective treatments due to poorly understood pathogenic mechanisms. There is a large body of evidence that points to sphingolipid metabolism as a driving force in the progression of glomerular disease. This study aims to define the mechanisms by which alterations in sphingolipid balance and signaling lead to renal injury, thereby allowing us to target these pathways in search of better therapeutic options for patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative This study uses ecological momentary assessment (EMA) to investigate momentary associations between stress and alcohol craving and use in a group of highly stressed mothers of adolescents and whether mindfulness moderates this association. The goal of this study is to identify targets for interventions that may disrupt associations between stress and drinking. Findings from this study will be used to inform interventions, including smartphone-based just-in-time interventions, for alcohol-related problems that may be tailored to meet the needs of women who have been underrepresented in alcohol literature and who have unique social demands and stressors (e.g., parenting).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Transcriptional control is fundamental to neuronal differentiation, and mutations in machinery critical to this process, such as the Integrator and Z3 complex, give rise to neurodevelopmental defects. Integrator and its associated Z3 complex regulate promoter-proximal RNA Polymerase II, but the molecular underpinnings of this interaction and its importance to brain development are unknown. My work will define the significance of Z3 and INT to neural differentiation using biochemical and functional genomics approaches to shed light on transcriptomic changes crucial for neuron formation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it identifies sex differences and potential sex- specific therapeutic targets that will impact the clinical care of patients with musculoskeletal pain. This innovative proposal will explore the underlying mechanisms that differentially effect females and males with ischemic muscle pain. This project is aligned with the priority of the NIH Federal Pain Research Strategy to “Elucidate Sex-Specific Pain Mechanisms and Determine their Implications for Optimal Treatment of Pain in Females and Males.”

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal aims to train Jenna Mendelson in molecular and cellular cardiac physiology in order to become an independently funded scientist conducting cardiovascular basic science research to combat cardiovascular disease. Her project investigates the role of mitochondrial fatty acid metabolism in a large animal model of right ventricular dysfunction. During her training, she will develop a new skillset including cardiac MRI, molecular biology techniques, and bioinformatics approaches that will enable her to develop into a productive, independent research scientist conducting translational research, and potentially identify a new therapeutic target for right ventricular dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: The International Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) Meeting Series is unique in providing an interdisciplinary, collaborative environment that convenes representatives from all fields involved in BCI research, including scientists, engineers, clinicians, policymakers, and users. The 2025 BCI Meeting will highlight innovative approaches and applications for BCIs, discuss progress towards translation, address key issues critical to further progress, and promote the education and participation of young researchers. This meeting and the resulting comprehensive publications will, like its predecessors, foster the translation of BCIs into clinically- viable devices.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While emerging adults who are not students or graduates of four-year colleges (N4YCEAs) experience greater levels of alcohol misuse and alcohol-related consequences, as compared with four-year college students and graduates, they have relatively limited access to evidence-based brief alcohol interventions (BAIs). In the proposed study we will examine the preferences of N4YCEAs for engaging in BAIs and we will explore the facilitators and barriers to implementing BAIs in the settings they prefer. This mixed methods community- engaged project will lay the foundation for an innovative program of research into the implementation of BAIs in community settings to address this significant public health priority.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease remains the leading cause of death in the United States and worldwide. Using the Multi-Ethnic Study of Atherosclerosis, this project evaluates the novel hypothesis that the presence of food specific IgE (sensitization), a prevalent condition, is a risk factor for cardiovascular disease, and that consumption of the food allergen modifies this risk. Establishing food sensitization as a risk factor for cardiovascular disease would provide new opportunities for prevention and could have major implications for how food allergy is managed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As seen with the COVID-19 pandemic and aftermath, RNA viruses continue to be a threat to public health and demand evolution in vaccines and therapeutics. Ironically, some RNA viruses contain molecular tools that can be co-opted to combat emerging viruses. This project is focused on identifying novel architectural strategies used by RNA viruses that can be integrated in therapeutic vaccination systems to combat viruses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Engineered cell therapies have successfully treated many blood cancers but have experienced challenges treating solid tumors due to issues involving specificity of the cells for the tumor and how the tumor suppresses these therapeutic cells. This project aims to address these challenges to improve the safety and potency of solid tumor cell therapy by engineering cells with a synthetic genetic circuit that allows them to sense modestly hypoxic tumors and express molecules to kill tumor cells and mitigate immunosuppression. If successful, this project will provide a new therapeutic technology that enables the development of safer, more effective cell therapies for solid tumors.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Glaucoma degrades vision and quality of life in hundreds of thousands of veterans. To date, vision loss resulting from the disease is irreversible. Lowering intraocular pressure (IOP) has been proven beneficial for most patients, but low patient compliance with daily eye drop regimens hampers the treatment success. We have previously demonstrated that transplantation of induced pluripotent stem cell derived material into the anterior chamber of the eye can reestablish the eye's natural ability to control IOP. The goal of this project is to test more efficient transplantation strategies, evaluate whether allotransplantation Is effective and safe and, crucially, to demonstrate that rehabilitation of IOP control is possible in human eyes with primary open angle glaucoma. This highly innovative treatment approach could provide physicians with a new therapeutic option and improve quality of life in veterans with glaucoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vascular dysfunction is one of the earliest pathological signs in the progression of Alzheimer’s disease, and cerebral ischemic injuries increase a patient’s risk of developing dementia. Endothelin-1 is increased in patients with AD and ischemia, likely leading to excess vasoconstriction and dysfunction of neurovascular coupling. This proposal will investigate whether endothelin-1 causes neurovascular coupling dysfunction after an ischemic injury and whether this contributes to Alzheimer’s disease-associated dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Sarcomas driven by gene fusions between Capicua (CIC) and several partner genes including DUX4 and NUTM1 present as aggressive tumors with dismal outcomes and few treatment options. This project will improve our understanding of the biology underlying these diseases by dissecting how CIC-DUX4 can be relocalized within a cell, and by uncovering the mechanisms CIC-NUTM1 uses to drive tumors. This knowledge will reveal new ways to inactivate the driving causes of CIC-rearranged sarcomas, leading to more effective therapies for an underserved patient population.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In stroke rehabilitation, it is believed that improving an individual’s capacity (what they are capable of doing on in-clinic measures) leads to improvements in an individual’s performance (what they actually do in the real- world); however, recent work has identified that an individual’s capacity and performance are not always congruent after rehabilitation. Learned non-use, the incongruence between capacity and performance after stroke, was originally identified in deafferented animal models with impaired proprioception, and this proposal will focus on the critical gap related to the contributions of proprioception on learned non-use in individuals with stroke. Completion of this proposed research will identify potential underlying mechanisms of learned non-use that will inform future rehabilitation efforts to combat this phenomenon that limits full functional recovery. .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Abnormal posture and postural instability are treatment-resistant symptoms of Parkinson’s disease (PD) that contribute significantly to decreased mobility, falls, and reduced quality of life, and the mechanisms contributing to these motor signs are poorly understood. This project will use two noninvasive neuromodulation techniques (transcranial magnetic stimulation and electrical vestibular stimulation) to explore the characteristics of the neural control of the trunk muscles in sitting, standing, and turning in people with PD compared to healthy controls. The results of these experiments will increase our knowledge of the impact of PD on the neural control of the trunk in abnormal postures which will help with the development of targeted therapies to improve postural instability in people with PD.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immune checkpoint inhibitor therapy, such as PD-1 blockade therapy, has substantially improved the treatment of triple negative breast cancer but limitations persist. Investigating understudied components in the tumor microenvironment, such as B lymphocytes, could improve clinical outcomes and inform future therapeutic studies. Our preliminary data suggest that PD-blockade therapy could regulate the antitumor function of B lymphocytes, and additional investigation is needed to better understand this mechanism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Inflammation plays a major role in heart and vascular disease and is driven in large part by immune cells, which can dynamically increase or resolve inflammation; however, most knowledge related to specific roles of immune cells in heart and vascular disease is from animal models, which have immune systems that differ from humans in important ways. We address this gap directly in this application, in which we will determine precise immune cell features in the blood and arterial plaque of humans underlying heart attack, stroke, and leg artery disease. This offers the potential to uncover precise, human-relevant immune cell components that may be targeted to resolve inflammation and reduce human heart and arterial disease risk.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Dexamethasone and other synthetic glucocorticoids are commonly used to prevent bronchopulmonary dysplasia in preterm infants but they are known to impair brain and somatic growth. Ciclesonide is a synthetic glucocorticoid prodrug that is rapidly converted to its active form in the lung and has been shown in neonatal models of brain and lung injury to be as efficacious in preventing lung injury without causing significant brain or systemic toxicity. In this study, we will pursue a phase I dose escalation clinical study using an inhaled preparation of ciclesonide to establish its safety and toxicity profile in preterm infants, while also assessing levels of CIC metabolites and glucocorticoid receptor activation profile.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: RELEVANCE NSUN2 is an RNA methyltransferase that converts cytosine to 5-methylcytosine (m5C) and is required for the decoding activity and stability of tRNAs and coding/noncoding mRNAs. NSUN2 mutations have been widely involved in developmental defects, including male infertility, Dubowitz-like syndrome, and intellectual disability, as well as in cancer. Dissecting the unique functions of the NSUN2-regulated epitranscriptome through liquid- liquid phase separation in the translational control of pluripotent stem cells is fundamental to developmental biology and disease modeling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance/ Project Narrative This project develops and tests new devices to measure the concentration of oxygen and carbon dioxide as well as the acid-base status of human blood. Measurements like this are made many times per day in patients with respiratory failure, circulatory shock, and many other conditions leading to critical illness and care in the intensive care unit. The new devices will provide the capability for accurate, frequent measurements at the bedside with immediate results, which will greatly improve upon existing techniques and provide critical tools to clinicians caring for hospitalized patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE OF PARENT K08 To improve alcohol use disorder treatment, particularly through precision medicine approaches, it is imperative that alcohol use disorder etiologic mechanisms are identified and assessed in a way that is reliable and valid across diverse groups of individuals. The proposed study will use a multimethod approach to develop and  validate a computerized adaptive test of alcohol use disorder etiologic mechanisms. Ultimately, the goal of this  work is to establish an efficient and comprehensive assessment of mechanisms that can be used in service of  determining the optimal treatment, whether behavioral, pharmacological, or both, for a given person with  alcohol use disorder. PROJECT NARRATIVE FOR PROPOSED ADMINISTRATIVE SUPPLEMENT This project proposes an administrative supplement to support the principal investigator’s return to full productivity following time-limited period of parental leave. The proposed supplement will provide additional personnel support which will facilitate progress towards the parent award’s overall goal of improving alcohol use disorder treatment through precision medicine approaches by enhancing the identification and assessment of the factors that cause and maintain alcohol use disorder.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While hormones of fetal origin have long been postulated to regulate placental nutrient delivery, our laboratory recently produced the first direct evidence of this phenomenon with chronic (9-day) fetal glucagon infusions reducing uterine blood flow, placental nutrient transfer, and placental lactogen secretion. The goal of this proposal is to identify the physiological mechanism by which fetal glucagon regulates trophoblast function and thereby, placental delivery of nutrients. Furthermore, results from this proposal will identify a previously unknown adaptive strategy for matching nutrient delivery to fetal metabolic demand, thus improving survival in complicated pregnancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) establishes a lifelong, silent infection in sensory neurons, and occasionally is reactivated to cause diseases that range in severity from benign cold sores to encephalitis. The proposed studies focus on a novel immunoevasion mechanism of the immediate-early protein of the virus ICP0 that is mediated by its interaction with the endocytosis adaptor protein CIN85. The ICP0/CIN85 complex subjugates endocytosis and exocytosis pathways during HSV-1 infection in order to suppress the function of host proteins with antiviral activity, facilitating virus infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Offspring born with fetal growth restriction (FGR) have increased incidence of metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD) and periportal fibrosis. The goal of this proposal is to advance our understanding of the mechanism for increased periportal collagen deposition, a sign of developing fibrosis, in the liver of the fetus with FGR and the impact on future liver metabolic disease. Results from this proposal will be used to help understand how fibrosis develops in postnatal liver of FGR offspring and determine future mechanistic experiments to investigate fetal origins of hepatic fibrosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tumor-associated macrophages (TAMs), derived from circulating monocytes, are among the most abundant immune cells in the tumor microenvironment and play an important role in suppressing immune responses and promoting cancer development, as well as in contributing to immune checkpoint blockade resistance. The proposed study seeks to understand how the cytokines macrophage-colony stimulating factor (M-CSF) and granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF) differ in the induction of TAM-associated functional characteristics in differentiated cells, and whether early unique metabolic changes in monocytes are responsible. This work will enhance our understanding of critical functional differences between M-CSF and GM-CSF generated TAM-like cells and potentially highlight new metabolic mechanisms that regulate TAM-associated functions, which could ultimately benefit TAM-targeting cancer immunotherapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People living in rural and other underserved areas, such as Appalachia, are more likely to experience disability, morbidity, and premature mortality; despite the increasing prevalence of newly acquired disabilities and their negative impact on the well-being of rural residents, we currently lack grounded perspectives on barriers and facilitators to optimal quality of life and health outcomes for people with disabilities. Consistent with NIH’s recent recognition of people with disabilities as a “health disparity population,” the proposed research will investigate diverse factors and circumstances that contributing to health inequities for rural, disabled, and underserved populations. This mixed methods research will expand knowledge of disability in Appalachia; identify gaps in health and human services; illuminate strategies to address individual, interpersonal, and community, and policy-level challenges; and inform the future development and implementation of interventions across the socioecological model to improve the lives of people with disabilities and their families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Renal fibromuscular dysplasia (FMD), a curable yet under-studied disease linked with increased morbidity and mortality rates, is associated with high blood pressure in pregnant women. Our goal is to use computational and machine learning techniques to examine kidney blood flow in FMD patients, with a focus on those also dealing with hypertension during pregnancy. Through this study, we hope to better understand this disease and potentially enhance the effectiveness of treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aside from socioeconomic status, factors that drive heart health disparities among American young adults with type 1 diabetes are not well defined. Heart health is shaped by multiple intersections of social identities (gender, race, social class, disability) and discrimination stress. In this study, the links between social and environmental determinants of health, discrimination, and heart health will be explored as well as the lived experience of perceived discrimination among young adults with type 1 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a progressive neurodegenerative dementia that lacks reliable therapies to markedly slow disease pathology and its symptoms. Pathological tau protein deposition and propagation to various brain regions correlates strongly with cognitive decline in AD such that strategies to reduce tau burden may be an effective treatment. The research proposed in this fellowship aims to evaluate a novel in vivo approach for proteasomal activation to degrade tau, mitigate tau propagation, and alleviate neuronal loss as a potential therapy for AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Infants born with complex congenital heart disease (CHD) depend on surgical intervention for treatment, yet complications from synthetic materials used in reconstruction result in lifelong morbidity. Tissue engineered vascular grafts (TEVGs) are a promising solution, transforming into growing blood vessels, yet the LYST protein contributes to graft narrowing, the primary complication preventing the widespread clinical use of TEVGs. Understanding LYST's role in TEVG narrowing could facilitate the development of therapeutic methods to reduce complications in vascular grafts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Raf kinases are central components of many intracellular signaling networks in eukaryotes. Despite the role of mis-regulated Raf function and activity in numerous cancers, many fundamental aspects of Raf-mediated signaling are still poorly understood. Here, we will use chemical biological, biochemical, and cellular analysis techniques to analyze the regulation, intracellular function, and pharmacology of Raf kinases with the goal of providing new insight into how to more effectively target these enzymes as anti-cancer therapies.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative INSPIRE will leverage deep expertise and resources in dissemination and implementation research and participatory approaches that center on advanced methods and modeling, and capacity support, while nurturing community engagement and dissemination practices. By harnessing the strengths and assets within the PATC3H-IN, findings will improve health outcomes of AYA at risk or living with HIV, by identifying novel insights on how to adapt, scale-up and sustain HIV research for AYA. A project of this scale has the potential to shift the paradigm on how dissemination and implementation science research is conducted for AYA in settings traditionally under-represented in research.
